column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Have you ever noticed that the way speakers at conferences present varies widely? Some are extremely boring, others entirely engaging, and everything in between.

The goal of this course is that upon completion you are ready and able to engage your audiences from the first sentence. At that initial moment (when they realize ‘OOOOOH, THIS is going to be a good one’), that they put their phones off and get ready to take notes. And afterward, that people gather around you to hear more or to connect at a later time.
This is possible! In this course you will:
●    Clarify what your current presentation strengths and development areas are
●    Understand what presentation techniques are received most positively by audiences in both ‘live’ and ‘virtual’ settings
●    Learn what behaviors to avoid when presenting
●    Learn to effectively interact and engage your audience
●    Learn how to deliver your message clearly and concisely
●    Learn how to present to large groups at conferences successfully</body>

column1: In every area of business, effective practitioners weave together these four distinct yet mutually reinforcing problem-solving and collaborative capabilities:

column2: They leverage technical expertise not only to solve problems but also earn credibility

column1: These capabilities apply especially to financial managers.  Undoubtedly, mastering the language and rules of accounting is essential.  But to become effective professionals who advise and influence decision-makers, financial managers and their teams must also be able to translate accounting numbers into business insights, communicate them simply and powerfully, and formulate compelling recommendations.

In this course, we will explore a few of the ‘social’ aspects that complement the technical dimension of accounting.  We will touch upon the fundamentals of translating numbers into business insight, developing recommendations, and structuring these insights and recommendations into compelling business presentations.

column1: The format of this course is 3 half-day sessions, during which several aspects of presenting will be highlighted. Participants will present multiple times, to watch themselves grow. A mandatory pre-assignment needs to be sent in at least 1 week in advance, so that wishes and expectations for the program can be anticipated. This will allow for customization of each training.  Although pitching and presenting are not the same thing, pitching will also be addressed during the course, as PhD candidates deal with this a lot. On the third day a fellow scientist will be present to watch and give feedback, as it is important that the practice of science is part of this training. In this way, practice and theory will coincide as much as possible.
The focus of the three meetings will be on:
- How to make science interesting to listen to and to watch
- Think about who your target audience is and what is important to them
- Determine what you want to get across
- Determine the necessity of your story and work with it
- With preparation and structure, you do yourself a lot of favors and thus also your audience
- Learn to see and watch to be able to respond to your audience. What do you see and what do you interpret?
Be sure to register at least 3 weeks before to the start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

column2: • Learn what is needed for preparing and delivering a scientific presentation
• Become aware of themselves as a presenter and research what suits them best to come across well
• Discover more their own style and gather tools on how to develop this
• Understand the need and motivation to tune into the target group and translate their interests into their own story
• Apply and try out the material provided during and outside the lessons
• Learn to know what you see and give targeted and tailored feedback, for colleagues to improve and to learn from themselves

column4: At least 1 week before the start of the course

column5: Prepare a pitch, a 2-minute presentation using the structure in the syllabus. Bring your preparation sheet so it can be used for feedback.
Prepare a final presentation of max 10 minutes. Indicate your goals and target group.

column1: One week after the end of the course, your assignments, evaluation, and attendance will be registered in OSIRIS as PA (=completed), NO (=not completed) or O (=fail).
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.
Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years.
Shortly after the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>‘Preventie en bestraffing’ gaat over de verschillende manieren waarop we reageren op criminaliteit. Het gaat dan in de eerste plaats om straf. Straf is niet alleen een reactie achteraf, maar de dreiging van straf dient ook om criminaliteit te voorkomen. We bespreken in dit vak uitgebreid het onderzoek naar de effectiviteit van verschillende vormen van preventie van criminaliteit, zowel door straf, als door sociale en situationele interventies. We kijken ook naar ontwikkelingen in het bestraffingsbeleid, in historisch en internationaal perspectief. Hoe soft of streng is Nederland in vergelijking tot andere landen en hoe heeft het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid zich ontwikkeld in de afgelopen 30 jaar? Deze ontwikkelingen worden geduid met behulp van het begrip beheerscultuur.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In dit vak zullen jullie kennis opdoen van de verschillende strafdoelen, hun onderlinge relatie en de mate waarin zij in het huidige sanctiebeleid tot uitdrukking komen. Tevens biedt dit vak inzicht in de doelstellingen en effectiviteit van verschillende resocialiserende interventies en andere mogelijkheden tot preventie van criminaliteit, met als doel voor verschillende criminaliteitsproblemen aanbevelingen te kunnen doen voor effectieve interventies, en kritisch te kunnen reflecteren op de waarde van effectiviteitsonderzoek van interventies. Voorts zullen jullie in dit vak leren om de ontwikkelingen in het Nederlandse sanctiebeleid in een historisch kader en internationaal vergelijkend perspectief te plaatsen. Daarnaast kunnen jullie, na afloop van het vak, de huidige verhouding tussen dader, slachtoffers en maatschappij verklaren aan de hand van het begrip beheerscultuur. Dit biedt het kader om diverse aspecten van het huidige sanctiebeleid met elkaar in verband te brengen en de maatschappelijke consequenties ervan te kunnen doorgronden.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Price setting is a crucial aspect of a marketing strategy, involving both supply side factors (e.g. costs) and demand side factors (e.g. consumer willingness to pay).

Pricing approaches have evolved from very restrained economic and financial perspectives to a broader consumer-oriented framework. In this course, we will study different approaches to have a comprehensive understanding of the economic, strategic, and behavioral considerations that impact a pricing strategy. We will study theoretical concepts linked to economic and behavioral approaches to pricing, price customization/discrimination, price bundling and multi-part tariffs, value-based pricing, dynamic pricing, retail pricing strategies, pricing for goods/services with externalities, and pricing in two-sided markets. We will use examples and case studies from various product categories such as consumer packaged goods, financial services, healthcare plans, and cell phone plans.

In the course, we will use the textbooks by Cabral and Smith, and a variety of readings, and cases. Readings and case references, notes and handouts will be announced throughout the block. The textbooks and the readings are designed to introduce basic concepts and principles. Cases will allow us to examine, in detail, the application of particular concepts and principles in business settings.
Attendance is compulsory for guest lectures and presentations, and highly recommended otherwise. There will be no make-up sessions in case you cannot attend a session.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the economic and financial aspects of pricing: estimate the demand curve, estimate customer willingness-to-pay, and calculate profit-maximizing prices
• Develop a value-based pricing strategy that also considers the effect of non-price factors on perceived value
• Learn to spot all relevant aspects of pricing in the marketplace, through business applications, examples and case studies

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113181,2023,Principles of Ecology: Biodiversity & Nature-Inclusive Design,Engels,Erasmus University College,,[],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course provides a background in the fundamental principles of ecology, including concepts of population sampling, population dynamics, community interactions and ecological succession. Students will acquire an ""ecological literacy"" about how the natural world works, and develop an understanding of how scientific methods are used to construct ecological knowledge. The course will also explore the issue of biodiversity loss as one of today's major ecological challenges, and the importance of research on nature-inclusive design to address these concerns. This course is aimed at giving students an overview of the field of ecology and how it applies to the sustainability of human societies. If you are curious about how we can address the major challenge of biodiversity loss, this course will provide you with a good introduction to the nested complexity of the natural world and to the use of design to include nature in our surroundings.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, you will be able to:

column2: • analyse how biotic and abiotic interactions give rise to patterns of abundance and distribution of organisms at several scales;
• design a management plan for the conservation of biodiversity in a world region by assessing the conflicts and opportunities on the use of natural resources by local populations.
• apply ecological principles to current environmental challenges and conservation concerns;
• characterize patterns and processes in nature through direct experience with local ecosystems;
• assess the effects of human disturbance on ecosystems through ecological succession and alternative-stable states theory;
• use ecological models to illustrate the abundance of organisms and the dynamics of populations over time;
• compare structural and functional features between different types of ecosystems;

column1: Does Okun’s law hold in practice? Does the Phillips curve really exist? In this course you will learn how to perform empirical analyses to answer this kind of questions. The course is strongly build upon what you have learnt in Basic Statistics and Intermediate Statistics I and is specifically aimed at students with a major in economics. During the course we will discuss important concepts for time series such as stationarity, unit roots and autoregressive models. Moreover, you will learn how to perform the analyses in the software program Stata.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After succesful completion of this course, you:

column2: • Understand the main concepts related to simple and multiple regression;
• Are aware of common techniques and concepts for time series analysis;
• Are able to apply ordinary least squares;
• Can perform basic analyses in Stata and are able to interpret Stata output;
• Can formulate a research question and testable research hypotheses on the basis of previous research and economic reasoning;
• Can apply statistical methods to answer a research question;
• Are able to structure and discuss the research findings through a written report.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course lays the groundwork for financial modeling in Market-and Bank-Based Financial Markets. As such, the course is a building block for later the electives FinTech and Algorithms in control. We start by discussing sources of company financial information, how different financial statements are connected, and procedures for financial statements forecasting, accuracy assessments, and valuation. In particular, we discuss how data analytics can help in this process.

The results of such analyses are important for investors who use them in assessing the risk and return of investments in corporate credit and equity markets. In each of those two markets we derive a standard optimization representations both for individual investments as well as for portfolios. We link these representations to real-world applications such as platform (P2P) lending, asset management, robo-advising, and high-frequency trading.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Know which financial statements firms report and how these inform financial markets
• Understand how data analytics can help to assess the accuracy of accounting information
• Understand the methods and data issues involved in forecasting financial statements and estimating equity value
• Be able to apply large-scale forecasting and valuation techniques
• Understand the link between risk and expected returns in financial markets
• Understand how this is different for equity and debt markets
• Express investment and insurance problems as standard data learning/optimization problems
• Be able to apply this approach to FinTech business models
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course Principles of Management will introduce you to the field of business administration and its various sub-disciplines. Business Administration is an interdisciplinary and a context-based field of study concerned with the organisation and the market environment of businesses. It is a problem-oriented discipline focusing on issues within organisations (how does an organisation set different goals and objectives?) and the interaction and relationship of the business with its surrounding (how do political factors affect the business?).

Similar to the discipline itself, this course will be context-based, using cases and examples presenting the latest business developments and current challenges business face for students to better understand the business world. Topics that will be discussed include the global context of business (business environments and business types), the business of managing, people in organisations (Human Resource Management, leadership and teams), managing information (IT), principles of marketing and finance, and political, social, economic, technological and ethical considerations affecting business. The course will provide basic knowledge on business therewith preparing you for more specialised 200 and 300 level Economics & Business major courses.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After the course, students are able to:

column2: • Understand the main theoretical perspectives on management and how they relate to the tasks, processes and content of managerial work in organizations;
• Understand the different elements that comprise an organization and relate these to organizational structure and organizational performance;
• Define and critically reflect on the (international) business environment;
• Discuss theories and applications of human resource management;
• Describe and explain the processes, tools and content involved in managing strategy;
• Explain how marketing can add value to the business, identify the marketing environment and its stakeholders;
• Discuss and critically reflect on generic methods of control and performance management, including financial measures to assess performance;
• Critically reflect on how information systems, and ERP systems in particular, can transform organizations and what the antecedents for its success are;
• Evaluate the significance of contemporary issues in business and management.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115005,2023,Principles of Negotiation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. D Tsekouras'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Negotiation training requires both intellectual training and developing skills. The main assumptions of this course are: (a) negotiating is a process that can be understood and (b) negotiating is a skill that can be taught and can be learned. The core questions posed in this course are:

column2: • What are the advantages and disadvantages of various strategies?
• What do these strategies require for success?
• When would these strategies be most appropriate?

column1: The course is a combination of reading & understanding theory (through the recorded lectures, assigned book and academic articles) as well as applying the theory in simulated negotiation role-plays and a research project. The minor consists primarily of plenary lectures based on required theoretical literature. Each lecture consists of a part of discussing the theory and a part where students are applying this theory (e.g., online/offline role plays). In parallel students prepare and execute a research project (e.g., field experiment, survey-based study) where they actively apply insights from the theory while focusing on a topic of their choice.
The main contents covered in this course are:

column2: • The theory of negotiation, including behavioral decision making & decision analytic perspectives,
• Conceptual frameworks to analyze conflict situations in personal and business-related settings and to design negotiation strategies to successfully resolve them.
• Negotiation techniques and their underlying theoretical explanations.
• The role of power, influence and persuasion in negotiations.
• The role of emotions in negotiation situations.
• The role of gender and personality style in negotiations
• The role of non-verbal communications and lie detection in negotiations
• How to manage difficult negotiations/people and the role of negotiation ethics.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <div>The learning objectives of the course in terms of academic knowledge are:

column2: • Analyze conflict situations and design negotiation strategies to successfully resolve them.
• Identify negotiation techniques and their underlying theoretical explanations.
• Comprehend the role of power, influence and persuasion in negotiations
• Identify the role of emotions in negotiation situations.
• Gain insights on the role of gender and personality in negotiations
• Understand non-verbal communication and detect non-verbal cues in negotiations
• Investigate the role of negotiation ethics.
• Reflect and learn from your experience in handling conflict situations
• Acquire new skills by “stretching your comfort zone
• Improve your ability to persuade others and understand their tactics in conflict situations
• Become capable of evaluating the outcomes of a negotiation

column1: De cursus Privaat- en ondernemingsrecht bevat een inleiding in het (privaat)recht. Er wordt aandacht besteed aan de verschillende soorten ondernemingsvormen in het eerste deel van de cursus. In het tweede deel van de cursus staat het verbintenissenrecht en het vermogensrecht centraal. De voorgaande onderworpen worden getoetst door middel van een schriftelijk tentamen.
De onderwerpen die in de cursus worden bestudeerd:

column2: • rechtspersonen (overwegend de besloten vennootschap en de naamloze vennootschap);
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Als econoom zal de student bij het nemen van beslissingen oog moeten hebben voor de bestaande juridische problemen en de oplossingen hiervoor. Na het volgen en behalen van deze cursus moet de student derhalve niet alleen in staat zijn het juridische probleem te beschrijven, maar moet hij tevens de relevante rechtsregels kunnen vinden, waarmee het probleem tot een oplossing kan worden gebracht. De student wordt vertrouwd gemaakt met de belangrijkste grondslagen en begrippen op het gebied van het recht. In het bijzonder wordt in deze cursus aandacht besteed aan het verbintenissenrecht, het vermogensrecht en het ondernemingsrecht.
• Ten aanzien van de personenvennootschappen de noodzakelijke rechtsregels ten aanzien van oprichting, vertegenwoordiging, aansprakelijkheid en verdelingen van winsten en verliezen toepassen.
• De voorgeschreven theorie omtrent de rechtspersonen (in het bijzonder de besloten vennootschap en naamloze vennootschap) toepassen.
• De verschillende vormen van fusie- en overnames toepassen.
• De bronnen van verbintenis benoemen en de samenhangende begrippen hieraan relateren.
• Beoordelen of er een rechtsgeldige overeenkomst tot stand is gekomen, wat de inhoud daarvan is en wat de gevolgen zijn als er niet aan de noodzakelijke voorwaarden is voldaan.
• Beoordelen of er sprake is van een onrechtmatige daad of een kwalitatieve aansprakelijkheid en deze leerstukken kunnen toepassen.
• Het leerstuk van de niet-nakoming toepassen om te beoordelen of een recht op schadevergoeding ontstaat en of ontbinding of opschorting mogelijk is.
• De overdracht van verschillende soorten goederen (inclusief de derdenbescherming) toepassen;

column1: In dit vak wordt het Rotterdamse credo ‘where law meets business’ in de praktijk gebracht. Het vak rust inhoudelijk op de drie pijlers van het vermogensrecht: delictueel aansprakelijkheidsrecht, contractenrecht en goederen- en insolventierecht. Het vak omvat bedrijfs- en kantoorbezoeken, masterclasses, schriftelijke en mondelinge opdrachten en is geënt op problemen in de praktijk, die op een juridisch-academische wijze worden opgelost.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• argumenten uit de bestudeerde literatuur inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module onder woorden brengen en analyseren en de verschillende invalshoeken synthetiseren tot een afgewogen standpunt;
• de huidige stand van de rechtspraak inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module onder woorden brengen en analyseren en deze toepassen op een concrete casus;
• identificeren wat de voornaamste praktijkproblemen zijn inzake het centrale onderwerp van de module en het belang en de omvang van die problemen inschatten;
• in samenwerking oplossingen aandragen voor een juridisch complex praktijkprobleem en kan binnen die samenwerking zich een eigen visie vormen en die motiveren.
• met betrekking tot een complexe juridische praktijkkwestie een inhoudelijke positie schriftelijk innemen en in een mondeling debat verdedigen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Popular accounts of privacy assert that it is a kind of commodity that may be ‘traded’ in exchange for security, or even convenience. This often overlooks how popular and even scholarly understandings of privacy are shaped by technological affordances as well as ideology. Moreover, these accounts shape what is considered appropriate and even ethical for media users, including researchers. This course considers how privacy is made meaningful as a legal/policy requirement, a cultural reference, and an ethical guide. Students will apply multidisciplinary accounts of privacy to various professional contexts, including their own scholarship.

This course aims to develop the students’ critical thinking about privacy and ethics issues of new technologies. It does so by exploring how privacy thought has evolved from being the ‘right to be let alone’ to being key for a free and democratic society, the introduction of the GDPR and the legislative focus on consent. Further to privacy, this module discusses the ethical dimension of Artificial Intelligence and ethics in research, which it will help provide the students with a solid foundation to conduct future research and work.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Multi-disciplinary accounts of privacy and other related concepts.
• How new technologies may impact public perception of social and ethical conditions.
• Critique technological advancements and applications in terms of their ethical and privacy impacts.
• Design and implement privacy-oriented tools, such as, privacy impact assessments and research ethics considerations.
• Differentiate between the different privacy conceptualisations and discuss their importance to the development of the concept of privacy.
• Formulate research problems related to privacy in socio-technological systems.

column1: From very humble beginnings in the 1980s, Private Equity has become a very large Asset Class. Although fundraising has levelled off in 2019 and 2020 from an all-time record in 2018, still, at the end of 2020 over $2 trillion of “dry powder” globally is looking to be invested by PE funds.

This course aims to give students a solid introduction to the world of Private Equity (including Venture Capital and Buyouts). It focuses on the following (along with practical insight from prior transactions) main areas of knowledge that underpin the PE environment:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand PE general concepts, how PE funds are formed, how they are managed and operate, how they pursue value creation for their stakeholders
• Be knowledgeable about the key attributes of private equity as an asset class; be able to apply specific Private Equity valuation and modelling techniques

• Understand the PE process and all components needed to successfully complete a PE transaction (valuation, leverage, transaction structure, transaction due diligence SPA signing, closing and post-closing)
• Recognize how market conditions impact the Private Equity industry: leverage & credit markets, equity market valuations
• Anticipate events and trends within the Private Equity industry and gain deeper insight of advanced corporate finance

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This is an exciting and transformative moment for streaming industries across the globe. As the economics of media industries shift from advertising-based revenue models to subscriber-based revenue models, streaming platforms that provide different types of content directly to consumers are becoming increasingly important. For example, the global expansion of streaming video on-demand services like Netflix both reflect and drive change within traditional audiovisual media industries like television and film. Yet, the proprietary nature of streaming audience data and the near total lack of data transparency offered by streaming companies themselves (e.g. Netflix, Spotify, YouTube) creates a variety of challenges for media industry researchers.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students have advanced their knowledge, understanding and awareness of:
- Using the “production culture” approach to understand media industry discourse and/or media industry practice.

- Gather and analyze relevant data about the streaming industries from a variety of publicly available secondary sources including but not limited to trade press articles, press releases, trade and popular press interviews, videos of industry events, annual reports, policy reports, and financial documents;
- Formulate a research question related to a specific streaming service situated within a broader streaming industr;
- Create a qualitative research design, collect and then analyze data;
- Execute the above research design and produce an academic research

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116073,2023,Professional Development & Mentoring I,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J Alkema', 'JJ Werkhoven, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: As the world turns, many (workplace) innovations result in speedy changes to both our personal and professional lives that outpace an individual’s ability to adapt. To stay connected and up-to-date, the future of work calls for lifelong learning (‘LLL’) and emphasises continued development of cognitive, social, emotional, and technological skills. It no longer is enough to simply obtain a Bachelor degree. Those who want to remain employable and successful throughout their careers and want to fully participate in society need to embrace a growth mindset and muster the (self-)awareness, discipline, and motivation to constantly develop themselves and others.

In addition, our increasingly globalised world leads to higher levels of ambiguity and complexity. Many of the problems and challenges managers are confronted with today (and in the future) require careful consideration and evaluation of different trade-offs and stakeholders. Those who want to become agents for positive change need to understand how to navigate these complexities with integrity, open-mindedness, and balance.

Clearly, it should now be evident to you as future (business/management) professional that it is not enough anymore to solely be a content expert and understand the intricacies of subjects such as finance, marketing, and operations management. Instead, you need to be equally skilful when it comes to things such as time- and self-management, emotion regulation, stakeholder management and moral decision-making.

This course (Professional Development & Mentoring 1) aims to support you in developing these skills. This requires continuous self-reflection, feedback and above all practice. Therefore, particular emphasis is placed on small-scale workshops in which you and your fellow students will actively practice the skills taught through lectures, online modules, and self-study. Throughout the course, you will regularly reflect on your own development and receive (peer) feedback.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, students are able to:

column2: Demonstrate, self-regulate, and reflect upon (their own) professional student behaviour (e.g., schedule personal time; track personal development; take personal accountability).

Demonstrate collaborative and successful teamwork behaviour in diverse and inclusive team settings (e.g., active listening; perspective-taking; constructive feedback giving and receiving; team accountability).
Display a growth mindset full of curiosity, self-awareness, balance, and open-mindedness.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115067,2023,Professional Development II,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. TA Alade'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The world is demanding new leadership for positive impact in an ever more complex and dynamic world. Professional Development is a course organized by the Department of Business-Society Management and focuses on the role of the business leader as a positive impact agent. As a benefit, this course offers you transformational knowledge, tools, and professional development skills (21st-century skills) to lead yourself and others, better understand and positively change organizations and the world. These benefits would be achieved by focusing on the three goals of the course.

In today’s highly demanding and complex world, it is inadequate to only acquire an excellent university degree, without skills that can provide a positive impact. These skills are more important to you now than ever before because they not only provide a framework for successful learning in the classroom but ensure you can thrive in the real world and future workplaces where change is constant, inevitable, and learning never stops. According to Charles Darwin, “It is not the strongest of species that survives, nor the most intelligent that survives. It is the one that is the most adaptable to change”.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Analyze the demands of the system (i.e. organizations) and your capabilities to resolve the challenges you encounter for positive societal change.
Evaluate your application of life-long learning skills to foster continuous professional development and thrive in a dynamic and complex world.
Evaluate the impact of your communication and collaboration skills in different settings.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116469,2023,Professional Development and Consulting,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['JJ Werkhoven, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Professional Development and Consulting runs from September till the beginning of January and forms the foundation in which students connect core course knowledge to skills development, personal development, and a real-life organisational context.

The main objective of this course is to help students be aware of their competencies and further develop these. Competencies consists of knowledge, skills, and attitude and therefore within this course students will gain new skills, work on their professional development, and connect the knowledge they acquired in our four knowledge courses (Strategic HRM, Organisational Design, People Analytics and Leading Organisational Change) to a real-life organisational context.
More specifically, this course consists of two elements:

column2: Company Project In teams, our students will step in the role of consultant and apply newly learned competencies a real-life organisation. The objective is that the student consultants will develop new and interesting insights and advice for a great variety of companies. We prepare students for this by training them on skills needed in this project.

Personal Development In tandem with the project and workshops, our students will work on their personal development. Based on self-assessment and feedback received by peers and professors, we encourage students to regularly reflect. Students will engage in mentoring circles (3 peers and an alum) aimed at students supporting each other and grow together. In doing so, students will be able to critically evaluate their own strengths and weaknesses and develop further.

column1: In this course you will collaborate with others (peers, alums, company coaches) in different settings. As others will invest their time, it is expected that you are present (in person) in each class. If you cannot make it, you are responsible for managing the stakeholders and agreeing on alternative timeslots to meet.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Apply relevant skills in the field of People, Organisations and Change to a real-life organisational context
• Lead a consulting project based on the phases of consulting
• Integrate self-awareness and the impact you have on others to develop your professional identity

column3: The module Professional Development focuses on the preparation for the labor market. The program is composed of:

column5: a four-days study-trip to International Organizations and Non-Governmental Organizations in Geneva. The study-trip is mandatory and involves extra costs [airfare ticket, lodging];
a one day visit to the European institutions in Brussels
a series of guest-lectures by practitioners and labor market experts to make students familiar with the and to help them to find their way at the international labor market.

column3: The trip to Geneva takes place in the Fall, the visit to Brussels in the Spring. Students are kindly invited to participate in the design and organization of the program.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After passing the module professional development students will be able to:
* understand the range of possible careers available to the graduates, including their advantages and disadvantages
* describe the main features of the international labor market, including selection procedures and entrance requirements of relevant employers;
* make informed choices about possible career paths;
* prepare an application package that meet international standards in order to be successful on the international labor market.

column1: In this course, students will have the opportunity to acquire skills necessary for employment in the professional practice of interventions and policies aimed at health behavior change. They will learn skills in evaluating their own achievement in critically reflecting on personal and professional development in the context of health psychology and behavior change. After the course students have the skills to carry out the steps of planning behavior change programs and reflect on their personal and team skills to manage such programs. The course runs in combination with the course Health Psychology and Behavior change and students will have the chance to develop skills they can apply when developing the behavior change intervention in that course.
The professional skills course addresses four topics:

column2: • Team skills: with whom do you collaborate and how?
• Managing the process of project planning: how do you organize your project and use time management or budgeting?
• Diffusion, implementation and communication: knowledge brokerage aimed at your target population such as policy makers.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course you will be able to...
• Critically assess personal strengths and weaknesses with regard to personal skills and team skills.
• Apply the skills and methods for planning health behaviour change programs.

• Create a personal portfolio using a personal leadership plan on where you are, a reflection on strengths and weaknesses, a plan with your personal and professional goals, and skills you need to develop.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Terwijl de wereld draait, resulteren veel (werkplek)innovaties in snelle veranderingen in zowel ons persoonlijke als professionele leven die het aanpassingsvermogen van een individu te boven gaan. Om ‘connected’ en bij de tijd te blijven, vraagt de toekomst van werk om levenslang leren (""LLL"") en wordt er nadruk gelegd op de voortdurende ontwikkeling van cognitieve, sociale, emotionele en technologische vaardigheden. Het is niet langer voldoende om simpelweg een bachelordiploma te behalen. Wie tijdens zijn loopbaan inzetbaar en succesvol wil blijven en volwaardig wil participeren in de samenleving, moet het idee van een groeimentaliteit omarmen en het (zelf)bewustzijn, de discipline en de motivatie opbrengen om zichzelf en anderen voortdurend te ontwikkelen.

Bovendien leidt onze steeds meer geglobaliseerde wereld tot een hogere mate van ambiguïteit en complexiteit. Veel van de problemen en uitdagingen waarmee managers vandaag (en in de toekomst) worden geconfronteerd, vereisen een zorgvuldige evaluatie van verschillende trade-offs en stakeholders. Wie positieve veranderingen wil bewerkstelligen, moet begrijpen hoe hij met integriteit, een open geest en gebalanceerd door deze complexe situaties kan navigeren.

Het moet nu duidelijk zijn voor jou als toekomstige (business/management) professional dat het niet meer voldoende is om alleen een inhoudsdeskundige te zijn en de fijne kneepjes te begrijpen van onderwerpen als finance, marketing en operations management. In plaats daarvan moet je even vaardig zijn als het gaat om zaken als tijd- en zelfmanagement, emotieregulatie, stakeholder management en morele besluitvorming.

Deze cursus (Professionele Ontwikkeling & Mentoraat 1) is bedoeld om je te ondersteunen bij het ontwikkelen van deze vaardigheden. Dit vereist voortdurende zelfreflectie, feedback en bovenal oefening. Daarom wordt bijzondere nadruk gelegd op kleinschalige workshops waarin jij en jouw medestudenten de vaardigheden die je via hoorcolleges, online modules en zelfstudie hebt geleerd, actief in praktijk brengt. Door heel het vak heen reflecteer je regelmatig op je eigen ontwikkeling en krijg je (peer)feedback.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na het volgen van dit vak, is het mogelijk voor studenten om:

column2: • Professioneel studentengedrag te demonstreren, te zelfreguleren, en hierop te (zelf)reflecteren (bijv. persoonlijke tijd plannen; persoonlijke ontwikkeling bijhouden; persoonlijke verantwoordelijkheid nemen).

• Collaboratief en succesvol teamwerkgedrag te laten zien in diverse en inclusieve teamomgevingen (bijv. actief luisteren; perspectief nemen; constructieve feedback geven en ontvangen; teamverantwoordelijkheid).
• Een groeimentaliteit vol nieuwsgierigheid, zelfbewustzijn, balans en openheid van geest (‘open-mindedness’) vertonen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115070,2023,Professionele ontwikkeling II,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. TA Alade'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De wereld vraagt om nieuw leiderschap voor positieve impact in een steeds complexere en dynamische wereld. Professionele Ontwikkeling is een cursus georganiseerd door de vakgroep Business-Society Management en richt zich op de rol van de zakelijke leider als een positive impact agent. Als voordeel biedt deze cursus je transformationele kennis, hulpmiddelen en professionele ontwikkelingsvaardigheden (21e-eeuwse vaardigheden) om jezelf en anderen te leiden, organisaties en de wereld beter te begrijpen en positief te veranderen. Deze voordelen worden bereikt door je te richten op de drie doelen van de cursus.

In de veeleisende en complexe wereld van vandaag is het onvoldoende om alleen een uitstekend universitair diploma te halen, zonder vaardigheden die een positieve impact kunnen hebben. Deze vaardigheden zijn nu belangrijker dan ooit omdat ze niet alleen een kader bieden voor succesvol leren in het klaslokaal, maar er ook voor zorgen dat je kunt gedijen in de echte wereld en op toekomstige werkplekken waar verandering constant en onvermijdelijk is en leren nooit stopt. Volgens Charles Darwin ""is het niet de sterkste soort die overleeft, noch de intelligentste die overleeft. Het is degene die zich het beste kan aanpassen aan veranderingen"".

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
•  Doel 1 - Analyseer de eisen van het systeem (d.w.z. organisaties) en je mogelijkheden om de uitdagingen die je tegenkomt op te lossen voor positieve maatschappelijke verandering.
•  Doel 2 - Evalueer je toepassing van vaardigheden voor een leven lang leren om voortdurende professionele ontwikkeling te stimuleren en te gedijen in een dynamische en complexe wereld.
•  Doel 3 - Evalueer de impact van je communicatie- en samenwerkingsvaardigheden in verschillende omgevingen.

column1: Studenten dienen te werken met Java. Hiervoor is een Java Development Kit (JDK) en een editor/IDE nodig.
Voor de JDK raden we de gratis Eclipse Temurin aan van het Adoptium project: https://adoptium.net/
Voor de editor/IDE raden we de gratis IntelliJ IDEA Edu versie aan: https://www.jetbrains.com/idea-edu/
Er is ook een betaalde versie van IntelliJ IDEA, waar gratis student-licenties voor zijn, maar deze versie heeft geen voordelen ten op zichte van de gratis Edu versie binnen dit vak.

Het is ook mogelijk om binnen dit vak te werken met alternatieve editors, zoals Eclipse, Netbeans, Visual Studio Code, Vim, Emacs, etcetera. IntelliJ IDEA biedt echter de beste hulp aan bij het programmeren, en we kunnen gebruikers van dit pakket makkelijker ondersteuning bieden tijdens de practica.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Welcome to the ‘programming for managers’ course. This course aims to strengthen your abilities as future managers with one of the most important yet mostly missing skills for managers: the art of programming. Managers with programming experience can be involved in the decision-making process of their developers. They can also --at a high level-- understand whether each developer is performing well. In this course, we will focus on one of the most widely used programming languages: Java. This course also lays the foundation for learning other important programming languages. Programming is an art and the entire career of many people worldwide. You should not expect to be developers in a few weeks. You should rather treat this course as an intense programming tutorial for absolute beginners. After taking this course, you will learn how to excel in Java even further or to start learning a new programming language from scratch. Java is greatly structured to be an easy-to-learn, yet a powerful programming language. We make sure we will help you as much as we can on this journey.

Previous years' results show that there is a strong correlation between class attendance and participation on the one hand, and students' final grades on the other. We, therefore, encourage you to use all modes of learning that we offer in this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Distinguish between object-oriented programming and procedural programming
• Rank the readability of any given Java code according to the ‘good programming style’ guidelines
• For any given Java code, describe what the code does in most cases, without executing the code
• For any given Java code, debug the errors of the code in most cases
• For any given class-diagram, create the corresponding Java code in most cases
• Implement most of the medium-size (with class diagrams with less than 10 classes) Java projects

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Progressive Changemakers: Diversity, Inclusion and the Future of Work is a 7-week course that explores the intersection of diversity, inclusion and the future of work in organizations. This course will cover topics such as remote and hybrid working, the gig economy, digitization, automation, and the rise of social and sustainable enterprises.
The course will use a constructivist teaching approach, where students will be empowered to construct their own knowledge with the guidance of the teacher.

The course will consist of self-study (including reading of relevant literature) and interactive sessions (including practical exercises, case discussions, and simulations). The course will also include a full-day workshop to encourage students to apply the content to their own practice as leaders and team members, as well as to practical examples and problems in organizations. Overall, this course will equip students with the skills to become progressive changemakers in organizations, promoting diversity and inclusion while navigating the future of work.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the concept of diversity and inclusion in the workplace and the current state of diversity and inclusion in organizations.
• Explore the impact of remote and hybrid working, the gig economy, digitization, automation, and social and sustainable enterprises on diversity and inclusion in the workplace.
• Develop strategies for building and managing diverse and inclusive remote and hybrid teams, gig workers, digital and automated workplaces, and social and sustainable teams.
• Apply the content of the course to their own practice as leaders and team members, as well as to practical examples and problems in organizations.
• Understand the future of work and the implications it has on diversity and inclusion.
• Evaluate their own progress and performance through 3 interim progress submissions and group participation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course Psychodiagnostics B1 is part of the learning path Vocational Skills. During your Bachelor and Master program you will participate in several courses that are part of this learning path and that will build on each other, helping you develop into an academically trained psychologist. The focus of the Vocational Skills learning path is on the development of important professional skills in the context of psychodiagnostics, communication, intervention, and professional ethics. The aim is to help you gradually develop from a novice to a professional that is equipped with all the necessary skills to enter the labor market.

The course Psychodiagnostics B1 exists of three modules that offer an introduction to psychodiagnostics relating to three different diagnostic domains: (1) intelligence and personality, (2) neuropsychology, and (3) developmental psychology. You will acquire knowledge and skills in the field of psychodiagnostics in accordance with the guidelines of the Basic Registration Psychodiagnostics*, a quality label of the Dutch Association of Psychologists (NIP). In addition, you will gain some insight into the work field of organizational/educational psychologist, neuropsychologists, and developmental psychologists.

The theoretical knowledge acquired by the assigned reading material is put into practice in the practical sessions, where the primary focus is on the diagnostic process. The learning activities are aimed at helping you acquire practical knowledge of the diagnostic cycle (the intake procedure, forming and testing hypotheses, selecting research tools, interpreting and reporting on the results). In addition, both the required reading materials and practical sessions will cover the ‘ethics of psychological assessment’ (e.g., informed consent; confidentiality; cultural sensitivity). During the practical we will also pay attention to observation and self-reflection, which are important skills that are relevant for the whole diagnostic cycle.

In three modules of this course, you will practice with the different steps in the diagnostic cycle. Each module will be concluded with an assignment focused on the diagnostic steps that were central to this module. You will receive feedback on the assignments from your tutor. In your final assignment, you are asked to reflect on all the steps of the diagnostic cycle using the information and feedback from the assignments associated with the three different modules.

* The BAPD (Basisaantekening Psycho-Diagnostiek) is an official certificate issued by the Dutch Association for Psychologists (NIP) to certify that holders of it possess appropriate knowledge and have acquired adequate skills in psychodiagnostics for successful further practice and training in post-master clinical courses.

column2: • Module 1 - period 1.1 - ‘Intelligence and Personality Assessment’: Estella van der Wal
• Module 2 - period 1.2 - ‘Neuropsychological Assessment’: Prof.dr. Katinka Dijkstra and Samuel van Zuijlen
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Explain how psychological assessment is conducted following the diagnostic cycle.

• Understand the diagnostic process regarding different types of questions/goals (recognize, explain, predict, select, assign), within three diagnostic domains (intelligence & personality, neuropsychology, developmental psychology).
• Understand psychometric aspects (validity/reliability) and quality requirements of psychological tests.
• Identify ethical aspects in different steps of the diagnostic process.
• Recognize and acknowledge cultural factors influencing psychological assessment (intercultural competencies).

• Administer, score, interpret, and critically evaluate several commonly used psychological tests/questionnaires (intelligence, personality, neuropsychological, and developmental tests and questionnaires).
• Document the various steps of the psychodiagnostics process (from intake and hypotheses to recommendation) according to the guidelines of the BAPD.

• Reflect on the different steps in the diagnostic process (including an awareness of the considerations that should be made in the selection of tests, and the influence of personal assumptions, shortcomings, and pitfalls in each of these steps).
• Formulate clear learning goals and a concrete improvement plan from these reflections.
• Provide constructive feedback to fellow students on the different steps in the diagnostic process.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The different psychological assessment instruments are important tools to gather information from clients for career advice, ‘diagnosing’ clients, or for companies to hire the best candidates. By using psychological tools, which are designed to be ‘objective and standardized measures of behaviour, affect and cognition’ one can provide recommendations that have the highest likelihood of 109 EUC Course Catalogue 2022-2023 May 2022 success. A score on a well-constructed test reflects an underlying psychological construct such as personality, well-being, emotional functioning, aptitude or cognitive ability. This course deals with both the psychodiagnostic theories as well as the application of the psychological tools and instruments that could be used in different settings including but not limited to clinical and work settings.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: As has been said this course is an introduction to Psychodiagnostics. After completing the course Psychodiagnostics you will have acquired:

column2: • basic knowledge of how a professional consultation is conducted following the hypothesis-testing model
• basic knowledge of personality testing, intelligence testing, neuropsychological testing and anamnesis
• skills in administering, scoring and interpreting some commonly used tests
• an experience in providing feedback to a client about his/her test results

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111100,2023,Psychological Science,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. R Zeelenberg', 'prof.dr. HAEM Pecher']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This elective is aimed at psychology students who would like to learn more about psychology as a science. In this course you will learn how psychological questions can be investigated in a methodologically sound way and how scientific literature can be evaluated. Students learn step-by-step how to get from research question to data collection: which research designs are possible, how to avoid confounds and other interfering factors, which conclusions can and cannot be drawn from data and how to write up research in a clear and scientific way. As part of this course a small experiment will be conducted with the Implicit Association Test, which is often used to investigate stereotyping. Literature on this topic will be used to illustrate research design and the results of the experiment will be the basis of a research report. The structure and content of a research report will be discussed in several tutorial meetings. During practical meetings students will practice with Excel and SPSS and learn how to analyse data and create scientific quality graphs. The statistics covered in this course will overlap with BA1 and BA2, but students will get a deeper and more critical understanding of these topics. At the end of the course students can design, execute, analyze, and report scientific research. In addition, they will be able to critically read scientific articles. The grade for the course will be a combination of the grades for the theoretical exam, practical (open book) exam and the written reports. This elective connects to a special bachelor thesis track in which students perform their own research (under supervision) that will be written up in their bachelor’s thesis. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Why do you forget someone’s name? Why do people who are in love get butterflies in their stomach? Are boys better in math than girls? Do you really use only 10% of your brain? Psychologists try to answer such questions, but they do not always agree. How do we distinguish chitchat from fact? And how do we acquire those facts?

In this elective students will attend lectures, tutorial group meetings and practicals to learn skills that are needed to understand and conduct scientific studies. They will conduct a small experiment on stereotyping and practice analyzing the results and writing a scientific report of this experiment.

During this course students can also start a supervised research project that will serve as the basis for their bachelor’s thesis. The research project will continue to run parallel to course periods 4 to 6. This special track of the bachelor’s thesis is not mandatory, but highly recommended for students who take this elective.
By the end of this course students will be able to:

<body>Door middel van het blok Psychologie van de opleiding Criminologie wordt een inleiding op verschillende perspectieven en thema’s binnen de psychologie gegeven. Daarbij ligt de nadruk op die perspectieven en thema’s die bij uitstek relevant zijn voor de criminologie. Bij de behandeling van deze onderwerpen wordt verwezen naar concrete maatschappelijke problemen en toepassingen in onderzoek. Er wordt in het blok bijvoorbeeld aandacht besteed aan de vraag: hoe kan antisociaal of crimineel gedrag worden verklaard aan de hand van psychologische mechanismen? Daarnaast wordt bekeken hoe psychologische mechanismen andere fenomenen uit de criminologie kunnen verklaren.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na succesvolle afronding van het blok kun je:

column2: • Belangrijke begrippen uit de psychologie en haar stromingen en bijbehorende klassieke onderzoeken omschrijven en uitleggen;
• Antisociaal gedrag, inclusief criminaliteit, verklaren met behulp van psychologische theorieën;
• Criminaliteit gerelateerde onderwerpen en reacties duiden en evalueren met behulp van kennis over de psychologie.

column1: In this course, we will explore core psychological principles that affect and shape the behaviour and decisions of actors in organisations. We start with a consideration of what guides independent individual choices and behaviour before gradually exploring how the social context and interdependence with other actors shape these factors. In the final part of the course, we consider settings in which teams work cooperatively to solve problems.

Attending live sessions is mandatory, but more importantly it is in your best interest. We will review, discuss, exercise the key concepts in each module--also practicing exam questions together. If you cannot attend a session, it's okay. You do NOT need to alert instructors. Please make sure you look at the session's slides, and talk to your group mates and colleagues to fill any remaining gap.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Recall, explain, and discuss core psychological principles and their effects on organizationally relevant behaviours and decisions
• Use psychological theories and research findings to critically analyse and design an intervention to affect others’ behaviours within societally relevant domains
• Use psychological theories and research findings to critically analyse and design an intervention to improve their own teamwork

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112600,2023,Psychology & Business PT,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. B Van den Bergh', 'dr. L van Bunderen, PhD']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In dit vak onderzoeken we welke psychologische aspecten gedrag en besluitvorming van individuen en teams in organisaties beïnvloeden. Dit vak bestaat uit twee modules. De ene module gaat over gedrag in teams en wordt gedoceerd door Lisanne van Bunderen; de andere module gaat over individueel gedrag en wordt gedoceerd door Bram Van den Bergh. In de ene module onderzoeken we hoe we ervoor kunnen zorgen dat individuen effectief met elkaar in teams samenwerken. Succesvolle teams zijn essentieel voor het succes van organisaties, maar welke factoren bevorderen of belemmeren nu de prestaties van team? In de andere module onderzoeken we welke factoren invloed kunnen hebben op de keuzes en gedrag van het individu. Hierin spelen zowel bewuste als onbewuste processen een rol, alsook de interactie van het individu met de sociale omgeving.

Dit vak is gebaseerd op een mix van onderwijsvormen, waaronder interactieve plenaire sessies, waarbij er theoretische concepten en modellen worden uitgelegd, maar de nadruk ligt op het toepassen van de theoretische concepten en modellen op de managementpraktijk. Ten slotte leren studenten in dit vak om praktische uitdagingen te identificeren gerelateerd aan de thematiek van beide modules en vervolgens interventies of oplossingen voor deze uitdagingen op basis van de literatuur te ontwerpen.

Deze cursus maakt geen gebruik van een leerboek, maar is gebaseerd op een reeks academische en praktijkgerichte artikelen en hoofdstukken uit handboeken. In het literatuurgedeelte aan het einde van deze cursushandleiding vindt u de volledige referenties van de artikelen die u moet lezen. Vanwege auteursrechtelijke problemen kunnen we deze artikelen niet op Canvas plaatsen. U kunt de artikelen wel zelf downloaden via de EUR-bibliotheekhttp://www.eur.nl/ub/en/. Harvard Business Review papers en cases zijn beschikbaar op de HBR-website. Zorg ervoor dat u zich binnen het netwerk van de universiteit bevindt of via een VPN op het netwerk bent ingelogd als u probeert toegang te krijgen tot de artikelen vanaf een locatie buiten de campus. Anders heeft u mogelijk geen toegang tot alle tijdschriften waarvoor de universiteit een abonnement heeft afgesloten. Instructies voor het instellen van deze VPN vind je hier: https://my.eur.nl/en/eur/ict-1/wifi-and-vpn/vpn-connection
Het wordt aangeraden om de verplichte literatuur van tevoren te bekijken omdat dit het begrip van de in de les behandelde stof, deelname aan de oefeningen en de discussies in de klas ten goede komt.
De sessies starten op het tijdstip vermeld in het cursusrooster. Zorg dat u op het aangegeven tijdstip aanwezig bent en klaar bent om te starten.
Studenten maken een tentamen waarbij ze over beide modules open vragen beantwoorden. Om het vak te halen moeten studenten voor het tentamen minimaal een 5,5 behalen.

Van studenten wordt verwacht dat het tentamen naar beste vermogen wordt gemaakt zonder de hulp van anderen te zoeken of te accepteren of gebruik te maken van bronnen en hulpmiddelen die niet expliciet zijn toegestaan Overtreding van deze regel wordt beschouwd als fraude.
Tentamens worden gecontroleerd op plagiaat. Elk vermoeden van fraude (waaronder plagiaat) wordt gemeld aan de Examencommissie die sancties kan opleggen.

column1: Het centrale doel van deze cursus is om studenten inzicht te geven in hoe psychologische processen de beslissingen, het gedrag en de uitkomsten van teams en van individuen in organisaties beïnvloeden. De cursus omvat de volgende leerdoelen:

column4: Leergebieden
Leerdoelen
Kennisverwerving en -begrip (remembering and understanding):

Na het volgen van deze cursus moeten studenten psychologische concepten en principes en hun effecten op organisatorisch relevant gedrag kennen, kunnen uitleggen en beargumenteren. Deze omvatten begrippen en principes op het gebied van team samenstelling, teamprocessen en team effectiviteit en oordeels- en besluitvorming en overtuigingskracht.
Analyseren en evalueren

Na het volgen van deze cursus moeten studenten in staat zijn om hun eigen gedrag en het gedrag van hun teams te analyseren en evalueren aan de hand van de theoretische concepten en modellen uit de modules.
Kennis toepassen en aanwenden om problemen op te lossen

Na het volgen van deze cursus moeten studenten in staat zijn om de theoretische concepten en modellen uit beide modules toe te passen om een oplossing/interventie te ontwerpen en kritisch te analyseren om hun eigen team(s) en hun eigen beslissingen te optimaliseren.

column1: Het meten van kenmerken en vaardigheden speelt een steeds belangrijkere rol in het dagelijks leven. Dit vak gaat over meten in de sociale wetenschappen. Tijdens deze cursus bespreken studenten de betekenis van meten en hoe de kwaliteit van psychologische metingen geëvalueerd kan worden. We benadrukken dat het in deze cursus niet alleen om psychologische tests gaat, maar om allerlei metingen die worden gebruikt om iets te zeggen over een onderliggend construct.

Tijdens deze cursus zijn betrouwbaarheid en validiteit de belangrijkste psychometrische eigenschappen die aan bod komen. Deze concepten zullen worden uitgelegd volgens de klassieke testtheorie en hun belang zal worden besproken in termen van psychologische praktijk en wetenschappelijk onderzoek.
In deze cursus komen de volgende onderwerpen aan bod:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van deze cursus kunnen studenten:
• De onderliggende principes van de klassieke testtheorie begrijpen.
• Uitleggen wat meetuitdagingen en verschillende vormen van bias zijn, uitleg geven over concepten met betrekking tot classificatie en het belang van betrouwbaarheid.
• Een eenvoudige betrouwbaarheids- en validiteitsanalyse uitvoeren en bepalen wat het effect van betrouwbaarheid op metingen is.
• De kwaliteit van een instrument evalueren op basis van descriptieve analyse, betrouwbaarheidsanalyse en validiteitsanalyse en de resultaten hiervan op een wetenschappelijke manier communiceren.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, some of the most common psychological disorders that can emerge during childhood and adolescence will be discussed. Although the course focusses most strongly on middle childhood and adolescence, we will start with a group of disorders that usually become apparent in early childhood. Every week the normal cognitive development across childhood and into adolescence will be considered, with the assumption that normal and abnormal behaviors are related and are dependent on the child’s level of development. As will become apparent during this course, different disorders emerge at different developmental stages, and are characterized by different abnormalities in cognitive development. During this course, you will study the typical brain and cognitive development, as well as neuropsychological aspects of various disorders.

Each week you will discuss the clinical symptoms, developmental course, classification, aetiology, risk and protective factors of several disorders, as well as treatment and prevention strategies. To get you started we have selected three basic books that provide a good overview of the most important information about normal cognitive development and disorders that are common in childhood and adolescence, namely DeHart, Sroufe, & Cooper (2004), Wicks-Nelson & Israel (2013), and Carr (2015).

Most psychological disorders result from multiple influences, and the disorders that are discussed during this course are no exception. Ongoing research examining the precise developmental factors involved in the onset and maintenance of childhood psychopathology is continually providing new insights. Therefore, every week influential and/or recent innovative articles will be included that focus on the aetiology and treatment of the various disorders.

During this course special attention will be paid to information that is relevant for future clinical child and school psychologists. Therefore, the lectures will be given by scientist-practitioners and a number of research papers is included that focus on evidence-based treatments and on new treatment techniques</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course you will have extended your knowledge of normal cognitive development in childhood and adolescence.

In addition, you will have extended your knowledge of the most common psychological disorders that emerge in early to middle childhood and adolescence. In particular you will have learned about the following aspects of these disorders:
Finally, for each disorder, you will dive more deeply into one of the following themes:
Appreciate the neuropsychological underpinnings of a variety of childhood disorders
Be able to reflect upon important theories of atypical child development
Develop and demonstrate critical thinking skills</body>

column1: <body>International public opinions matter more and more. In order to influence them, nations, but also international organizations such as NGOs or IGOs must develop public relations campaigns in coordination with their policies. Confronted with a growing number of new media that allow anyone to speak their mind globally, the United States is perfecting the concept of Public Diplomacy, in order to ""Tell America's story"". The U.S. is not alone to practice Public Diplomacy; a number of countries are also developing strategic communication campaigns in order to win the global battle of public opinion. In this course, students will explore the importance of public opinions in international relations. Techniques of strategic communication will be discussed and analyzed along with case studies on today's Public Diplomacy. Students will regularly meet practitioners in Public diplomacy. For that reason, a reasonable level of professionalism and flexibility will be required.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Major perspectives on Public Diplomacy and its affiliates like Cultural Diplomacy, Nation Branding and Soft Power;
• Role and importance of public opinions and strategic communication campaigns in international relations.
• Critically review current research on Public Diplomacy;
• Apply theoretical concepts to real-life cases in Public Diplomacy;
• Analyze and reflect on the use and impact of strategic communication campaigns in international relations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides a thorough understanding of a number of key topics of public finance. The course consists of a mix of positive (i.e., descriptive) and normative (i.e., prescriptive) analyses. It deals with the following topics and more:
1. The equity and efficiency properties of a laissez-faire market equilibrium
2. Tax incidence: the distributional effects of taxation
3. Deadweight loss: the distortionary effects of taxation
4. The implications of bounded rationality for tax policy
8. Tax competition, tax havens, OR public good provision

The goal is to understand both the traditional theory on each topic, as well as the state-of-the-art insights generated by current academic research. As such, the required literature for many of the topics consists of recent scholarly papers as well as textbook chapters.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To gain knowledge on the principles of public finance.
• To understand how changes in taxes affect decisions to work, consume, and engage in tax evasion.
• To understand how taxes affect market outcomes, efficiency, and the distribution of resources.
• To understand which policies are best suited to tackle problems generated by income inequality, externalities, internalities, and tax evasion.
• To understand optimal policy rules for the provision of public goods.
• To understand how relaxing rationality assumptions affect conventional public finance wisdom.
• To link insights from public finance to actual policy debates.
• To critically read and understand academic journal articles at the scientific frontier of public finance.
• To apply basic concepts from microeconomics and mathematics to the study of public economics.
