column1: This course gives an in depth introduction into the theory of optimal taxation. It discusses the welfare economic foundations of public finance, the Ramsey (1927) principles for optimal commodity taxation and Mirrlees' (1971) non-linear income tax. In addition, the main theorems in public finance will be covered: the Atkinson-Stiglitz (1976) theorem on the desirability of commodity/capital taxation and the Diamond-Mirrlees (1971) production effciency theorem. We will also discuss the Samuelson (1954) rule for the optimal provision of public goods in second-best settings with distortionary taxes. The main principles will then be applied to various topics such as optimal income redistribution, capital income taxation, human capital taxation, corrective taxation of externalities, optimal public goods provision in second best and the marginal cost of public funds. Finally, theory will be confronted with actual policy discussions, such as the flat-tax debate, the basic income, proposals for participation subsidies and in-work tax credits, consumption tax proposals, and carbon taxes.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course students should be able to understand

column2: • the welfare economic foundations of public finance
• the aim of (non-linear) income taxation and the role of tax distortions
• the optimal commodity tax and the debate on direct vs. indirect taxation
• the effects of the tax system on human capital investments
• the optimal provision of public goods and the marginal cost of public funds
• the optimal corrective tax on externality-generating goods in second-best settings
• various policy debates regarding the desirability of tax progression, the flat tax debate, the basic income, the consumption tax debate, the desirability of in-work tax credits, carbon taxes.

column1: Public Health is een multidisciplinair vakgebied dat zich richt op het behouden en verbeteren van de gezondheid van (brede groepen binnen) de bevolking door middel van collectieve maatregelen, zoals vaccinatieprogramma’s, sanitaire maatregelen en voorlichting. In de minor komen vooral Public Health thema’s die spelen in grote steden, zoals Rotterdam aan bod.

De minor Public Health is ontwikkeld binnen de Faculteit Geneeskunde & Gezondheidswetenschappen en een gemeenschappelijk product van de Erasmus School of Health Policy en Management en de Afdeling Maatschappelijke Gezondheidszorg van Erasmus MC. Bij de ontwikkeling van de minor is nauw samengewerkt met organisaties in de publieke gezondheid, met name met de GGD Rotterdam Rijnmond.
Bekijk de video en leer meer over deze minor.

Public Health is een multidisciplinair vakgebied dat zich richt op het behouden en verbeteren van de gezondheid van een bevolking(sgroep) door middel van collectieve maatregelen. Denk bijvoorbeeld aan preventieve gezondheidszorg (zoals vaccinaties), sanitaire maatregelen, gezondheidsvoorlichting en sociale voorzieningen, maar ook aan beleidsmaatregelen en de organisatie van zorg. Omdat zowel de oorzaken als oplossingen meestal buiten de klassieke geneeskunde en gezondheidszorg gezocht moeten worden, vraagt dit om een gecombineerde inbreng vanuit diverse wetenschapsgebieden en actoren.

De minor richt zich met name op de grootstedelijke context. Overal ter wereld neemt het aantal mensen dat in grote steden woont toe. Deze concentratie van mensen op een relatief kleine oppervlakte brengt veel risico’s met zich mee en zorgt voor een uitvergroting van gezondheidsproblemen in grote steden. In de minor Public Health ontrafel je de oorzaken van deze problemen en leer je over de oplossingen ervan.</body>

• De bijdrage van de publieke gezondheidszorg aan de stijging van de levensverwachting in geïndustrialiseerde landen uitleggen
• Basale prevalentie-, incidentie- en associatiematen berekenen en interpreteren
• Uitdagingen om publieke gezondheidszorgmaatregelen op de beleidsagenda te krijgen herkennen
• Sociale determinanten van gezondheid op verschillende niveaus herkennen
• Voor- en nadelen van specifieke publieke gezondheidszorgprogramma's beoordelen
• Bevindingen uit literatuur en eigen onderzoek vertalen naar advies voor beleid en praktijk

column1: This course is about the interaction between public health, economics, and public health policy. Good health policies are impossible to formulate without some understanding of the relation between public health policies, individual behaviour and population health. In this course students will be taught how to apply statistical methods and economic theory to questions such as: “How should we measure and summarize population health?”, “How do increases in (healthy) life expectancy influence health care spending and pension entitlements?”, “What is the impact of medical care on population health and what is the relevance thereof for cost effectiveness?”, and “What are economic arguments for and against public health policies?”.

The first 3 meetings will be spent on the measurement of population health. The lifetable approach developed in these first meetings is crucial for the rest of the course. In the meetings thereafter, these measures of population health will be linked to redistributions of wealth within populations, determinants and cost effectiveness analysis. Three meetings deal with a specific case study on public health policy: obesity, infectious diseases and cancer screening.

This course consists of lecture and interactive workgroups. The lectures are a combination of online material (papers, videos and homework) and live Q&A sessions in which students can discuss the material and homework. During the work groups students work together in small groups on an in-depth case related to the course material.
The course build on the knowledge from the following courses from the HEPL/HE:

column2: • Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics (previously known as Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics)
• Economics and Financing of Health Care Systems
• Economics of Health and Health Care
• Stata/SPSS or other similar statistical software
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, students will be able to:

column2: • calculate various summary measures of population health, explain the differences between these methods, and interpret variation (across group or over time) in these measures;
• construct simple models based on the life table to answer questions relevant for public health policy;
• interpret empirical research within the domain of public health economics;
• apply a welfare economic framework to policy interventions in the field of public health and use this framework to make policy recommendations

The purpose of this course will be on the one hand to introduce students to main concepts of contemporary international law, such as sources and subjects of international law, sovereignty and international responsibility; and on the other hand to explore how we are governed globally by looking at ideas, legal doctrines, institutional and administrative structures developed over the last century to organize and legalize international economic and political life. The readings will focus on various ways to think about the legal organization of global order, and on the history of legal efforts to organize and institutionalize international affairs.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The course will contribute to the student attaining the following critical outcomes:

column2: • Collecting, analysing, organizing and critically evaluating information conveyed during lectures and further analyzed in the Tutorials;
• Demonstrating an understanding of the world as a set of related systems;

column1: Students successfully completing this course should be able to:

column2: • Understand and appreciate the nature of the international system, how it is organized and how it works
• Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the key legal regimes operating in the international realm
• Demonstrate the ability to identify various factors and forces that shape the contemporary international community and how problem-solving contexts are interrelated
• Apply the knowledge gained from this cause to solve contemporary international problems

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114247,2023,Public International Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. F Violi', 'mr. L Said', 'R de Geus, LL.M']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The Bachelor 3 course in Public International Law builds on the Bachelor 1 mandatory introductory course, Introduction to International and European Law. The focus of the Public International Law course, which is instructed in English, falls on the structure of international law, how that structure manifests itself in particular core regimes of international law such as the law of treaties, the law of state responsibility, the law on the use of force, human rights law, law of immunities, international criminal law, international economic law and dispute settlement – and also, briefly, how the structure of the international legal order is changing, and why.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Draw connections between the different fields of public international law and explain how the subjects are related to each other and how they fit in the (fragmented) system of international law (problem 8);
• Explain the terms ‘primary’ and ‘secondary’ rules of international law and distinguish between them in order to obtain a better grasp on the structure of international law;
• Examine and apply the secondary rules of state responsibility in order to solve case-studies in which primary rules of public international law have been violated (problem 1);
• Examine and apply the secondary rules of the law of treaties and their bearing on the application and interpretation of primary rules of public international law (problems 2 and 3);

• Describe how international dispute settlement works in the international legal order, and explain the different methods of dispute settlement in public international law (judicial means, diplomatic means and UN collective security). Students will be able to connect the phenomenon of proliferation of courts and tribunals to the myriad of dispute settlement mechanisms available under international law (lecture 2);

• Analyze the law of the use of force (and the threat of the use of force), including recent developments (especially since the 2000s) and explain how it relates to dispute settlement methods within the framework of the United Nations (lecture 2  and 3 and problem 4);
• Analyze the regime of international human rights law and contrast the different human rights instruments and enforcement mechanisms (problem 5);
• Analyze the law of immunity in terms of the differences and linkages between two types of immunity, namely: state immunity and immunity of high-ranking state officials (problem 6);
• Describe the role of international organisations (IOs) as actors at the international level and the impact of their activities on individuals and groups in society (lecture 4);
• Solve case-studies using the rules of international criminal law (problem 7);
• Analyze the existing institutional framework of international economic law and some of its problematic dimensions
• Analyze international case law and, on this basis, form and give an independent opinion regarding the legal merits of individual cases;
• Examine opinions and comments of commentators concerning various topics of the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Public issues are issues of public contestation whose formation often coincides with the formation of previously non-existent publics. This introductory core course studies the historical, geographical, socio-political and socio-technical aspects of such issues. We ask how issues are publicly imagined, and by which technological mediations and infrastructure this occurs. We also focus on the ways issues are intertwined with (potential) publics. This requires also that we investigate contemporary conceptions of the public sphere in an interdisciplinary way. In order to do so, you are made familiar with a number of key contemporary public issues, such as: climate change, racism, smart urban technologies, global drone warfare, sexism and contemporary neoliberal capitalism and the precarization of life.

These issues are analyzed by means of a conceptual vocabulary that centers on the social and material infrastructures (policy and politics, media, the internet, energy supply lines etc.) that underlie many public issues; the social imaginaries through which public issues come into being; the identities at stake in public issues; the interfaces that allow people to engage with such issues; and the investments and interests that are entangled with them. By means of this conceptual vocabulary, the course seeks to highlight the importance of composition in making things public, and to move from ‘the public’ and ‘the public sphere’ to the ongoing and uncertain constitution of a plurality of publics (policy makers are one particular public, or they can be part of publics). Publics, in other words, are composed out of a variety of people and things.

The course provides room for the development of your own engagement with public life and allows you to experiment with ways of unpacking the complexities of a public issue of your choosing in a paper.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will:
1. have insight into the main sociological theories and analyses of the contemporary public sphere
2. be familiar with cutting edge sociological approaches to the ways publics and issues emerge
3. be able to apply these approaches to a variety of current public issues
4. be able to write an academic paper on a current public issue and analyze it in sociological terms

column1: This course brings together state-of-the-art theories on public knowledge, in-depth analyses of knowledge circulation in public issues, and exciting field experiments with inventive methods. The aim of this course is to develop your critical understanding of what knowledge can do in public issues. By studying exemplary cases and experimenting with methods, you will learn how research can itself be an intervention in and engagement with public issues.

As a start, you will become more familiar with a set of concepts and approaches that will allow you to analyze what knowledge can do. You will learn how methods, research and knowledge are performative: they do not disinterestedly describe but actively compose our common worlds and the issues through which we engage with it.

On this basis, you will be performing your own attempts at (re-)composing a public issue through social scientific research methods. Throughout the course you will be testing materials and methods as ways to intervene in public issues.

This course is expressly aimed at preparing you for your thesis trajectory. You’ll deepen your understanding of research methods, while also developing an initial mapping of the topic and field that you have chosen for your thesis. The final assignment of the course consists of a field exploration report that will become your launching pad into your master’s thesis research.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will:
1. be familiar with the main cutting edge sociological theories and analyses of knowledge and expertise
2. be familiar with the different modalities of public intervention
3. be able to make a sociological analysis of the ways knowledge figures in the staging of public interventions
4. be able to judge the performative role of knowledge claims in the public sphere
5. be able to set up and conduct a study of a public knowledge controversy</body>

• the general management of organizations that operate in an environment in which public values play an important role; and/or

column1: In the Public Management course, it is discussed how public management theories and practices have developed over time (think of the emerging popularity of New Public Management in the 1990s.and its subsequent demise since the 2000s) and how public management as theory, practice and ‘fad’ has been taking different shapes in various national and sectoral settings. In this course you will become acquainted with the core elements of public management theories and practices (from a functional and sector-specific perspective), and of how public management theories and practices have developed over time and space.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After following this course students will be able to

column2: • Define nature, causes and consequences of public management as a theoretical concept (both as management activities applied in a public sector context, as well as a series of functional/operational activities), and as a national and international practice
• Explain how public management theories and practices are rooted in [have emerged from] scientific fields such as political science, law, sociology and economics
• Explain how public management theories and practices are related to social and governance issues;
• Describe how public management as theory and practice has evolved in time (history) and place (across national contexts)
• Analyze, evaluate and explain whether and why, in specific policy fields and/or national contexts, public management practices have been able to address social and governance issues

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111776,2023,Public Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. AM Kanas', 'prof.dr. HJM Fenger', 'prof.dr. PWA Scholten', 'S van Weeghel']",,"Inhoud

The course is directed to the explanation of nature (form) and effectiveness of public policies: to what degree are public policies effective remedies to social and governance issues, and how can we explain how and why public policies change over time, or are remarkably resistant to change? The course introduces how public policies are shaped by democratic decision-making procedures, and rule of law, and that in many cases this means that policies are remarkably stable over time, with policy change only occurring during critical junctures.

Throughout the course, special attention is given to comparative analysis of public policies, or, in other words to the question of whether, and if so to what degree and why public policies differ in various national contexts.</body>

• Explain how public policy theories and practices are rooted in [have emerged from] scientific fields such as political science, law, sociology and economics;
• Explain how public policy theories and practices are related to social and governance issues;
• Describe the conditions under which public policies change (e.g., institutional learning occurs) and inversely, why in many cases public policies display remarkable stability over time;
• Name and explain  mechanisms through which public policies may converge or diverge across national or sectoral contexts;
• Identify conditions and mechanisms of policy change (or lack thereof) in specific, national or sectoral public policies.

column1: Hoe en waarom wordt een probleem een ‘beleidsprobleem’? Wat is beleid, en hoe wordt het ontwikkeld? Wie neemt er besluiten over beleid? Hoe kun je zorgen dat beleid ook echt wordt uitgevoerd? En op welke wijze kun je bepalen of beleid succesvol is geweest, of niet?

Deze vragen staan centraal in de cursus ‘Beleid’. De cursus laat studenten kennismaken met de ‘beleidscyclus’ en leert de student vanuit meerdere perspectieven (rationeel, politiek, cultureel en institutioneel perspectief) een analyse te maken van beleidsprocessen. Op deze wijze krijgt de student inzicht in de meervoudigheid van beleidsprocessen waarin kennis, macht, beeldvorming en instituties een rol spelen.

Ideaaltypisch worden maatschappelijke problemen geagendeerd (agendavorming), waarna politici doelen stellen en beleidsambtenaren bij deze doelen instrumenten selecteren (beleidsvorming en -besluitvorming), en uitvoerders deze instrumenten toepassen (beleidsimplementatie). Vervolgens wordt in de fasen toezicht, handhaving en evaluatie gecontroleerd of het beleid conform de intentie van beleidsmakers is uitgevoerd, respectievelijk of met het beleid het achterliggende maatschappelijke vraagstuk is opgelost. Tevens wordt aandacht besteed aan de factoren die ten grondslag liggen aan beleidsverandering.

Gedurende de cursus zullen de perspectieven op de beleidscyclus worden toegepast op diverse maatschappelijke problemen. Dit zal bijdragen aan een beter begrip van de weerbarstigheid en complexiteit van hoe beleidsprocessen in de realiteit plaatsvinden</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Na afloop van het vak kan de student:

column5: de assumpties en kernelementen van het rationele, politieke, culturele en institutionele perspectief op beleidsprocessen benoemen;
een analyse maken van de rol van kennis, macht, beeldvorming en instituties in beleidsprocessen
de verschillende fasen van de beleidscyclus herkennen en toepassen op concrete maatschappelijke problemen;
een analyse maken van hoe en waarom beleidsproblemen op de maatschappelijke, politieke en beleidsagenda komen, of waarom agendavorming juist wordt voorkomen

column1: It is often (if not always) not what we communicate but how we communicate. Getting our message across (especially verbally, when having merely a limited amount of time), within the context of a highly internationalized (business) world, can be a cumbersome task from a personal or organizational perspective. Humans make a business run. Personal development (in this case learning ‘to speak out loud’), theoretical knowledge and practical skills as such, are essential aspects nowadays. Having an interview for a new job, speaking ‘out loud’, presenting or pitching in front of the class or in a future work-setting, and even ‘worse’, speaking in front of a group of people on a set ’stage’ or even in the board room during company meetings, can be very challenging. Not possessing public speaking skills (theory, strategy and practice) can nowadays truly make or break someone’s career (prospects) and can cause serious, unnecessary anxiety issues, not to mention hinder the ‘sales of knowledge, service or product’ with (personal, social, economic, stakeholder relation etc.) consequences to follow....

Public Speaking essentials, involve verbal and written storytelling and communication theories and practices; pitching/presentation training; all in all, based on the understanding and practice of effective verbal, written and body language strategies within a 21st century international business context. Several scientific fields / studies and work field practices are relevant in this case. To name a few: Leadership-, Management-, Organizational-, Entrepreneurial studies, Sociology, (Positive) Psychology and of course Communication sciences. This seminar is a strategy and implementation oriented ‘training’ with relevant and specifically selected theory as an additional solid backbone to accommodate university students in their next step towards ‘real life scenarios’.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Why public speaking is essential in a globalized 21st century (individual and business) context
• What characteristics of verbal (and written) communication we can consider important when willing to be effective communicators
• The difference between public speaking and storytelling
• The importance of storytelling and other verbal, written and body language methods in public speaking
• Why cultural differences matter in public speaking

• How to communicate a properly structured text in public speaking (writing and by heart)
• To evaluate the (inter-cultural) context within which public speaking takes place
• To evaluate and learn from other public speakers

column1: Publiek management is het managen van publieke organisaties. Het gaat dan om twee soorten management. Ten eerste, het interne management ofwel de bedrijfsvoering van publieke organisaties. Dat betreft zaken zoals organisatiestructuren en -typen, personeel, financiën, communicatie, ICT, strategie en bedrijfsvoeringtechnieken. Ten tweede, het externe management ofwel het aangaan en onderhouden van contacten met tal van stakeholders, burgers en de politiek.

In dit vak gaan we in op beide soorten management in een serie colleges, kennisclips en praktische voorbeelden. De opgedane kennis wordt getoetst in een schriftelijk tentamen en toegepast in een groepsopdracht over een echte publieke organisatie. Daarbij kijken we niet alleen naar de overheid in enge zin, maar naar de publieke sector in de volle breedte.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Aan het eind van deze cursus is de student in staat om:

column2: • Verschillende onderdelen en vormen van publiek management te benoemen en in eigen woorden uit te leggen;
• Organisatiestructuren en -typen te herkennen en de voor- en nadelen ervan te benoemen
• Verschillende stadia van strategievorming te herkennen en adviezen te formuleren over de toepassing ervan door publieke organisaties;
• Meerdere bedrijfsvoeringtechnieken te benoemen en de toepassing ervan te beoordelen of daarover te adviseren aan publieke organisaties;
• Meerdere methoden voor extern management te benoemen, te herkennen in de praktijk en de voor- en nadelen ervan te benoemen;
• Te adviseren aan publieke organisaties over het aangaan en onderhouden van contacten met stakeholders, burgers en de politiek; en
• Kritisch te reflecteren op het managen van publieke organisaties en theorieën of modellen daarover.

column1: Leiderschap is een ‘hot’ onderwerp, waarover tal van wetenschappelijke en niet-wetenschappelijke publicaties verschijnen. Ook binnen de bestuurskunde is veel aandacht voor het thema waarbij wordt beargumenteerd dat de positie en rol van (publieke) managers door allerlei (externe) ontwikkelingen is veranderd.

De module begint met een inleiding over leiderschapstheorie waarna vervolgens een verdieping volgt op basis van het boek Van Wart. Daarnaast kijken we ook specifiek naar enkele actuele ontwikkelingen in leiderschap aan de hand van enkele wetenschappelijke artikelen. Daarbij staan we ook nadrukkelijk stil bij de invloed van de publieke context op leiderschap.

column1: Macro principles of good writing and publishing (Day 1)
1.    What makes a paper a good paper; why do some paper get published and others not
3.    Writing as a contribution to scholarly discourse: Finding your conversation, finding a story to tell
4.    Structuring a paper: Different options and when they are appropriate.
6.    Knowing the key ingredients for each section of a paper: what has go into an introduction, a literature review, etc., and where exactly should it be located.
7.    Good sections, good paragraphing (pyramid principle, topic sentences etc.)
8.    Rules for building strong sentences, cohesion among sentences (e.g., relating to action characters, strong verbs, 2-3-1, paragraphing, creating overlap, from known to unknown, concision)
9.    Choice of tense and mode to fit section of the paper and the content, choice of words that send the right “signals”, etc.
10.    Conducting your writing project: Strategies for productive writing and editing
11.    Writing to get published in leading academic journals
14.    Measuring and managing your impact as a scholar
Prerequisites: Please note that attendance is expected on all three days. Participants will be admitted on a first come, first served basis. The maximum number of participants is 20.

column1: This course aims at improving participants’ academic writing skills, and help them to publish papers at leading journals. The course is an intensive one-week course, where participants are expected to focus exclusively on this course. Participants are expected to submit a piece of writing before the start of the seminar. This can be a draft of a conference paper or a draft of a regular paper. During the course, you will be invited to revise the written piece after each day. At the end of the course, the initially submitted piece of writing should be revised substantially and should be re-submitted to the professor. Participants should also actively take part in the discussions

column2: • At the end of this course, participants know how to craft high quality papers.
• Participants know the principles of good academic writing, and recognize these principles.
• Participants improve their own writing and editing.
• Participants understand the publishing process, including research ethics issues that can arise in its course.
• Participants understand how scholarly impact is created and measured, and can apply this knowledge to increase their own impact.
• Participants get an understanding why many papers get rejected.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In essence, purchasing involves everything one receives an invoice for. But what is the more substantive definition of this business process, particularly from a management point of view? Over the years, numerous definitions have been provided for Purchasing and Supply Management (PSM). In broad strokes, one could depict the development of definitions over time as moving from more operational, to tactical, to more strategic. Central in any definition of purchasing and supply management is the process (at least as final objective) of acquiring inputs. As such, the economic transactions between actors are at the heart of purchasing and supply management. This is also the core difference with logistics or supply chain management, which focus on planning and controlling the amounts, routes, and timing of flows of goods and services and associated information.

As a management activity, purchasing and supply has a quite rich history. In the 18th century, the United East India Company (in Dutch: Vereenigde Oost-Indische Compagnie) already conducted sophisticated make-or-buy analyses. While at a general level, the principles of purchasing and supply management may thus have remained largely the same, there are some particular areas of development in the last decade or so.

Perhaps the most fundamental development is that the realization is growing that purchasing and supply management can not only contribute to the ‘bottom-line’ of organizations, but also to the ‘top-line’. In other words, the buying organization does not only seek to reduce costs but also to increase the revenue-generating potential of the acquired inputs. Another development is that organisations place growing emphasis on strategy development at the level of so-called purchasing ‘categories’. More and more organisations apply an explicit approach to segmenting their spend in terms of characteristics such as financial importance and supply or technological risks, and apply explicitly differentiated strategies for the different segments.

The objective of this core course is to provide students with the key concepts regarding purchasing and supply management. This course will cover the whole purchasing cycle, including strategic, tactical, and operational purchasing activities.

Attendance of the lectures is strongly recommended, but not mandatory - see the final syllabus for further details. Please note, however, that the quizzes will be held during the lectures, at the beginning. Attendance and active participation will not only improve the learning experience for yourself, but also for the entire class. Moreover, attendance and active participation will earn you bonus points. Please see the final syllabus for further details on participation grading.

Attendance of the workshops is mandatory. For the workshops, we will split the two sections into two subsections each (1A, 1B, 2A, 2B). Program management has put you into a student team (typically of four members), and the team ID will identify your workshop group. Team-members who are allowed by Program Management to attend online are obliged to attend the workshop on-line of their specific workshop group.

column1: The following topics are covered in this course in 4 consecutive weeks: (1a) qualitative “versus” quantitative research; (1b) measurement and operationalization in qualitative research settings; (2a) data collection: interviews, participant observation, textual documents, unobtrusive data, and visual materials; (2b) data analysis: data reduction, causal inference, and qualitative data analysis software (NVivo, Atlas.ti, fs/QCA, et cetera); (3a) ethnography; (3b) grounded theory methods; (4a) case study methods; and (4b) content analytical methods and discourse analysis.

column1: The goal of this course is to equip students with the intellectual baggage necessary for the design, execution, and publication of truly excellent qualitative research studies. The emphasis in this course will be on getting acquainted with: (a) the canonical steps of the qualitative research process in general, and (b) four exemplary qualitative research designs in particular.

Central to this course is that students acquire an advanced understanding of the qualitative research process in general, and of several commonly used qualitative research designs in particular. Students are also expected to get acquainted with and learn how to use qualitative data analysis programs, such as NVivo, Atlas.ti, DICTION, fs/QCA, or MAXQDA.

column1: In order to understand, analyze and make sense of diverse changes in the social world, research is paramount. This course aims to provide theoretical and applied knowledge in the different methods of qualitative social scientific research and an understanding of how to analyse and interpret the data gathered through these methods. This course first focuses on methods of qualitative data collection (e.g., focus groups, interviews, observation) and then on different forms of qualitative data analysis and interpretation. Within a qualitative tradition students will increase their skills in developing a comprehensive qualitative research plan and should be able to critically assess the methodological approaches of published qualitative research. The focus within this course is on developing students’ abilities to design their own research using qualitative methods for use in their future research courses and thesis development.
Note: Students should have completed the course Introduction to Social Science Research (CM1002) before they may enter the courses Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The benefits and challenges of these methods;
• How to develop a research design and how to collect and analyze qualitative data.
• An understanding of the relationship between theory, methodology and methods in qualitative research.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity  to:

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course aims to acquaint students with key qualitative research methods, their application as well as conceptual underpinnings. Students learn what kind of research questions can be effectively addressed by qualitative methods. Participants of the course learn how the application of qualitative methods allows one to move from collecting information to its analysis. Course materials highlight that the application that qualitative methods spans not only across disciplinary boundaries but also across both empirical and interpretivist traditions in social and behavioural sciences. The course shows that qualitative methods adhere to the same ‘excellence criteria’ as quantitative approaches do, namely validity and reliability, as well as being able to provide a poignant critique of existing social order and practices. By focusing on contemporary societal and environmental challenges, students will learn how qualitative methods can be of help not only in identifying causes of these problems but also contribute to the development of their solutions. Throughout 7 lectures and 7 seminar sessions students will get acquainted with various forms of qualitative data collection, sampling and analysis, namely various forms of cases studies and process-tracing, interviews and focus groups, ethnography, discourse and qualitative content analysis, visual methods, fieldwork as well as the potential ethical challenges that the application  of these instruments entails. The lectures embed qualitative methods in various research traditions as well as highlight strengths and weaknesses of particular approaches. The seminars will introduce students to the application of qualitative methods as well as acquaint them with examples of best practice in using distinct qualitative approaches.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The goal of this course is to equip you with basic knowledge of the principles of the scientific method and the most important methodological concepts in the social and behavioral sciences. With this knowledge and hands-on practice, you will be able to evaluate research articles in terms of their methodological quality and design your own research. The course will give you insight into the current controversies surrounding the integrity of research in the social and behavioral sciences. It will also prepare you for subsequent courses on statistics and a capstone project where you will apply all this methodological and statistical knowledge and skills in performing your own research project.

column2: • the scientific method, its principles, and criteria for evaluation
• the most important types of research and research designs
• measurement, measurement methods, and criteria for evaluation of measurement instruments
• evaluating research articles in terms of their methodological quality
• identifying solutions for methodological weaknesses found within (published) academic articles
• proposing a research design for a given research question

column1: Why do people do what they do? People can have many different motives for doing things and
often construct their life worlds with others. Qualitative research is specifically suited to study the
meaning systems of the participants in social life. In this course you will take the approach of the
qualitative researcher. We will introduce you to the fundamentals of qualitative research and
different qualitative research methods. Like all skills courses, we use a hands-on approach: in teams
of 3-4 students you will think of a theoretically relevant research problem, write an interview
protocol and then go out to conduct interviews. For data analysis, you will learn about analytical
methods based on the Grounded Theory approach, start to code your own data using the software
program Atlas.ti, and identify and analyse patterns across the data. At the end of the course you
will outline your findings (your theory) in a research report and also present them to your fellow

column1: <body>The course Qualitative Methods is about the way social scientists answer research questions and design research proposals within the qualitative paradigm in social sciences. The main focus will be on the design of a research proposal, choosing from several approaches like ethnography, grounded theory, phenomenology, narrative research, and case studies. Attention is also paid to qualitative research procedures like doing observations, conducting interviews, and analysing documents and other (visual) data sources.   </body>

column1: The challenges of qualitative research such as case studies are widely underestimated. While it is obvious that quantitative research cannot be conducted without mastering relevant statistical or mathematical techniques, many researchers engage in qualitative research without having the requisite knowledge and skills. This course seeks to endow prospective researchers with the insights needed to adequately perform one type of qualitative research: case studies.

It seems easy to collect and analyse cases, because information about business organisations is abundantly available and all students have a certain experience in interpreting and writing texts. However, a number of thorny issues render qualitative research a challenging task. First, how to know whether the focal research topic lends itself to the use of this type of research? Second, if qualitative research is indeed a suitable method, how to determine what data are most relevant and how to access those data? Third, once all data has been gathered, how to reduce the vast amount of data to manageable proportions and how to make sense of the data? Fourth, after the data analysis, how to report relevant findings in an insightful way? This course offers answers to these questions, which are of critical importance to anyone conducting qualitative research (such as case studies).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To create understanding when qualitative (especially case study) research methods are appropriate
• To develop the ability to select and tap into different qualitative data sources
• To develop the skills to systematically analyse qualitative data
• To develop the skills to report findings from qualitative (especially case study) research in a structured and concise yet complete way

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Quality and safety are very much on the agenda of health care governance throughout the world. In this course we engage students to actively explore theoretical backgrounds to, as well as the major themes of, quality and safety governance. In general, the course takes the position that quality and safety in health care are emergent properties that need continuous work. Consequences of specific interventions to improve quality and safety are often unpredictable, hence we take the position that a straightforward ‘how to’ improve quality and safety is, at best, not very productive. Instead, we emphasize in this course the need for both ‘top-down’ and ‘bottom-up’ approaches to quality and safety, and place particular stress on theories of the 'middle' - the level where the work of management and leadership usually resides. The course explores six challenges that come from this 'mangle of the middle'. These challenges are said to face each quality and safety improvement effort, and can be structural, political, cultural, technological, emotional and educational.

Taking these challenges and their relations as a core theme, the course invites students to explore amongst themselves, and with their tutors, several recent cases of quality and safety improvement efforts. Guided by given concepts and theories, students formulate their own questions about and answers to these cases, and while doing so they can explore strategies and instruments that can be taken in dealing with each challenge.
Language: Obligatory literature and lectures are in English. Workgroups are in Dutch, assignments and the exam can also be written in Dutch.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The goals of the course are to give students an understanding of the theoretical backgrounds to and challenges of quality and safety in healthcare settings, to train students in reflexively working with these theories and in exploring specific quality and safety issues from a multi-dimensional perspective. Using active participation in class focused on professional behavior, peer review and a written take home examination, we aim for this course to help students in developing a self-reflexive and concrete academic mode of argumentation.
After this course you will be able to:

column2: • Critically appraise quality and safety issues in healthcare organizations based on critical organizational theory
• Critically reflect on methods for quality and safety work in healthcare organizations
• Develop a logically coherent argumentation based on scientific literature

column1: Professionally lead and participate in meetings, using theoretical perspectives to substantiate your arguments

column1: In many situations, making decisions solely based on intuition does not suffice. Especially in situations with uncertainty, following your intuition might lead to suboptimal decision making. A structured and systematic approach based on sound analysis of the relevant data can improve the quality of the decision making process. In addition, making decisions based on intuition makes it hard for managers to justify decisions in the future, especially when decisions turn out to have negative consequences. This course provides students with the methods and tools to make better, more responsible, decisions. The methods and tools are not only discussed conceptually during lectures and exercise sessions, but are also implemented using spreadsheet modelling software.

• Explain the most important concepts related to Monte Carlo simulation to analyze complex business systems with uncertainty
• Explain the most important concepts related to modelling basic business decision problems as (integer) linear programming problems

column1: After successful completion of this course, students are able to:

column2: • Implement and analyze decision models using payoff tables and decision trees conceptually and using spreadsheet tools
• Implement and analyze a Monte Carlo simulation conceptually and using spreadsheet tools
• Implement, solve and analyze (integer) linear programming problems conceptually and using spreadsheet tools

column1: This course consists of three modules. Each module consists of 1 or more lectures and associated exercises. Each lecture covers the material for 1 week and is divided into 4 or 5 recorded videos. In total, each lecture contains approximately 1 hour of video material. For each lecture, a set of exercises is available which can be divided into two categories: written exercises and computer exercises. In the written exercises you are asked to apply the material to small problems that can be solved on paper. In the computer exercises you are asked to implement the material in Excel so that larger problems can be solved.

Each module is concluded with an online workshop in which the material is briefly repeated and part of the practice exercises will be discussed. These sessions take place on the Friday of the week in which the module ends (weeks 2, 3 and 6). On the other Fridays (week 1, 4 and 5) there is an online Q&A session in which students can ask questions to the teacher. In the week before the examination, a final Q&A session will be organized.
The course will be concluded with two exams: a computer exam and a written exam. Both exams will take place on the same day.

column1: The course Quantitative Empirical Legal Studies aims to introduce students to the design and analysis of quantitative empirical legal studies.  The students will learn different quantitative empirical designs and their relevance in gaining insights for the law. They will be challenged to think creatively about causality and research design and will learn the basics of descriptive and inferential statistics used to analyze quantitative data. Through examples of experimental and observational methods students are familiarized with the strengths and weaknesses of different approaches (from the advantages of running an experiment to using observational data and exploiting natural shocks in the law).

The students will not just acquire knowledge on different methods and the insights they have generated. The course also contains tutorials where students will learn how to use the statistical software STATA to conduct quantitative analyses themselves. At the end of the course, they will be able to identify correlations and run different types of regressions, instruments that are essential to identify causal relationships between variables characteristic of legal problems.
The course is a hands-on course. Students will have both lectures and tutorials.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To introduce students to quantitative empirical legal studies and their analysis. Students will be able to think critically and creatively about empirical research as well as learn the basics of analyzing quantitative data themselves.

column1: Quantitative skills are an important asset for historians. Data can be summarised in a clear manner using statistical techniques, empirical data can be accurately analysed using statistical programs and quantitative models can form the basis for testing theories. This course will deal with the collection, description and analysis of quantitative data. Many scientific articles are incomprehensible to researchers without a thorough knowledge of some basic statistical techniques. Moreover, the popular media also refer to quantitative data to provide insight into societal phenomena. Data and numbers are so important in contemporary society that academics should be able to cope critically with this kind of material.

Students will learn to interpret and perform statistical research in this course. This course mainly deals with descriptive statistics but some basic principles of interferential statistics will also be introduced. After a brief introduction about the collection and processing of quantitative data, different methods for summarising the data will be reviewed and practiced. Students will learn to create tables, draw graphs and calculate central tendencies and measures of dispersion. Index numbers, moving averages and trend lines are also covered in this course, as these are essential tools for understanding historical evolutions. During the second part of the course, students will discover how they can determine the relationship between two variables. Finally, they are also introduced to multiple regression analysis. The assessment consists of weekly multiple-choice questions about theory and concepts during the term, a paper, and a final written examination in the PC labs.
Quantitative Historical methods is a mandatory course in the bachelor history at Erasmus University.

This course is in line with the specific profile of the history programme in Rotterdam with a strong emphasis on the connection with the social sciences. Most historians rely on qualitative methods, which are dominant in the humanities, but a social science approach urges historians to use quantitative methods. This course is programmed in the first term of the second year, because this enables students to make use of quantitative methods in their papers during the second and third year. Quantitative methods are for instance essential to understand historical analyses of economic developments, social inequality and international relations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

• Students can critically evaluate the use of statistical analyses in historical research.
• Students can process historical data using SPSS and interpret the statistical analysis of these data.
• Students can use the results of statistical analyses in research reports.

column1: This course has been designed to help students understand important and topical dilemma’s that financial market participants face in real life, and how academic insights can be used to solve these problems. The course builds on the Financial Modeling course in which basic financial models have been discussed and implemented in MS Excel. The main features of the course are the following: (1) introduction to topical dilemma’s in the financial industry such as differentiating between alternative philosophies in setting up investment portfolios and the implementation of sustainability, (2) the use of both classical studies and latest insights from the stream of literature on empirical asset pricing to solve these problems, (3) the use of MS Excel to implement solutions to these problems, and (4) Problem-Based Learning.
Attendance to the session is a requirement to participate in the exam. Student can miss max 2 lectures and otherwise are not eligible to take the exam.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Understand the complications of implementing sustainability in investment portfolio
• Understand the techniques for constructing rank portfolios, performing returns-based style analysis, and optimizing portfolios under sustainability restrictions
• Understand how to use MS Excel to implement these techniques to solve the problems mentioned earlier
• Understand how to interpret and present key results of their empirical analyses

column1: This course provides an introduction to the field of Quantitative Finance by studying modern econometric techniques that are widely used in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management and derivatives pricing and hedging.
The course can be divided into three parts:

column2: • In the first part, we consider models for time-varying volatilities and correlations of asset returns, which are crucial inputs for quantitative risk management. We also consider concepts such as Value-at-Risk and Expected Shortfall of an asset or portfolio of assets. The most important techniques for computing and evaluating these risk measures are studied. Ample attention will be given to the practical implementation of these techniques.

• In the second part of the course, we study factor models, which are commonly applied in asset pricing and portfolio management. For example, constructing a portfolio with optimal risk-return characteristics requires an estimate of the covariance matrix of asset returns. In practice the number of assets typically is large (100+), such that the number of unknown parameters becomes too large. Factor models then are an attractive way to reduce the dimensionality of the problem. Again, ample attention will be given to the practical implementation and use of these models.

• In the third and final part, we provide an introduction to the most important derivative securities, including options, forwards and futures. Popular models for computing the fair price of these derivatives are discussed, while we also consider the use of derivatives for hedging risk involved in other assets.

column1: This course aims at getting students involved in quantitative research. Students learn how to formulate appropriate research questions and hypotheses, how to operationalize key constructs, and how to use an online data tool (i.e., Qualtrics) for collecting data. Furthermore, students will learn how to write the Methods and the Results section of a scientific publication which uses quantitative data. Finally, students gain the knowledge of different data analyses (i.e., factor analysis, reliability analysis, ANOVA and mediation analysis using regression) by using SPSS and learn how to interpret results.

The course has a dual structure. First, students gain a thorough understanding of a variety of commonly used quantitative research methods. Second, students engage in practicing on specific methods in-depth and analyze data using statistical analysis.

column2: • Students should have completed the course Introduction to Social Science Research (CM1002) before they may enter the courses Quantitative and Qualitative Methods in Media and Communication.
• Students should have completed the course Introduction to Statistical Analysis (CM1005) before they may enter Quantitative Methods in Media and Communication.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• How and when to use common quantitative research methods in the field of media and communication.
• The benefits and restrictions of these methods.
• How to develop a research design and how to choose the right data analyses.

column1: This seminar will prepare you for formulating and executing your own quantitative research studies. The course content is arranged in the order of conducting a quantitative study, beginning with understanding research questions up to the analysis stage. General topics include the scientific process; developing and evaluating research questions and hypotheses; measurement (operationalization, validity, reliability); sampling; research design (experiments, quasi-experiments, non-experiments); evaluation; and generalizability (replication, meta-analyses).

This seminar differs from MBA and applied degree programs in that our focus is on the science underlying quantitative research methods. Each session has a similar structure: conventional perspectives, extensions through cutting-edge thinking, critiques, applications, and evaluation of a quantitative study.
(This course used to be offered under the title ""Empirical Research Methodology & Measurement"".)</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To learn basic principles and factors within each decision phase of the quantitative methodological process and their collective inter-dependencies.
• To develop a foundation for planning, structuring, implementing, and critiquing quantitative research methodology.
• To learn perspectives of quantitative methodological practices including conventional and opposing views, their respective limitations, and practical myths and urban legends.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Data can be collected through a variety of methods: peering through a microscope, measuring brain activity, retrieving records from large databases, excavating ancient artifacts, etc.; the list is virtually endless. Often, the data collected are quantitative in nature. This course will provide you a solid foundation for making well-informed decisions from quantitative data and turn data into understanding, insight, and knowledge.

The skills you develop in this course include the collection, organisation, analysis, interpretation and presentation of quantitative data. Doing this by hand  is  often  slow,  tedious  and  error  prone. With the rise of information technology, powerful tools have been developed to support us conducting these activities. You will learn how to import and export data, explore and manipulate data (i.e. recoding, transforming, aggregating and combining datasets), and create data visualizations using freely available statistical programming tools. Furthermore, you will learn about basic statistical theory to draw valid inferences from your datasets.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body> After completion of this course you should master (i.e., know, understand and be able to explain) the following:

column2: • The major statistical indices used to describe variables and relations between variables;
• How to draw statistically valid inferences about a population from samples;
• How to use SPSS to process and analyze data, and make graphs.

column1: Evidently, a single course cannot teach you all there is to know about statistics. In later years, depending on the major that you choose, more advanced courses on statistics (and research methods) will be offered.

column1: The course focuses on modern, quantitative methods for measuring risks faced by financial institutions. It covers:

column2: • Various risk measures and risk measure theory (Value-at-Risk, expected shortfall, coherency)
• General method used for quantifying risks (analytical method, historical simulation, Monte Carlo)
• Market risk and risk aggregation (dynamic volatility model, normal mixture distributions, Extreme Value Theory, copula)
• Credit risk (Merton model, threshold model, Bernoulli mixture model)
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To understand the risk management process from the perspective of financial institutions as the process by which various risk exposures are identified, measured, and controlled.

• To understand various quantitative techniques and econometric theories that are widely used in financial risk management. The course focuses on modern, quantitative methods to measure and manage the risks faced by financial institutions.
• To be prepared for the role of a risk manager in financial markets and to have necessary skills for future research in risk management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is to develop students’ knowledge and skills in quantitative, social-scientific research methods. While social scientists use a vast range of quantitative methods, this course will focus on the fundamentals of descriptive and inferential statistics.

Quantitative methods are used across the social sciences in sociology and public administration, psychology, criminology, political science, international relations, demography and economics (amongst others). It is impossible to become a well-rounded social scientist without a basic knowledge of quantitative methods for presenting and analyzing data.

Many fields outside of the social sciences make use of quantitative methods, as well, and statistics play an important role in business, policy making and analysis, and governance. The future is in the hands of a “data-literate” generation who can tame the jungle of data out there—including quantitative data!

We know that for some students, ‘quantitative methods’ may bring to mind visions of complex mathematical equations and confusing Gr𝜀𝜀𝜅 letters. And many may not have a background in mathematics or their last mathematics course may have been many years ago. But there is nothing to fear! We have designed this course to be a user-friendly introduction to quantitative methods for the social sciences, accessible to all, no matter their mathematical background (or affinity). Students will learn these methods by applying them to real-world questions. And they’ll get their hands dirty with real-world data, learning how to explore, analyze and present data using statistical software.

This course builds upon 1.3 Designing Social Research, where students learn how to use the empirical cycle to develop a research idea into a research question and testable hypotheses. It also builds upon 2.1 Qualitative Methods, where students learn how to answer research questions by collecting and analysing qualitative data. In this course, students further build their methodological toolkit by learning how to use quantitative data to answer research questions using hypothesis testing. Students will also learn how to understand and critically evaluate quantitative research conducted by others and the mass of quantitative information in the world around them.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course, students will be able to:

column2: Explain how measures of central tendency describe a distribution
Explain the differences between a sample and a population
List the implications of the central limit theorem and explain their importance for inferential statistics
Calculate and compare sample- and population characteristics
Formulate research questions which can be tested using statistical tests
Formulate hypotheses to match research question, which can be tested using statistical tests
Choose the correct analysis to test a given or one’s own research question
Conduct (by hand or with statistical software) and interpret the outcome of the following statistical tests/analyses:
With statistical software: one- and two-independent-samples t-tests, chi-square test, Pearson’s and Spearman’s correlations, bivariate linear regression, multiple linear regression.
Explain the use of control variables and positive and negative confounding; interpret multiple regression results with and without control variables
Conduct and interpret a moderation analysis between a discrete and a continuous variable and between two continuous variables using multiple linear regression;
Conduct and interpret a mediation analysis using multiple linear regression;
List the assumptions underlying multiple regression analysis.

column1: Students will also be able to do the following, with the help of statistical software:

column2: Calculate new variables, based on existing ones

Performing the following tests/analyses: calculating z-scores, one- and two-independent-sample t-tests, chi-square test, Pearson’s and Spearman’s correlations, bivariate linear regression and multivariate linear regression, including moderation and mediation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course seeks to provide students with the practical tools and theoretical vocabulary required to understand, conduct, and critically evaluate quantitative empirical research. During the course, students are exposed to the key types of models, their assumptions, common data collection approaches, and statistical software needed to become a successful, independent researcher.

The following key questions are addressed in the course: First, what research design is the best fit with my research question? Second, how do I measure the concepts underpinning my research question? Third, what data do I need to collect to address this question, and what tools should I use to collect this data? Fourth, what statistical models are best suited to analyze these data? And, finally, how do I report the results of my analyses in a rigorous and statistically sound manner? This course offers answers to these questions, which are of critical importance to anyone conducting quantitative research.
Attendance to the second through fourth workshops is mandatory: there will be practical exercises that need to be passed in order to pass the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understanding the key considerations in designing and implementing a quantitative empirical study
• Justifying choices related to statistical modelling approach and construct measurement
• Interpreting empirical results in an econometrically sound manner
• Understanding the required vocabulary to communicate quantitative research

column1: Prerequisite: Participants are required to have followed the one of the following courses before participating in Module II.
If you have already followed MEP-CK020 Biostatistics I, we do not recommend to do this course, as the contents are similar and overlapping.
For questions about the requirements, please contact Prof. dr. Dimitris Rizopoulos: d.rizopoulos@erasmusmc.nl

R has recently become one of the most popular languages for data analysis and statistics. This course teaches students the basics of this statistical programming language. The aim of this course is to equip participants with the R knowledge needed to explore data, make data visualizations and perform simple statistical analyses. At the end of the course, the participants will have gained basic skills in R, such that they will be able to independently read data into R, bring it in the correct structure, visualize the data, perform basic statistical analysis and write simple R functions. This course is module II in the modules on statistics. Participants must have followed module I (Introduction to Biostatistics) and need this module to follow the courses on Survival analysis (module III) and prediction models (module IV).
After completing of the course, the participant should:

column2: • Understand what R and Rstudio are, install them on their own PC/laptop, and know how to code in R;
• Be able to load in their data sets in R and perform different data transformations  to prepare the data for analyses;
• Know how to explore characteristics of their data set and visualize the data;
• Perform simple statistical analyses with R and interpret the results;
• Be able to write simple functions and loops to aid with data transformation and automation.

column1: *the program may be subject to change.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.
All assignments will be made during the planned practical sessions in the course. There are no additional assignments.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

column1: <body>In this BSc Honours course, you will explore the Silicon Valley modes of science and technology commercialization and its approaches to transfer knowledge - from research laboratories to new ventures and established companies. We will analyze how many of these local firms managed to develop into global leaders and how Silicon Valley became the symbol of a successful high-tech cluster.  At the same time, we will pay attention to the shadow side of Silicon Valley and what it stands for. For example, there are growing concerns about the monopoly power of companies like Google, Facebook and Amazon.com (see European Union), their negative role in the elections of democratic countries (e.g. US and UK), their market power and political influence (e.g. Facebook vs the Australian government), their business models based on permanent privacy violations, their negative effects on labour relations in platform companies (e.g. Uber), as well as undesirable effects on the liveliness of cities (e.g. Airbnb). Finally, we will investigate the world of policy makers: is it possible to emulate the success of Silicon Valley in other regions of the world and what are conditions for success? After an intensive introduction to the key actors and factors making up Silicon Valley as the world’s hotbed for innovative entrepreneurship, the course will conclude with a study trip to Silicon Valley and the Bay area.   </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The course provides students with a broad understanding and in-depth knowledge of topics related to Silicon Valley and its effects on the global economy and society. More specifically, upon completion of the course, you will ….

column2: • Be able to analyse the requirements of a regional innovation ecosystem such as Silicon Valley including early-stage venture deployment, corporate venturing, and university-industry-government collaboration
• Be able to articulate the importance and role of a pro-active and entrepreneurial mindset for countries, regions, and companies
• Be able to analyse why some innovation practices of startups, scale-ups and leading companies work better than others
• Be able to conduct a foresight exercise for the purpose of understanding which strategic challenges organizations face in a particular industry.
• Be able to develop innovative solutions for companies and organizations looking for new ways to improve their relevance and efficiency
• Be able to effectively present your ideas, both orally and in writing

column1: Students will learn how to apply structured problem-solving skills to a current real-world strategy project of a corporate partner. Students will use a structured approach to provide a recommendation for a current problem of the corporate partner, which is divided into 3 mini case challenges. These strategic challenges are transdisciplinary and not limited to one functional discipline, such as marketing or logistics. They further have a large structural impact on the company’s revenue and cost structures. The corporate partner is involved in the case, such that students can discuss choices that present real trade-offs, long-term strategy commitment, and the position of the company vis-a-vis competitors with the corporate partner.
Attendance in lectures and workshops is mandatory. All lectures and workshops are in-person. No live streaming will be provided.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Judge solutions for a strategic problem and select a solution with the course-specific strategic management methodology
• Communicate the strategic problem, its solution, and the underlying problem-solving approach to specialist and non-specialist audiences unambiguously
• Assess and influence your own and team members’ collaborative behavior during teamwork
• Identify consequences of a strategic problem and the corresponding solution for stakeholders of the focal organization

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114631,2023,RW Cultural Lifestyles and Participation,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TA Calkins III'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This research workshop focuses on the relation between theory and research in the domain of cultural participation taken in the broad sense. The questions to be addressed can be summarized as: who engages in which cultural activities and why? Students formulate questions about (specific forms or patterns of leisure or) cultural participation and its relation to people’s socioeconomic background characteristics and formulate hypotheses on the basis of the relevant literature.

Subsequently, they employ data made available by the lecturer to test their hypotheses on social differentiation in cultural participation (be it museum visits, concert or theatre attendance, TV watching, reading, going out, etc), Statistical techniques for causal analysis will be used in order to determine which characteristics of respondents are actually determining their cultural taste or behavior.

Students produce a research report (individually or in duos) that includes a concise literature review on the topic to be analyzed, and a presentation and discussion of the statistical analyses carried out.
It is recommended to take this course only after the Statistics course has been completed successfully.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course, students learn to answer questions about cultural participation by analyzing existing quantitative data. After this research workshop, they are able to translate substantial questions into adequate statistical analyses and produce a sound report of their work. They learn to critically reflect on the (im)possibilities of empirical research and to interpret their results in light of the original research questions.</body>
