The course deals with key concepts of rationality and choice:
- preferences and their interpretation, representation, and measurement,

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course gives an advanced introduction to problems of rationality and choice. In doing so, we will encounter and analyse a number of foundational problems associated with both decision and game theory. After having completed this course, you will be able to:
(i) name, understand, and criticise key concepts in rational choice theory from a philosophical perspective and in terms of their role for the foundations of economic theory,
(ii) critically analyse philosophical and economic contributions to decision theory in terms of their arguments, and their conceptual and methodological assumptions,
(iii) critically analyse philosophical and economic contributions to and uses of game theory in terms of their arguments, and their conceptual and methodological assumptions,

(iv) critically evaluate and engage with philosophical and economic literature in rational choice theory and any literature in the humanities and social sciences that employs rational choice theory, in an independent way.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: If there is one problem that health care systems around the world face and share, it is making the best use of the available resources in health care. Despite growing health care expenditures, there are never sufficient resources to meet all health care needs and demands. This means that health care somehow needs to be rationed. Baily (2003) defined rationing as follows:
“To limit the beneficial health care an individual receives by any means – price or non-price, direct or indirect, explicit or implicit.”

Hence, policy makers somehow decide or organise that some care, that would likely benefit certain patients, is not provided (timely or freely). Although perhaps necessary and unavoidable, rationing (even the word itself) has been, is, and likely will remain a contentious topic in both politics and society.

This course focuses on this important topic mainly from an economic perspective, making use of behavioural economic insights. The topics that are discussed are rationing in general, demand and supply side rationing, and principles of rationing. Moreover, you will gain insight into how different countries ration health care.
The course consists of 6 weeks of interactive lectures.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To acquaint students with principles and practice of rationing health care from an economic perspective.
• To provide a thorough understanding of supply side and demand side rationing and their advantages and disadvantages
• To give insight in how different European countries deal with this difficult topic

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111378,2023,Re-imagining Tomorrow through Arts & Sciences,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['CLH Tio, MSc', 'T de Groot, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This is a transdisciplinary minor for students from Erasmus University, University of Leiden, Delft University, Codarts University of the Arts, and Willem de Kooning Academy.

In this minor, students from various fields and backgrounds develop theoretical competences in the area of transdisciplinary research and together with teachers and societal partners, a setting is created in which theory and practice, and academic and artistic practices interact to identify and reframe a complex societal issue. The minor facilitates the building of collaborative learning contexts and networks, with an emphasis on the involvement of societal partners (e.g. government, businesses, and civil society members). This encourages students to (further) develop an entrepreneurial attitude.

Students and teachers from Erasmus University College, Codarts and Willem de Kooning Academy will work together to create a collaborative framework that allows combining disciplines within a project situated in a specific context. The minor is suitable for open-minded, engaged and critical students who feel an urgency to work beyond disciplines and are keen to actively partake in shaping their learning process. This minor requires serious interest and an open and flexible attitude towards education. Students will collaborate continuously and intensively with their fellow students, teachers and societal partners, and take position as active, committed world citizens. This gives students the opportunity to engage in transdisciplinary, collaborative project-based research, in a small team of students and teachers from the fields of science, visual arts and performing arts, and together with stakeholders from beyond the academy/university. The minor is part of the innovative educational practices of the Rotterdam Arts and Sciences Lab (RASL). While exploring a complex societal issue (the selection of the issue is student-led) in depth and from a range of perspectives, students will develop creative, critical and other skills needed in the 21st century.

The minor is divided into two parts (15 EC + 15 EC). Students can either participate in Part I or in Parts I and II. It is not possible to participate only in Part II. EUC students can enrol in Part I (15 EC) as an EUR minor and opt to enrol in part II in their elective space.
This is a full-time minor, and the collaborative nature of the programme requires committed attendance and a flexible attitude throughout the entire process.

column1: Real Estate Economics covers the economic processes underlying our built environment. Based on insights from Urban Economics we look at markets for residential and commercial real estate. In this course we cover land use and land pricing, hedonic pricing, implicit prices of urban amenities, land negotiations, zoning, development, valuation and real estate as a specific class of assets.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Reproduce and interpret theories and views on the spatial-economic development of cities and the functioning of urban labour, land and real estate markets.
• Reproduce and interpret theories on real estate economics, dealing with investment decisions and real estate development.
• Apply economic reasoning to analyse current issues in the development of urban areas on various spatial levels: from region to neighbourhood to dwelling.
• Apply theories, concepts and research methods from contemporary literature to practical examples.

column1: Het vak bestaat uit twee delen. In het eerste deel van het vak – duurt tien weken – komt de basis van de rechtsgebieden aan bod. Op deze manier leren de studenten de kern van ieder rechtsgebied.

In het tweede deel van het vak – duur vijf weken – verdiepen de studenten zich in een rechtsgebied naar keuze. De studenten kiezen voor een aan het gekozen rechtsgebied gekoppelde bedrijf. Studenten gaan vervolgens groepsmatig en zelfstandig aan de slag om op projectmatige wijze de projectdossiers uit te werken en de bedrijven te voorzien van advies. Zij hebben daarbij de rol van juridisch specialisten/junior advocaten van een advocatenkantoor die het bedrijf van advies moet voorzien en worden ‘begeleid’ door hun patroon (docent). De adviezen worden door de studenten gepresenteerd aan het betreffende bedrijf. Zij leren daarmee de stof toe te passen in de praktijk en samen te werken. Ook zal het verband tussen de verschillende rechtsgebieden aan de orde komen in de projectdossiers. Zo kan een rechtsregel in het ene domein een knelpunt vormen voor het andere domein (denk aan bescherming van werknemers versus vrijheid van ondernemerschap).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak Recht en Bedrijf draait om de samenhang van de rechtsgebieden Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht. Het vak duurt in totaal 15 weken (blok 4, 5 en 6) en bestaat uit twee delen. Het vak beslaat in totaal 21 EC.

Het doel van het vak is studenten (op hoofdlijnen) de juridische taal te leren spreken van het Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht, om vervolgens de verschillen en overeenkomsten tussen de drie rechtsgebieden aan de hand van concrete casus te analyseren. De student neemt als het ware de positie in van een bedrijfsjurist en is in staat de juridische knelpunten die zich in het bedrijfsleven op het snijvlak van Arbeids-, Handels-, en Ondernemingsrecht manifesteren te herkennen en een (begin van een) oplossing aan te dragen. Daarnaast leren studenten door middel van projectmatig onderwijs samen te werken. Ze leren de stof toe te passen in de praktijk door bedrijven te adviseren over juridische vraagstukken die bij deze bedrijven spelen. In dit tweede deel verschiet het perspectief van de bedrijfsjurist naar dat van de junior advocaat of juridisch specialist die door het bedrijf is ingehuurd een vraagstuk op te lossen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak bestaat uit twee delen. In het eerste deel van het vak – duurt tien weken – komt de basis van de rechtsgebieden aan bod. Op deze manier leren de studenten de kern van ieder rechtsgebied.

In het tweede deel van het vak – duur vijf weken – verdiepen de studenten zich in een rechtsgebied naar keuze. De studenten kiezen voor een aan het gekozen rechtsgebied gekoppelde bedrijf. Studenten gaan vervolgens groepsmatig en zelfstandig aan de slag om op projectmatige wijze de projectdossiers uit te werken en de bedrijven te voorzien van advies. Zij hebben daarbij de rol van juridisch specialisten/junior advocaten van een advocatenkantoor die het bedrijf van advies moet voorzien en worden ‘begeleid’ door hun patroon (docent). De adviezen worden door de studenten gepresenteerd aan het betreffende bedrijf. Zij leren daarmee de stof toe te passen in de praktijk en samen te werken. Ook zal het verband tussen de verschillende rechtsgebieden aan de orde komen in de projectdossiers. Zo kan een rechtsregel in het ene domein een knelpunt vormen voor het andere domein (denk aan bescherming van werknemers versus vrijheid van ondernemerschap).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak Recht en Bedrijf draait om de samenhang van de rechtsgebieden Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht. Het vak duurt in totaal 15 weken (blok 4, 5 en 6) en bestaat uit twee delen. Het vak beslaat in totaal 21 EC.

Het doel van het vak is studenten (op hoofdlijnen) de juridische taal te leren spreken van het Arbeidsrecht, Handelsrecht en Ondernemingsrecht, om vervolgens de verschillen en overeenkomsten tussen de drie rechtsgebieden aan de hand van concrete casus te analyseren. De student neemt als het ware de positie in van een bedrijfsjurist en is in staat de juridische knelpunten die zich in het bedrijfsleven op het snijvlak van Arbeids-, Handels-, en Ondernemingsrecht manifesteren te herkennen en een (begin van een) oplossing aan te dragen. Daarnaast leren studenten door middel van projectmatig onderwijs samen te werken. Ze leren de stof toe te passen in de praktijk door bedrijven te adviseren over juridische vraagstukken die bij deze bedrijven spelen. In dit tweede deel verschiet het perspectief van de bedrijfsjurist naar dat van de junior advocaat of juridisch specialist die door het bedrijf is ingehuurd een vraagstuk op te lossen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course “Recht en Data” focuses on the governance of data and data protection at the national, EU and international level, with a special focus on the complex legal relations arising from the techno-empirical reality of the digital age. Students will specially become familiarized with the overarching data governance and data protection regime at the EU level (GDPR and Data Governance Act), as well as the recent legal development in the framework of the European strategy for data: data act and the proposal for a European Health Data Space. This course looks particularly at the fundamental rights and entitlements dimensions of data.

De cursus “Recht en Data” richt de aandacht op de governance van data en dataprotectie op het nationale, EU en internationale niveau, met bijzondere aandacht voor de complexe rechtsbetrekkingen die opkomen in het digitale tijdperk. De studenten zullen vooral vertrouwd raken met het overkoepelende data governance en beschermingsregime in de EU (AVG en Data Governance Verordening). Daarbij worden de recente juridisch ontwikkelingen vanuit de EU Data Strategie betrokken, zoals de Data Verordening en het voorstel voor een Europese Health Data Space. De cursus stelt centraal: de fundamentele rechten en de beschikkingsmogelijkheden over data.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, students:

column2: • Are able to indicate the interdependencies between the economic, technological, and sociological dimensions of the complex context of data law for market actors, governments, and citizens.
<li>Can select and apply to a complex case the law regarding:

column3: • The position of individuals as data subjects under data protection law, consumer law and the law regarding entitlements to data.
• Data governance and data protection principles and rules

column2: • Can critically examine the scope, core concepts, principles, data subject rights and other actors’ responsibilities under the GDPR.
• Can appraise and compare the different regulatory and governance initiatives at the national and supranational level on which data are the main object of regulation.
• Can differentiate, investigate, and apply the concepts through which the law determines entitlements vis-à-vis data, as well as the possibilities and limitations of these entitlements.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/111320,2023,Recht en gezondheidszorg,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['EM Linthorst, LL.M', 'mr. CA Bol', 'mr.dr. AP den Exter', 'prof.mr.dr. MAJM Buijsen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In deze Minor wordt u geprikkeld om op juridisch-medisch-ethische, sociaal-economische en communicatieve vraagstukken te reflecteren en om op grond van de geldende regelgeving en heersende morele opvattingen hier beargumenteerd over te kunnen discussiëren.

De gezondheidszorg beslaat inmiddels meer dan 10% van de nationale economie. Het is de sector waar verhoudingsgewijs het meeste geld in om gaat en waarin, ondanks de economische recessie, een spectaculaire groei van de werkgelegenheid is waar te nemen. In de afgelopen tien jaar groeide het aantal banen in de zorg met 385 duizend. Het totaal aantal banen in Nederland nam toe met 515 duizend. Drie kwart van de banengroei in het afgelopen decennium is dus toe te schrijven aan de zorg. De gezondheidszorg is sterk in beweging en juridiseert in toenemende mate. Met gezondheid en gezondheidszorg samenhangende economische, juridische en ethische vraagstukken halen dag in dag uit de voorpagina’s van de dagbladen.

Recht en gezondheidszorg staat allereerst uitgebreid stil bij de rechtsbetrekkingen tussen de belangrijkste partijen in de gezondheidszorg: de burger als patiënt, de zorgaanbieder (dokter, ziekenhuis), de zorgfinancier (de verzekeraar) en de burger als verzekerde. Aan bod komen onder meer de geneeskundige behandelingsovereenkomst, het beroepsgeheim, de rechten en plichten van patiënten, de rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaars, de aansprakelijkheid voor medische missers, het medisch tucht- en klachtrecht, medezeggenschap in de zorg, (good) governance, marktwerking, rol en taak van de overheid in de sector en het zorgverzekeringsrecht. Ook de uitdijende internationaalrechtelijke dimensie van gezondheidszorg komt aan bod. Het recht op gezondheidszorg is immers een mensenrecht en ook op dit terrein wint de Europese Unie aan invloed.

Een van de functies van het recht in onze samenleving is het voorkomen van conflicten en, als conflicten al bestaan, om deze op te lossen. Dit geldt ook voor het terrein van de gezondheidszorg, waar men soms van andere regels moet uitgaan dan in andere maatschappelijke sectoren gebruikelijk is. In deze Minor staat die specifieke wetgeving op het terrein van de gezondheidszorg centraal.

Het gezondheidsrecht bestaat naast eigen wetten en regels die specifiek op de gezondheidszorg van toepassing zijn, ook uit leerstukken van algemeen recht. Allereerst gaan we dan ook in op een aantal algemene rechtsgebieden, zoals het burgerlijke recht, het strafrecht, het bestuursrecht en het internationale recht. Doel is het bekend worden met de aard en de functie van deze rechtsgebieden. Daarnaast staat de betekenis hiervan voor de gezondheidszorg centraal. In sommige gevallen zal dan blijken dat het algemene recht niet voor alles een oplossing heeft, waardoor er toch weer behoefte is aan specifieke regelgeving. Ook de relatie tussen algemeen recht en bijzondere wetgeving is dus een punt van aandacht. Omdat deze Minor toegankelijk is voor studenten van verschillende studierichtingen, zullen afhankelijk van de beschikbare voorkennis, (aspecten) van te bespreken onderwerpen bekend, minder bekend of nog totaal onbekend zijn. Binnen deze Minor is dan ook een van de doelstellingen dat studenten elkaar bevragen, elkaar zaken uitleggen en zo van elkaar leren.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De student verkrijgt kennis van en inzicht in:

column2: • de wijze waarop in Nederland het stelsel van de gezondheidszorg juridisch is vormgegeven
• rechten en plichten van de patiënt
• rechten en plichten van de beroepsbeoefenaar, zorginstelling, zorgverzekeraar en zorgverzekerde
• de internationaal- en Europeesrechtelijke aspecten van gezondheidszorg

• de juridische aspecten van bijzondere vraagstukken als euthanasie, dwangbehandeling, biotechnologie, orgaandonatie, proefpersonenonderzoek, toegankelijkheid van de zorg, de menselijke waardigheid, et cetera.

column1: De student verkrijgt vaardigheden in:

column2: • het opzoeken, interpreteren en toepassen van relevante regelgeving
• het zelfstandig schrijven van een essay
• het mondeling presenteren van onderzoeksresultaten
• het met elkaar discussiëren over gezondheidsrechtelijke actuele onderwerpen in hun sociaaleconomische en/of sociaalmedisch-ethische context

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114237,2023,Recht, economie en maatschappij",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['mr. JJA van Amerongen', 'prof.mr.dr. F Weber', 'prof.mr.dr. LT Visscher']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Waar mensen samenleven en goederen schaars zijn, ontstaan onvermijdelijk conflicten. Het recht biedt oplossingen voor deze conflicten. Rechten worden dus toegekend en plichten worden opgelegd omdat ze ergens toe dienen, omdat ze een functie vervullen. In R.E.M. wordt het recht bestudeerd vanuit de functie van het verlagen van kosten voor de samenleving als geheel.

De verschillende rechtsregels vormen samen een aaneensluitend geheel van oplossingen die ervoor zorgen dat verschillende soorten kosten voor de samenleving als geheel verminderd worden. Bij deze kosten kan gedacht worden aan bijvoorbeeld ongevalskosten, vervuilingskosten, overlast en hinder, schade doordat regels en afspraken niet worden nageleefd, kosten door criminaliteit et cetera. In het vak komen voorbeelden aan bod uit onder andere het privaatrecht (eigendom, contract, onrechtmatige daad), het strafrecht en het bestuursrecht. Ook worden fiscaal recht en internationaal en Europees recht aangestipt.
Bij het analyseren van de effecten van rechtsregels is, naast theoretisch onderzoek, empirisch onderzoek van belang. In R.E.M. worden enkele voorbeelden van zulk empirisch onderzoek kort besproken.

R.E.M. dus gaat over de maatschappelijke rol van het recht, waarbij de verschillende rechtsgebieden worden gezien als onderdelen van een samenhangend geheel, en waarbij niet alleen aandacht aan theoretisch maar ook aan empirisch onderzoek wordt besteed. Op deze manier beoogt het vak een ‘scharnier’ te vormen waarmee inzichtelijk wordt dat alle vakken uit het eerste bachelorjaar, alsmede uit de verdere rechtenstudie, met elkaar verbonden zijn.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Uitleggen dat het recht een functie in de samenleving vervult.
• Uitleggen hoe de rechtseconomie de functie van het recht in de samenleving invult.
• De ex ante en ex post benadering van het recht vergelijken en uitleggen welke benadering de rechtseconomie hanteert.
• Beargumenteren hoe efficiëntie en rechtvaardigheid samen kunnen gaan.
• Vanuit rechtseconomisch perspectief schetsen hoe verschillende rechtsgebieden één systeem vormen.
• Alternatieve juridische oplossingen voor een samenlevingsprobleem met elkaar vergelijken aan de hand van een prikkel-, transactie- en risicokostenanalyse.
• Concrete voorbeelden uit wetgeving en rechtspraak beoordelen aan de hand van de prikkel-, transactie- en risicokostenanalyse

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het overkoepelende thema van dit vak is ‘recht, staat en samenleving’. Onderwerpen die onder andere aan bod zullen komen zijn de belangrijkste ethische theorieën (utilisme, kantiaanse plichtenethiek en deugdenethiek) en juridische beroepsethiek, grondrechten, democratie en rechtsstaat, maatschappelijk onrecht, de problematiek van multilevel legal orders en global legal pluralism, theorieën van het sociaal contract, theorieën van verdelende rechtvaardigheid, het debat over legal moralism, strafrechtstheorieën en het debat over universalisme versus relativisme. De relevantie van de vaak abstracte theorieën zal inzichtelijk worden gemaakt door middel van terugkoppeling naar actuele casus.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De algemene doelstelling van het vak valt in twee delen uiteen. Het eerste doel is om de studenten kennis en inzicht te laten verwerven in de normatieve grondslagen en de achtergronden van het recht en de vier grote rechtsgebieden: privaatrecht; staats- en bestuursrecht; strafrecht; internationaal en Europees recht. Het lezen van rechtsfilosofische teksten – moderne én klassieke – is een van de methoden hierbij.

Het tweede doel van het vak is om de studenten te trainen in de schriftelijke vaardigheid om filosofisch te reflecteren op het recht en een beargumenteerd normatief standpunt in te nemen. In het onderwijs worden vaardigheden, kennis en inzicht zoveel mogelijk op elkaar betrokken.

Een onderdeel van het vak vormt de schrijfvaardighedentraining. Deze training vindt onder meer plaats in de vorm van studievragen en het wekelijks uploaden van een antwoord op een oude tentamenvraag. In week 3 is er een take-home schrijfopdracht (rechtsfilosofisch betoog) voor 10 punten.

column1: <body>De rechter moet achterhalen of de verdachte schuldig is aan het tenlastegelegde feit. Dat doet hij door te bekijken of er in het dossier voldoende wettige bewijsmiddelen zitten die hem overtuigen van de schuld van de verdachte. In deze minor wordt ingegaan op wat er allemaal mis kan gaan bij dit proces. Ook wordt ingegaan op een alternatieve, rekenkundige manier van bewijsweging, de zogenoemde Bayesiaanse benadering. Bewijsmiddelen die aan bod komen zijn: getuigenverklaringen, herkenningen en bekentenissen. Verder wordt onder meer ingegaan op leugendetectie, verhoren en tunnelvisie</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Tijdens dit vak worden deelnemers bekend gemaakt met de volgende onderwerpen:

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114635,2023,Recognition in the Visual Arts,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['CA Malig Jedlicki, MSc', 'U Hahn, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This research workshop examines recognition within the art world. As in most fields, recognition can lead to various types of artistic success, from economic gain to critical acclaim. However, recognition in the arts is better understood as a social phenomenon, rather than exclusively the consequence of an artistic creator or artwork’s characteristics. Field conventions dictate what is created and ""greatness"" is evaluated according to the standards of time, place, and those professionals credentialed to offer their opinion. In this course, we will take such a sociological perspective in order to arrive at a better understanding of why certain creators are celebrated, while the majority of art and artists are largely unknown. We begin by thinking about what is recognition in the art world and what the different forms of recognition are. Next we discuss what factors contribute to differences in exposure and value. As this course is a research workshop, once we have discussed these questions, we will begin to empirically find answers. Students will conduct a small qualitative research project in which they examine recognition in the art world.
Note: It is highly recommended for entry into this course that students have completed the first year course on Methods.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>By the end of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Understand key concepts in the sociological examination of recognition in the visual arts;
• Design their own small, qualitative research project about recognition in the visual arts;
• Conduct their research project about recognition in the visual arts;
• Report on their research project through written and oral description.

Oudijn', 'dr. A.V.J. Rozeboom, Arts', 'dr. J.W. van Neck', 'dr. M.J. Koudstaal']",,

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The reflection track supports and structures the students’ learning journey by helping them to critically reflect on their experiences. Beyond cognitivism, the track familiarizes students with reflective concepts from existential phenomenology, psychodynamics, and sociology. Students will engage with the reflection track through interviews and guided journaling practices, with journal entries serving as springboards for deeper reflection practices during a series of small-group interactive workshops.  Students will develop a reflective habit through regular journaling and meta-reflection and will develop a sense of agency in the world related to sustainability issues.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Student will be familiar with the psychological frameworks underlying the four levels of reflection in the reflection track (cognitivism, phenomenology, psychoanalysis, critical pedagogy)
2. Students will be able to apply the psychological frameworks to their personal reflection process through the use of structured journaling methods and guided workshops
3. Students will be able to articulate their reflection across multiple levels verbally and in writing, through the use of peer-interviews and Articulated Learning Reflection (ALR).
4. Students will be able to draw a learning arc across their entire learning experience in the programme using the ALR toolkit.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This Reinforcement Learning course focuses on using machine learning methods to model and solve problems relevant to management science problems – in particular, those problems involving machines that autonomously make decisions on the behalf of the modeler, as in online settings.

The course is based mainly on reinforcement learning (when we model states and transitions) and multi-armed bandits (when states are not modelled). We will focus on the design, solution, and implementation of learning methods for sequential decision-making under uncertainty. Sequential decision problems involve a trade-off between exploitation (acting on the information already collected) and exploration (gathering more information). These problems arise in many important domains, ranging from online advertising, clinical trials, website optimization, marketing campaign and revenue management.
1. Reinforcement Learning and multi-armed bandits: introduction and foundations
2. Stochastic Bandits and Regret Analysis
3. Optimality and lower bounds. The UCB algorithm
5. Contextual Bandits, Adversarial Bandits and Bayesian bandits (e.g., Gittins and DAI)
6. MDP and Model-based State-based RL algorithms
7. Reinforcement Learning and Deep Reinforcement Learning

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of the course, students will be able to:

<table class=""Table"" style=""background-color:#ffffff; border-collapse:separate; border-spacing:0px; box-sizing:inherit; color:#363636; font-family:-apple-system,BlinkMacSystemFont,"Segoe UI",Roboto,Oxygen,Ubuntu,Cantarell,"Fira Sans","Droid Sans","Helvetica Neue",Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-variant-ligatures:normal; font-weight:400; text-align:start; text-decoration-color:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-thickness:initial; white-space:pre-wrap; width:484px"">

column4: KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING

Understand the fundamental building blocks of reinforcement learning methods and in particular, state-free multi-armed bandits, such as Thompson sampling, UCB, index-based methods and regret-based methods.
APPLICATION OF KNOWLEDGE
Choose the appropriate method for solving specific problem, program these methods, apply them sensibly, interpret the results and understand conceptual and practical implications.
COMMUNICATION
Written and oral presentation of results within the research project.
LEARNING SKILLS
Work on the research project on a team.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114687,2023,Religion, Culture and Global Encounters",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. N da Silva Perez', 'J Beocanin']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The goal of this advanced course is to teach students how to plan and execute a coherent and well supported small research project in the theme of religion, culture, and global encounters.

Lectures will showcase historical examples from the diverse histories of, for instance, Judaism, Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, African Spiritualities, American Indigenous Spiritualities, and Chinese Philosophies, among others. Tutorials will focus on the guided development of the student's research project related to the role of religion and spirituality in global history. Students will advance their already existing writing skills to analyze historical sources, critically examine historiographical arguments, and create sound arguments.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course combines learning goals related to both content and skills. By completing the work of this course, the student will be able to:

column2: • Understand and critically discuss selected historical case studies, ranging from different periods in history, where religion or spirituality intersected with culture to influence geopolitical events.

• Analyze existing secondary literature to write a concise historiographical overview—applied to a specific case study that the student will choose in consultation with the instructor—of how religion intersects with culture to influence geopolitical events.
• Formulate a relevant research question about the role of religion in the cultural context of the case study the student will choose in consultation with the instructor.
• Select and analyze relevant primary sources about the role of religion in the cultural context of the specific case study the student will choose in consultation with the instructor.

• Create a coherent research-based argument, using primary sources, and communicate it in a well-supported research paper about the role of religion in the cultural context of the specific case study the student will choose in consultation with the instructor.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course in ‘Reporting, Analysis and Valuation’ you will learn the basic concepts of financial statement analysis, enabling you to understand how financial reports are used by investors and to take a fundamental approach to equity (and debt) valuation.

The course has a practical emphasis. We adopt the view of an active investor and apply methods of fundamental analysis in a series of real-life exercises, cases, and assignments involving listed companies. We examine various valuation methods—residual earnings, abnormal earnings growth, and discounted cash flow approaches to valuation, among others—and ask which one will give us an edge. We do all this under the strict discipline of a fundamentalist: separate what you know from speculation and anchor in what you know from analysing financial statement information.

Just as importantly, we learn how to handle accounting and financial reports in valuation. We see that valuation is really a matter of accounting for value. The course combines accounting principles and investment principles to answer the question: How do I account for value so that I can challenge stock prices with some confidence?

The course discusses techniques that are commonly used in an equity research department of a bank, independent research firm, or equity hedge fund. However, the material covered in the course is just as relevant to the corporate business analyst or financial consultant, for private equity analysis, for evaluating acquisitions, restructurings and other investments, and for calculating the value generated by strategic decisions. Thus, the course is of interest to those contemplating careers in investment banking, security analysis, accounting, consulting, and corporate finance.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the environment in which financial reporting by companies takes place
• Analyse business strategies to understand the value that they add
• Determine the quality of the accounting in financial reports and undo accounting distortions
• Analyse a firm's operating and investment performance through ratio and cash flow analysis
• Understand theories on capital structure and dividend choice
• Analyse a firm's financing and dividend decisions
• Understand the primary determinants of the cost of capital
• Forecast future financial statements, determine the cost of capital, and apply fundamentals-based valuation techniques
• Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular valuation case, and present and defend the joint findings and conclusions in a report

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/115845,2023,Representation, the People and Contemporary Democracy",Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,"['dr. GH van Oenen', 'J van der Klaauw, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is part of cluster 1: Representation: Democracy, Science, and Culture.

Ever since the concept of ‘we the people’ was born, with Rousseau and the American and French revolutions, there has been a search for how to represent this sovereign yet elusive entity, ‘the people’, the product of the abolition of fixed social categories like estates. Social relations have now become a matter of contestation and proclamation fueled by association and mobilization. Combined with processes of emancipation, and division of labour, this had led to ever shifting ideas and practices of who represents whom. Parliament, government, the magistrature, labor unions, new social movements, the media, populist politicans all claim to speak in name of the people and to somehow represent either some part, or all of the people.

Democracy, as it unfolds in thought and in practice, both enriches and complicates representation through its claim that ‘the people themselves’ are both willing and able to participate in processes of representation. In its radical form this implies that the people could, and should, represent themselves. As ‘natural’ or traditional representation has vanished, yet ‘the people’ can never be present, the place of power in democracy is ‘empty’, or structurally vacant, and the shaping of both the people and whomever represents them becomes a matter of symbolic practices, which temporarily assign roles and legitimize procedures.

In this course we look at manifestations, conceptualizations, and institutionalizations of the people in forms such as crowds, masses, parliaments, movements, and assemblies. We discuss phenomena like populism, anarchism, communism, and post-politics in their relation to more established forms and ideologies of politics and democracy. We will be reading and discussing authors such as Claude Lefort, Frank Ankersmit, Jodi Dean, Nadia Urbinati, Warren Breckman, Chantal Mouffe, Michel Foucault, and Judith Butler.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - understanding the basic concepts around democracy and representation;
- understanding the relation of the basic concepts around democracy and representation in historical and cultural context;
- understanding how to apply the basic concepts around democracy and representation to societal issues and problems</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114690,2023,Representing War in Popular Historical Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. CR Ribbens'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: World War II until today is an important reference point in popular historical culture, both in the Netherlands and elsewhere. Other large-scale conflicts, such as the First World War, the Cold War  and the recent wars in the Middle East, are as well appealing historical experiences with an impact on the collective memory. But the way wars are represented and collectively remembered is anything but immutable and unambiguous. The ways in which wars of the past were brought to the fore (usually outside of academia) during the 20th and 21st centuries for a variety of audiences are quite diverse: ranging from museum exhibitions to comics and novels, and from films and musicals to games and new media. In this course the focus is on the question in what kind of historical representations of war all these elements have resulted, and what meanings are assigned to it? What are the expectations of both producers and consumers regarding different ways of presenting this past, and which views exist on understanding and – in as far as possible - 'experiencing' past wars. The emphasis will be on war representations in the popular historical culture of the Western world with a special focus on the medium of comics

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of the course is to gain knowledge and understanding of the ways in which wars from the early 20th century to the beginning of the 21st century are represented and framed in popular historical culture. Students learn in what ways a diversity of media and other forms of historical presentation reflect memories and visions of various large-scale conflicts and how developments in these representations relate  to historical interpretations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Research & Writing Skills course has the objective of developing practical skills in doing legal research and in writing legal texts. The course will assist students with developing expertise in three different legal methods, namely classical black letter law research, comparative law research and legal research design. Law and Ethics will be part of courses in block 2 to combine substantive and social aspects of law at the same time. The skills of the course of Research and Writing Skills will be trained through writing papers, oral presentations and group discussions.

All topics you will be studying relate to commercial law, with a further focus on questions relating to the master variation you have chosen. This way, the course not only introduces you to legal research, improving skills necessary for the remaining of the course as well as your legal career, but also introduces you to the exciting field of commercial law, which will be explored for the rest of the year.

During the Research & Writing Skills course you will be confronted with many practical and legal issues from recent years. Common to these issues is the international nature and complexity of the legal relations involved. In order to find sound and workable solutions to these problems, you must learn to determine the relevant international standard(s) applicable. Where no uniform international standard exists, a comparative legal approach may be necessary to determine the main schools of thought about certain issues adopted by different legal systems.

The internal moot case plays a central role in the Research & Writing Skills course curriculum. It means that (almost) all of the assignments are linked to this case and constitute important building blocks that you use, structuring your argumentation for instance when drafting a legal memorandum (it will be explained further in a section with the assignments’ overview). For example, the comparative law assignment concerns force majeure, which is a relevant legal concept used in the moot case. Case reports that are discussed during the workgroup sessions are also useful authorities that can be used to support legal argumentation during the internal moot.

Each week you will face more and more challenging legal concepts, which will be based on (building on) the knowledge already acquired from the previous sessions. It means that the course requires your full attention.

Dear Exchange Students, Research and Writing Skills courses designed for different variations of Commercial Law LL.M. (RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84) offer an intensive small group teaching and training. These courses are taught by the same teachers, have a very similar structure and will allow you to acquire the same set of skills. Please bear in mind, however, that in case when the limited capacity of the chosen track is reached, we might be forced to assign you to another Research and Writing Skills variation of Commercial Law LL.M. (thus another course from those available under these codes RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84).</body>

After this course the student should have an ease of using the following research and writing skills both while working independently but also when collaborating with others.</body>

column1: The research clinic constitutes the formal start of the thesis trajectory of the MSc Strategic Management and MSc Strategic Entrepreneurship curriculum. The master thesis is a piece of empirical research in which you develop and examine a research question based on your interests.  It is an independent project that represents a major part of your degree program. During the process, you have the opportunity to dig deep into your chosen topic and train your skills in academic writing, empirical methods, and project management. While the process is intellectually exciting, it can at times also feel complex and challenging.

The objective of the research clinic is to help students become familiar with the process of academic research. It intends to set a solid foundation for the thesis trajectory by providing guidance for the development of the research statement. It also provides practical insights with respect to writing academic work, including: identifying relevant literature, writing style, referencing style, reading academic papers, organizing your notes, etc.

There is no attendance control. If missing a class due to illness or other unexpected emergencies is unavoidable, no notification is required. However, it is your own responsibility to catch up on the content you missed. Throughout the rest of the thesis trajectory students are expected to be familiar with the content of the research clinic lectures.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Formulating a relevant and feasible problem definition and research question
• Positioning this research question in the wider academic literature within your research topic
• Articulating both academic and managerial contributions that the research, if successfully completed, is likely to add
• Outlining a conceptual model to be developed in full in the thesis
• Proposing a preliminary research design for testing this conceptual model empirically

column1: The research clinic (BMRSCMiM) supports the first steps of the thesis trajectory where the students develop their research proposals. It helps students see what it takes to go from an interesting research topic, to specifying a concrete research problem, decide on a research question, research strategy and method. Lectures and workshops during the research clinic will help to craft a research question, conduct the literature review, craft the introductory chapter and discuss methodological topics. Furthermore, the research clinic introduces the students to the specific possibilities of either qualitative research or specific quantitative methods for research in finance, depending on the students’ choice of research profile. It builds on the course Business Analytics.

• Being able to define a relevant research question in the current business context
• Provide a relevant and coherent overview of the most relevant literature
• Understand the managerial importance of the research question

column1: Net als andere universitaire masterstudies kent de parttime Master in Management als afsluitend onderdeel een afstudeerproject. Het primaire doel van het afstudeerproject is dat studenten de bekwaamheid ontwikkelen in het doen van wetenschappelijk onderzoek op een bedrijfskundig terrein. Daartoe onderzoeken studenten zelfstandig een bedrijfskundige probleemstelling waarbij het gehele proces van probleemformulering, theoretische ontwikkeling, methodologische verantwoording en onderbouwing, rapportering van empirische resultaten en bediscussiëring van onderzoeksimplicaties wordt doorlopen. Dit proces leidt tot een master thesis of afstudeerscriptie. De afstudeerscriptie is hiermee een individuele proeve van bekwaamheid in het zelfstandig opzetten en uitvoeren van een wetenschappelijk verantwoord bedrijfskundig onderzoek, van academisch denkniveau, en van intellectueel en analytisch vakmanschap.

Het afstudeeronderzoek geeft studenten de mogelijkheid zich te verdiepen in een specifiek onderwerp binnen een interessegebied. De interessegebieden vallen onder vijf thema’s die voortvloeien uit de vakken die eerder gevolgd zijn: HRM & Sustainability, Strategisch management & Innovatie, Marketing, Finance & Accounting, en Data analytics & Supply chain management, Bij het afstudeeronderzoek worden antwoorden gevonden op een van tevoren geformuleerde onderzoeksvraag binnen een van die thema’s teneinde kennis te produceren die niet alleen voor jezelf van belang is maar ook (juist) voor andere betrokkenen en belangstellenden waardevol is. Naast het ontwikkelen van meer begrip over een onderwerp en de bekwaamheid in het doen van academisch onderzoek, leidt het afstudeertraject ook tot de vaardigheid om studies en voorstellen te evalueren die voorbereid zijn door derden (bijv. consultants) en vaak dienen om managementbesluiten te nemen.

Het afstudeertraject bestaat uit twee onderdelen. Het begint met de Research Clinic (BMRSCMiM-P; 1 EC) waarin studenten een eerste research statement schrijven. Tijdens het schrijven van dit research statement ontwikkelen studenten de vaardigheid een onderwerp te identificeren dat ook methodologisch haalbaar is en een bijdrage aan inzicht levert. Dit research statement vormt het uitgangspunt waarmee de afstudeerscriptie (BMMTMiM-P; 16 EC) begonnen wordt.

In de Research Clinic worden studenten geholpen om te bepalen wat er zoal plaatsvindt in een bepaald vakgebied en waar eventueel onderzoek naar plaats kan vinden, en beginnen ze na te denken over een methodologische aanpak. Dit mondt uit in een research statement.

Het vakgebied wordt bepaald door de themakeuze. Het vinden van een scriptieonderwerp is een persoonlijke reis waarin studenten aandachtsgebieden binnen bedrijfskunde identificeren die hun interesse hebben.
In het pMiM programma kiezen studenten een voorkeur uit 5 bredere thema’s waarbinnen de scriptie geschreven wordt:

De voorkeurskeuze voor het thema is in oktober gemaakt. Aan de hand van de keuze worden studenten uiteindelijk ingedeeld bij een coach, die verdere begeleiding naar en op een meer afgebakend onderwerp binnen een van die thema’s zal verzorgen.

Alvorens de coach z'n intrede doet, begint het vak met een college begin december, waarin het afstudeertraject behandeld wordt en waarin studenten een verdere stap zetten naar het bepalen van een onderwerp. Daarnaast krijgen studenten een introductie in de methodologische aanpak. Bij de bepaling van een scriptieonderwerp en ontwikkeling van een onderzoeksvraag is het van belang vooruit te denken over de methodologische aanpak en haalbaarheid. Als onderdeel van dit vak worden in januari twee colleges verzorgd die ingaan op kwalitatief en kwantitatief onderzoek.

Tegen deze achtergrond zal een eerste research statement geschreven worden. Net als elk ander academisch onderzoek, kent een scriptie globaal 5 onderdelen: introductie, theoretische achtergrond, methodologie, resultaten en discussie & conclusie. Het research statement vormt als het ware een eerste versie van de introductie van de scriptie. In de introductie wordt het onderzoeksprobleem en de bijdrage aan academische inzichten uiteengezet, de onderzoeksvraag ontwikkeld, en een eerste aanzet voor de onderzoeksstrategie en -methode gegeven. Het research statement zal dienen als startpunt voor het onderzoeksvoorstel dat onderdeel uitmaakt van het afstudeerproject. Het research statement dient uiterlijk 31 januari ingeleverd te worden via Canvas, en wordt beoordeeld met een voldoende/onvoldoende (pass/fail).

column1: Research design refers to a series of interrelated decisions about the kinds of questions that can be answered empirically (and ethically); the theoretical and social justification for asking those questions; and the appropriate procedures for sampling, collecting, and analyzing data to answer them.

In this course, students strengthen their research design skills by developing a research project (proposal) of their own. They formulate scientifically sound research questions, place them in relation to existing literature, make and justify decisions related to data collection and analysis, data management and research ethics. By presenting and discussing their work in class, they also engage in peer review processes, sharing and receiving suggestions for and from their peers. Opportunities to scrutinize successful research (grant) proposals and to discuss with authors the ‘behind the scenes’ of specific research projects further sharpen students’ critical sensibility toward research design choices.

Seminar discussions pay special attention to the relationship between theory and research; alternative methodological approaches and styles/traditions of research within the social sciences, as well as the pros and cons of combining methods; personal involvement and/or bias; research ethics and data management. Practical constraints that affect research decisions are also considered.

The course is meant to advance and systematize previous knowledge and experience students already have in social scientific research in general. It prepares students for the more specialized methodological courses that follow

column1: <body data-gr-ext-installed="""" data-new-gr-c-s-check-loaded=""14.1068.0"">This course provides a general understanding of the basics of research design and writing of a research project, i.e., master’s thesis. It also offers practical guidance working with hands-on exercises based on different research cases covering quantitative and qualitative strategies across several subjects. The course focuses on how various elements of a proper research project should be developed, including:

column2: • Motivation - often referred to as problem statement[1].
• Research questions (and sub-research questions if applicable).
• Introduction to survey, case studies, secondary data (also desk research), and ethnography.
• Identification of appropriate data collection, variables, and analysis methods.

column1: The RD course, UDA1 & 2 complement each other. Within those courses, students learn and apply methodological skills that support them in completing their theses[1].

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course introduces the basics of social science research and offers a practical guide to developing a research framework. The learning objectives of the course are as follow:

column2: • Understand how to formulate a research question (and sub-research questions when applicable) based on an academically sound justification (i.e., problem statement).
• Recognize elements contained in a competent literature review.
• Identify the critical elements necessary for producing a sound conceptual framework.
• Recognize why research design choices are made in consideration of the research questions, data, and limitations.

• Understand the objectives and elements in the formulation of an empirical strategy for data and variables, i.e., the translation of concepts into indicators, and in presenting a clear explanation for methodological choices.
• Understand how to properly present and discuss analysis results.
• Explain how ethics are involved and can be addressed in social science research.

column1: Apply the elements above in the development of a master’s research project

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: You will learn what is necessary to move from a broad PhD topic to a researchable and relevant research question. After this module you can distinguish the academic relevance of your research from societal relevance.

You will learn: what the importance of a good literature review is and what the building blocks for making it are. You will understand the role of a theoretical framework and the differences between different types of frameworks, most importantly theoretical (in an empirical setting) and normative (in a legaldoctrinal setting).

You will understand the need to specify your overall methodology and the elements that determine the choice of specific methods (research question, approach, skills). Research Method seminars In this part of the course you will learn the basic principles of various research methods that are used in the research into legally relevant phenomena. During these seminars you will receive an explanation by several teachers about the specific method and how to apply it.
The following Research Method Seminars are offered in this course:

column2: • Empirical legal research (a basic part and an in-depth part)
• To introduce PhD students to the different methods of legal research.
• To create awareness about the possibilities of these methods for their project.
• To highlight the risks connected with each method.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course we will focus on one of the most important parts of academic life: the writing process. All experienced writers know that writing a paper, a chapter or even a book is never a straight march from the idea to a finished product. While writing you will likely go through many drafts, go into blind alleys, and even make new discoveries that may lead you to rethink your entire project. In the end, a lot of what is in your early rafts will not even make it into the final version. One of the most important skills you will learn during your PhD is working your way through this process of drafting, reviewing, rewriting, receiving and incorporating feedback and refining your work. In this course we will go through this process together. We will not only focus on writing itself, but also on giving and receiving feedback. In this course we will focus on 3 general steps that will help all researchers in their struggle towards a well-written and convincing product:

column2: • Strategy, how do you get started with writing and what should be included in your text.
• Inter-vision, how to read other peoples’ work and how to provide as well as receive feedback.
• Revising your work and incorporating any feedback.

column1: First you will write an abstract in which you briefly introduce your research, second you will write a first version of your introductory chapter, and finally you will write the revised and final full version of your chapter.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Big data is omnipresent in modern society and in conjunction with machine-learning techniques promises both new and deeper insights to address business research problems. Yet, even with big data, not all research questions are interesting, and not all models are appropriate.

This course, therefore, allows students to put their methodological knowledge to the test and verify first hand if they have what it takes to address business research questions that are of high academic and managerial relevance. It offers an important meta-learning experience, connecting all the teachings preceding the course and thought simultaneously. The assignment can be further developed into a research paper in year 2, during the Research Clinic, and during the second Research Hackathon where the second-year students can up their game, moving their work away from a student-assignment type of output and closer to a research publication.
In the second year, students will focus on their specific field of interest, improving their modelling approach and fine-tuning the business implications of their research findings.
For this course, students are expected to have prior experience with one or more high-level programming languages, such as R, Python, C++, and MATLAB. And to work with LISA.
Students are expected to bring their own laptop.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students should work on a specific research assignment. This assignment can be part of an ongoing, or recently started project of the academic supervisor: the student is not expected to be the principal investigator. Yet, the assignment must be demarcated clearly enough for the student to be able to make a significant contribution to the assignment and to conclude the RI within the time allowed for the given EC. During the RI, students will be stimulated to apply the knowledge and research skills they have already acquired, but will also be challenged to acquire new knowledge and research skills by working in close collaboration with the RI supervisor. The supervisor is expected to provide constructive feedback to the student throughout the RI period.

Note: The work of the internship cannot be reused for the thesis: The two products should be clearly distinct. It is however possible to collect and prepare data during the internship that can be used for the academic supervisor’s project, as well as for the student’s thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of the RI, students should a. have acquired further knowledge of the process of conducting research, developing an critical attitude and a systematic and rigorous way of working, b. have improved further their capacity to communicate about the process of conducting research with an academic both in writing and orally, c. have started developing the capacity to reflect upon their own learning.
The specific content of the first learning goal above (learning goal a.) depends on the type of the research internship the student chooses –there are three options:

1. Literature review: if students choose for an RI of the type ‘reviewing and synthetizing the literature’, they can build upon the knowledge and skills they have already been confronted with during the department seminars and business foundation course. Consequently, learning goal a. involves the following:
- Have gained knowledge of one specific research areas in business data science or management
- Have improved the ability to critically analyze and evaluate existing literature

- Have improved the ability to synthesize the existing literature and to integrate it to produce novel insights (i.e., in the form of original propositions supported by an integration of different ideas from the existing literature)

2. Data Acquisition and Preparation: if students choose for an internship of the type ‘Data Acquisition and preparation’, the RI builds upon the knowledge and skills they have acquired with the data science courses. Consequently, learning goal a. involves the following:
- Have gained hands-on knowledge and broad understanding of data science research methodology and its data requirements in business and management
- Have applied data science approaches to compile and prepare data in order to address relevant research questions in business and management
- Have improved the ability to produce replicable and well documented processes
- Have the ability to reflect on the ethical implications of the data acquisition and preparation

3. Programming/Data Analysis: if students choose for an internship of the type ‘programming/analyzing data’, the RI builds upon the knowledge and skills they have acquired with the data science courses. Consequently, learning goal a. involves the following:
- Have gained hands-on knowledge and broad understanding of programming/data science research methodology and its applications in business and management
- Have applied data science approaches to program/solve relevant research questions in business and management
- Have improved the ability to critically program/analyze data and evaluate methodological approaches and results
- Have the ability to reflect on the ethical and social implications of the outcome of their work
Combinations of these options or alternative trajectories are possible, and they should be approved by the RI coordinator.

- Have gained knowledge of one specific research areas in business data science or management
- Have improved the ability to critically analyze and evaluate existing literature

- Have improved the ability to synthesize the existing literature and to integrate it to produce novel insights (i.e., in the form of original propositions supported by an integration of different ideas from the existing literature)

2. Data Acquisition and Preparation: if students choose for an internship of the type ‘Data Acquisition and preparation’, the RI builds upon the knowledge and skills they have acquired with the data science courses. Consequently, learning goal a. involves the following:
- Have gained hands-on knowledge and broad understanding of data science research methodology and its data requirements in business and management
- Have applied data science approaches to compile and prepare data in order to address relevant research questions in business and management
- Have improved the ability to produce replicable and well documented processes
- Have the ability to reflect on the ethical implications of the data acquisition and preparation

3. Programming/Data Analysis: if students choose for an internship of the type ‘programming/analyzing data’, the RI builds upon the knowledge and skills they have acquired with the data science courses. Consequently, learning goal a. involves the following:
- Have gained hands-on knowledge and broad understanding of programming/data science research methodology and its applications in business and management
- Have applied data science approaches to program/solve relevant research questions in business and management
- Have improved the ability to critically program/analyze data and evaluate methodological approaches and results
- Have the ability to reflect on the ethical and social implications of the outcome of their work
Combinations of these options or alternative trajectories are possible, and they should be approved by the RI coordinator.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The RI position in Block 1 and 2 is to be considered one. The RI position of block 3 and 5 of year 1 can be extended to the RI position of Block 1 and 2 of year 2, but this is not compulsory. Although the RI is scheduled in block 3 and 5 of year 1, and block 1 and 2 of year 2, the RI may take place in another period, but only 1) if that is feasible and more desirable, and 2) if it is approved by the RI Coordinator.

Students should work on a specific research assignment. This assignment can be part of an ongoing, or recently started project of the academic supervisor: the student is not expected to be the principal investigator. Yet, the assignment must be demarcated clearly enough for the student to be able to make a significant contribution to the assignment and to conclude the RI within the time allowed for the given EC. During the RI, students will be stimulated to apply the knowledge and research skills they have already acquired, but will also be challenged to acquire new knowledge and research skills by working in close collaboration with the RI supervisor. The supervisor is expected to provide constructive feedback to the student throughout the RI period.

Note: The work of the internship cannot be reused for the thesis: The two products should be clearly distinct. It is however possible to collect and prepare data during the internship that can be used for the academic supervisor’s project, as well as for the student’s thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of the RI, students should a. have acquired further knowledge of the process of conducting research, developing an critical attitude and a systematic and rigorous way of working, b. have improved further their capacity to communicate about the process of conducting research with an academic both in writing and orally, c. have started developing the capacity to reflect upon their own learning.
The specific content of the first learning goal above (learning goal a.) depends on the type of the research internship the student chooses –there are three options:

1. Literature review: if students choose for an RI of the type ‘reviewing and synthetizing the literature’, they can build upon the knowledge and skills they have already been confronted with during the department seminars and business foundation course. Consequently, learning goal a. involves the following:
- Have gained knowledge of one specific research areas in business data science or management
- Have improved the ability to critically analyze and evaluate existing literature

- Have improved the ability to synthesize the existing literature and to integrate it to produce novel insights (i.e., in the form of original propositions supported by an integration of different ideas from the existing literature)

2. Data Acquisition and Preparation: if students choose for an internship of the type ‘Data Acquisition and preparation’, the RI builds upon the knowledge and skills they have acquired with the data science courses. Consequently, learning goal a. involves the following:
- Have gained hands-on knowledge and broad understanding of data science research methodology and its data requirements in business and management
- Have applied data science approaches to compile and prepare data in order to address relevant research questions in business and management
- Have improved the ability to produce replicable and well documented processes
- Have the ability to reflect on the ethical implications of the data acquisition and preparation

3. Programming/Data Analysis: if students choose for an internship of the type ‘programming/analyzing data’, the RI builds upon the knowledge and skills they have acquired with the data science courses. Consequently, learning goal a. involves the following:
- Have gained hands-on knowledge and broad understanding of programming/data science research methodology and its applications in business and management
- Have applied data science approaches to program/solve relevant research questions in business and management
- Have improved the ability to critically program/analyze data and evaluate methodological approaches and results
- Have the ability to reflect on the ethical and social implications of the outcome of their work
Combinations of these options or alternative trajectories are possible, and they should be approved by the RI coordinator.

column1: In het vak Research Lab – de Toepassing (dat loopt van blok 3 t/m 6) van de opleiding Criminologie komen vaardigheden die relevant zijn voor een criminoloog aan bod. Studenten ontwikkelen vaardigheden gerelateerd aan analyseren, argumenteren en juridiseren. Dit blok richt zich in vier modules op onderzoeksmethoden (bestaande uit kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve analyses), juridische analyse en (wetenschappelijke) schrijfvaardigheden. Deze gevorderde vaardigheden worden toegepast op een criminologisch relevant en blijvend actueel onderwerp: surveillance door de overheid. Dit zijn allemaal vaardigheden die van pas komen in de dagelijkse werkpraktijk van de criminoloog. De tijdens dit geschreven stukken en verzamelde data vormen de basis van het bacheloronderzoek, waarmee jullie de bachelor Criminologie afsluiten.

column1: This course prepares students for the thesis trajectory that starts in January. The course consists of plenary sessions that are a combination of lecture and workshop. The first two lectures regard general topics about research, research questions and literature review. After these two joint sessions, students join either a qualitative or a quantitative research track for which three/four sessions will follow. In these tracks students are taught a more specialized understanding of either qualitative or quantitative research.
Assessment is mixed and consists of an individual assignment and a team assignment.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Apply key phases of a qualitative or quantitative research project.
• Write a literature review that is conducive for writing the thesis.
• Systematically analyse qualitative or quantitative data via the application of the approaches learned in class.

column1: Research Methodology 1 & 2 will provide students with an understanding of the basics of qualitative and quantitative research methods, as well as the skills to design and implement sound research projects in the area of sustainability management. The overall aim of the course is to provide students with insights and skills to make informed choices regarding the research methodology to be used for their MSc thesis. The course is structured to coincide with work on the master thesis.

Research Methodology 1 is focused on research design and literature review. By taking this course, students will have the opportunity to find their research topic and formulate their research questions. Research Methodology 2 offers more specific knowledge on qualitative and quantitative methods.
Class attendance is not mandatory but strongly recommended.</body>

We will cover the following topics: research strategies and designs, sampling, common types of data collection methods (interviewing, surveys, and experiments), data analysis, writing, and research ethics.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: One of the primary reasons why organizations recruit university graduates lies in the students’ academic mindset and skills. This includes having a critical attitude towards what is presented as “the truth,” the ability to systematically assess the quality of research, and the competence to study a phenomenon in a structured way. These very attributes are required of you as you design and execute your Master thesis project. This course teaches you how to design your project, use the available literature, and collect and analyze data for empirical research. It follows the steps of research design, data collection, and data analysis. Furthermore, you will have the chance to go into depth for specific topics (methods and/or skills) that you will need for your own Master thesis, enabling you to tailor your academic journey to your unique requirements.

column2: • Lectures: not compulsory, but strongly recommended to attend (lectures will not be recorded)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Digital media have influenced empirical research. Using smart devices and experience sampling techniques we can capture “life as it is lived”.  Instead of taking a photo by a one-time questionnaire, we use repetitive measurements taking within person fluctuations into account. We try to meaningfully interpret the fluctuations over the measurement points (days, moments…). This implies that retrospective bias is reduced, but also that we can answer a different kind of research questions.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: • knows what experience sampling is and can reflect on potential advantages and side backs;
• understands what type of research questions can be answered by ESM studies;
• is capable to think of possible research questions and research designs in ESM;
• is able to analyze the results of an ESM study;
• is able to report the results in the format of an extensive abstract or poster presentation.
