column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het onderzoeksproject is een voorproef van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek. Door samen te werken in kleine onderzoeksgroepen, doorlopen de studenten de hele empirische cyclus volgens de standaarden van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek op basis van hypotheses. Het onderzoek begint met het formuleren van een probleemstelling en onderzoeksvraag, en een voorlopig theoretisch antwoord dat vervolgens methodisch verantwoord wordt getoetst. Twee onderzoeksmethoden worden toegepast: een kwantitatieve benadering die de hypotheses test en een kwalitatieve benadering, waarbij data en theorie elkaar versterken. In de conclusie wordt een duidelijk antwoord gegeven op de geformuleerde onderzoeksvraag en worden hypothesen bevestigd of weerlegd. Tot slot reflecteren studenten op de beperkingen van het onderzoek en hun bevindingen. Tijdens het onderzoeksproject voeren studenten opdrachten uit waarmee ze de empirische cyclus doorlopen. De beoordeling is gebaseerd op een schriftelijk onderzoeks-rapportage en een evaluatie van het groepswerk. De opdrachten in het vak vormen de basis voor dit onderzoeksrapport. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of this course, students will be able to..

column2: Conduct a full deductive empirical research cycle, according to the academic standards: including a relevant explanatory research question, a theoretical framework and conceptual model, empirical data, clear-cut conclusions and discussion;
Combine qualitative and quantitative empirical research methods following a mixed methods research approach;
Communicate the research (report and presentation) in a transparent, clear and well-argued manner;
Work together as a research team with fellow students.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113501,2023,Research Project,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. O Slivko', 'dr. R Cadario', 'dr. Y Zheng']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Research Project course is about learning how to conduct empirical research to solve business and societal problems. The course provides you both with hands-on experience on the main research methods and on acquiring the knowledge about the principles underlying these methods.

The design of the course covers all stages of the empirical cycle, in which a research problem is identified, relevant literature is explored, a research strategy is designed, qualitative and quantitative data are collected, processed, prepared and analysed, results of analysis are summarized in writing and presented in various ways in order to communicate the insights effectively and to further critical academic discussion.

During the course, students will work with different kinds of data, both qualitative and quantitative and stemming from different sources. Some data will be self-collected through qualitative interviews, surveys or online experiments. Other data may come from secondary (online) sources and will be downloaded for use in the project. Students will learn how to collect and (statistically) analyse these various kinds of data in order to answer research questions.

This course aims to enable you to approach managerial problems scientifically by learning how to: (1) understand what information is required to answer a question; (2) select the best method for obtaining the required information; (3) learn how to apply the different methods of data collection effectively; (4) apply statistical methods and draw appropriate conclusions from data; (5) engage in precise causal reasoning and understand the limits of data; (6) ethically and accurately communicate information and uncertainty.

Organizations base their strategies on information about the business environment and their main stakeholders such as consumers, industrial buyers, distributors, employees, competitors, suppliers and regulatory bodies. The Research Project course deals with how to collect and analyse this information. The presentation and discussion of results of empirical research are part of everyday life. Not only in discussions about or presentations for business, but also in newspapers about business-related phenomena, and in academic papers. Understanding the way these empirical results have come about and have entered the business, public or academic debate is important in order to be able to judge the validity of the argumentation and the scope of the findings. A thorough comprehension of the many choices that are inherently part of conducting research, the various assumptions that underlie the valid use of research techniques, and the many ways that findings can be presented and communicated, are key ingredients of a critical academic attitude. The Research Project will contribute to these skills.

The Research Project course covers block 5, 6 and 7 of the bachelor curriculum. It is jointly offered by the department of Marketing Management and the department of Technology and Operations Management. It builds on knowledge and skills obtained in Year 1 courses on Philosophy of Science, Marketing Management, Strategic Business Plan, Organizational Behaviour, Mathematics and Statistics.

The Research Project course contributes to the overall mission of the school to develop business leaders that can be a force of positive change, by providing the future leaders with the tools and knowledge of research. The course is aimed to make students understand the value of accurate information to solve business problems. It enables students to critically reflect on a business research problem, to evaluate how research findings from within or outside their organization help to (not) solve the problem, and to initiate research in domains where relevant business insight is missing. For the course assignments, a general theme or business or societal problem will be chosen that fits the mission of the School. For example, how to change consumer behaviours towards healthier or more sustainable choices.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: define a research problem, formulate a research question and develop research propositions, and understand what information is required to answer a question
learn how to make use of a literature study and exploratory research methods to gather insight into the topic of interest
learn how to develop interview protocols, conduct interviews, and process and present the results of these interviews

learn how to download online data from secondary sources or Internet, design stimuli and measures to collect data effectively, set up and conduct (online) surveys, design and conduct (online) surveys and experiments consistent with the research problem under study
understand, motivate and apply statistical techniques to analyse and report the collected quantitative data, and validly infer from these analyses

summarize research findings in well-thought out writing, present those findings in various presentation forms, and professionally give feedback about the merits and limitations of the research conducted by others.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het doel van Research Project is een verdere kennismaking met de sociologische onderzoekspraktijk. Centraal staat het zelfstandig verbinden van sociologische theorie en empirisch onderzoek. In groepen van gemiddeld 5 personen wordt aan het leeronderzoek gewerkt. Het onderzoek wordt begeleid door één van de docenten. Iedere groep verricht een kwantitatief onderzoek naar een vooraf gegeven probleemstelling die wordt beantwoord op basis van bestaande surveygegevens. Aan de hand van verschillende opdrachten wordt de probleemstelling uitgewerkt tot een onderzoekbaar conceptueel model. Op basis van secundaire survey-data wordt gerapporteerd over de operationalisering van de variabelen uit het conceptuele model en over de toetsing van de hypothesen. De opdrachten vormen de bouwstenen van een onderzoeksverslag dat de integrale verslaglegging van het verrichte onderzoek behelst (bestaande uit een theoretisch kader, de resultaten van de data-analyse en de inhoudelijke conclusies).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het eind van dit vak zijn studenten in staat zijn om zelfstandig de empirische cyclus van een kwantitatief onderzoek te doorlopen. Dit betekent meer concreet dat studenten na het af- ronden van dit vak:

column2: • een sociologisch relevante verklarende probleemstelling kunnen uitwerken;
• zelfstandig een literatuurstudie kunnen verrichten waarmee een zo goed mogelijk beredeneerd antwoord op de probleemstelling kan worden gegeven;
• een conceptueel model met daarbij behorende hypothesen kunnen opstellen;
• op een verantwoorde manier variabelen kunnen operationaliseren;
• vooropgestelde hypothesen kunnen toetsen met een regressieanalyse;
• helder en logisch kunnen rapporteren over hun onderzoeksresultaten.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113679,2023,Research Project,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. P Mascini'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het onderzoeksproject is een voorproef van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek. Door samen te werken in kleine onderzoeksgroepen, doorlopen de studenten de hele empirische cyclus volgens de standaarden van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek op basis van hypotheses. Het onderzoek begint met het formuleren van een probleemstelling en onderzoeksvraag, en een voorlopig theoretisch antwoord dat vervolgens methodisch verantwoord wordt getoetst. Twee onderzoeksmethoden worden toegepast: een kwantitatieve benadering die neerkomt op het toetsen van hypotheses en een kwalitatieve benadering, waarbij data en theorie op elkaar worden betrokken. In de conclusie wordt een duidelijk antwoord gegeven op de geformuleerde onderzoeksvraag en worden hypothesen bevestigd of weerlegd. Tot slot reflecteren studenten op de beperkingen van het onderzoek en hun bevindingen. Tijdens het onderzoeksproject voeren studenten opdrachten uit waarmee ze de empirische cyclus doorlopen. De beoordeling is gebaseerd op een schriftelijk onderzoeks-rapportage en een evaluatie van het groepswerk. De opdrachten in het vak vormen de basis voor dit onderzoeksrapport. </body>

column1: In this course you will apply your knowledge from Introduction to Econometrics and Academic Skills to write two reports which will resemble research articles. You will analyze data in Stata and interpret your findings. Homework 1 is an individual assignment, all other assignments are with the same group of four students, which will be formed during (not before) the course. You will not need to register for a (tutorial) group before the course.
1. The structure of a research paper;
4. interpreting regression results, including p-values and confidence intervals;
5. understanding bias using the potential outcomes framework;
6. how to use uni- and multivariate regression to make predictions;
7. why non-experimental data typically do not yield consistent estimators of causal effects;
8. the internal and external validity of experimental results based on randomized treatmen assignment;
9. logit average marginal effects and the linear probability model;
10. interpretation of the coefficients of dummy variables and interaction terms;
Timeline of the learning activities in the previous academic year (this may deviate in the next academic year):

Week 1: Lecture 1 gives general information about the course; register for feedback session 1; study the introduction and chapter 1 of the book Mastering Metrics and the introduction of an article about equality of opportunity; study materials in introductory quizzes on the subject of the regular assignment and econometrics; look ahead to homework 1 and if preferred take the optional quiz which explains Stata commands.

Week 2: Study materials in two additional quizzes on cross section econometrics (the Quiz on Lecture 2 and the Quiz on Econometrics); submit homework 1 and discuss questions with the RP team during the workshop.
Week 3: Attend feedback session 1 to discuss homework 1.
Week 4: Discuss questions on the regular assignment with the RP team during the workshop; submit regular assignment report by the end of this week.
Week 5: Submit creative assignment research proposal (same group of 4 students) and discuss this during feedback session 2. Lecture 3 will be on time series econometrics.
Week 6: Submit homework 2 (same group of 4 students) on time series econometrics.

Week 7: Learn from mistakes in the regular assignment report during the inspection session; ask questions on the creative assignment during the workshop; submit creative assignment report; submit slides for the oral defense.

column1: ​The Research Methods in Finance course gives students the opportunity to acquire the statistical and econometric skills needed to work with data, conduct an empirical analysis, interpret and report the results in the context of an academic paper or thesis. These skills are essential for the successful completion of the Master Thesis. Students will attend lectures and workshop sessions, will work with Stata (and Excel) and have to complete an empirical assignment.

For the assignment, students can choose between two tracks: Corporate Finance or Investments. Otherwise, the two tracks are identical. The skills students train are the same (e.g., processing data, implementing empirical methods using statistical software, and interpreting results), and so is the exam. </body>

Importantly, students should understand the main econometric methods used in finance and apply these to answer research questions.</body>

column1: <body>During the research traineeship in the first year of the Research master's programme, students participate in one of the Faculty's research projects or in an external research project which is led by a Faculty member or in which a Faculty Member is involved as an advisor. The traineeship results in (a substantial contribution to) a research paper or research report and familiarizes students with some of the most vital research activities: developing a research project, writing a research proposal, doing the actual research and data analysis, and presenting research findings in the form of a research paper or research report and an oral presentation. In principle, the research subject should fit within the fields that are covered in the research master's and it should fit within the Faculty's current research projects and research interests. In order to guarantee the suitability and quality of the supervision and the traineeship, a concise research traineeship proposal should be submitted to the Programme directors who need to approve of the chosen subject and content of the traineeship before the start of the traineeship. A research traineeship includes at least the following components:

column2: • Contribution to research report or research paper
• Attendance and active participation in presentations by fellow students.

column1: The course Research training I deals with common univariate statistical methods and techniques in an applied empirical context. The course gives a start to independent assessment and application of of elementary quantitative empirical research. It has a theoretical part (the online modules with corresponding material), which emphasizes the theory of statistical methods and techniques, and an applied part, which considers the application of these methods and techniques with the statistical software program R.

Results of statistical research are routinely found in various presentations, journal articles and reports. As a consequence, it is essential for managers to have the knowledge to be aware of the assumptions and analyses on which these results are based and to be able to judge the manner in which these results are interpreted.

Below summarizes the topics covered in the four modules of this course. These topics are introduced in the videos about the theory and are practiced in the tutorials about the use of the statistical software R.
1 Elements of statistical research, choices of methods and techniques, measurement levels and role of models
2 Sample and population, sampling methods, descriptive analysis statistical estimation

The course has four weeks during which the material is explained. Use is made of pre-recorded online videos for both the theory and the tutorials. In addition, an online platform will be used to make exercises. A recent version of the time table is available via timetables.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The objective of the course is that participants:
(1) gain insights into the theoretical background of statistical methods and techniques; and
(2) develop practical skills in applying statistical methods and techniques.
More specifically, the learning goals are stated as the ability to:
* Explain and reproduce elementary methodological parts of statistical research, like sampling methods and modelling;
* Visualize assumptions about empirical processes by means of a causal diagram;
* Apply univariate statistical methods and techniques in well-defined problems;
* Apply univariate statistical methods and techniques in a programming environment.</body>

It has a theoretical part (the online modules with corresponding material), which emphasizes the theory of statistical methods and techniques, and an applied part, which considers the application of these methods and techniques with the statistical software program R.

Results of statistical research are routinely found in various presentations, journal articles and reports. As a consequence, it is essential for managers to have the knowledge to be aware of the assumptions and analyses on which these results are based and to be able to judge the manner in which these results are interpreted.
There are no specific entry requirements. But it is important to be aware that the material builds on Research Training I.

<body>This research workshop introduces students to the main issues concerned with doing cross-national comparative research in communication and media, while it also offers them advanced training in writing a comprehensive literature review on a research topic of their own choosing. It is a practical course that introduces students to a number of important steps in the choices to make when carrying out cross-national and/or comparative research.</body>

• Write a clear and balanced literature review as a team, presenting the state of knowledge regarding their chosen cross-national and comparative research topic;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will provide students an understanding of management in the cultural sector. The starting point of view is that cultural organizations such as museums, venues, musical societies, theatre companies, and other creative enterprises possess particular characteristics from an organizational point-of- view that influence the way they operate. Cultural/arts management has developed as a full-fledged discipline. Cultural organizations increasingly need to develop management strategies to realize their objectives, paying attention to their potential visitors-audiences-users, and to the financial constraints that may hinder their activities. The cases selected by the students will be used to study and illustrate the impact that strategic management can have on the performance of cultural institutions. Students will have to apply the theoretical framework to cultural organizations in order to see how theory translates into reality.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This research workshop will familiarize students with the management of cultural organizations by case study research methods. They learn to connect theory to practice by conducting their own small research project about an existing cultural organization.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114637,2023,Research Workshop: Media, Culture & Tourism",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: From Hobbiton to Graceland to 221b Baker Street, media- and cultural tourism – visiting places in the wake of popular culture & heritage – is a growing industry. While connected to traditional forms of sightseeing, media- and cultural tourism raises different questions about the relationship between the mass media, its audiences, and physical places. What are tourists looking for? How are these attractions marketed and managed? And what about the locals, who see their home suddenly becoming a ‘fictional’ location swarming with tourists? What does the increased prominence of this kind of tourism say about the relationship between imagination and reality in an era characterized by an increasing omnipresence of the media and global mobility? These are the sort of questions asked in this course. Students will explore different aspects of media- and cultural tourism, from its origins and history, its connection to other parts of the tourism industry, its relationships to audience- and fan-practices, managerial aspects, and tourist experiences in order to foster a sophisticated understanding of this multifaceted phenomenon. Starting from this, students will create their own small research project on an aspect of media- or cultural tourism that interests them. Students will use research techniques and methodology from cultural studies and qualitative sociology, hence it is advised to be familiar with these before partaking the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This research workshop will introduce students to the key issues in media- and cultural tourism: that is, tourism inspired by (popular) media, such as films, TV-series, music, literature and video-games. Students will be able to identify the current themes and challenges to orient themselves within the ongoing academic debates surrounding media- and cultural tourism. Students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in academic publications. Students will extend this knowledge through conducting a small-scale qualitative research through hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data, developing a research design and reporting on their findings.

column1: The Research & Writing Skills course has the objective of developing practical skills in doing legal research and in writing legal texts. The course will assist students with developing expertise in three different legal methods, namely classical black letter law research, comparative law research and legal research design. Law and Ethics will be part of courses in block 2 to combine substantive and social aspects of law at the same time. The skills of the course of Research and Writing Skills will be trained through writing papers, oral presentations and group discussions.

All topics you will be studying relate to commercial law, with a further focus on questions relating to the master variation you have chosen. This way, the course not only introduces you to legal research, improving skills necessary for the remaining of the course as well as your legal career, but also introduces you to the exciting field of commercial law, which will be explored for the rest of the year.

During the Research & Writing Skills course you will be confronted with many practical and legal issues from recent years. Common to these issues is the international nature and complexity of the legal relations involved. In order to find sound and workable solutions to these problems, you must learn to determine the relevant international standard(s) applicable. Where no uniform international standard exists, a comparative legal approach may be necessary to determine the main schools of thought about certain issues adopted by different legal systems.

The internal moot case plays a central role in the Research & Writing Skills course curriculum. It means that (almost) all of the assignments are linked to this case and constitute important building blocks that you use, structuring your argumentation for instance when drafting a legal memorandum (it will be explained further in a section with the assignments’ overview). For example, the comparative law assignment concerns force majeure, which is a relevant legal concept used in the moot case. Case reports that are discussed during the workgroup sessions are also useful authorities that can be used to support legal argumentation during the internal moot.

Each week you will face more and more challenging legal concepts, which will be based on (building on) the knowledge already acquired from the previous sessions. It means that the course requires your full attention.

Dear Exchange Students, Research and Writing Skills courses designed for different variations of Commercial Law LL.M. (RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84) offer an intensive small group teaching and training. These courses are taught by the same teachers, have a very similar structure and will allow you to acquire the same set of skills. Please bear in mind, however, that in case when the limited capacity of the chosen track is reached, we might be forced to assign you to another Research and Writing Skills variation of Commercial Law LL.M. (thus another course from those available under these codes RB30, RR39, RB73, RR84).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

After this course the student should have an ease of using the following research and writing skills both while working independently but also when collaborating with others.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The substantive theme of this course focuses on European Union (EU) and international law and in particular on the interactions between these legal orders, with significant attention devoted to processes of economic integration. During the course, students will acquire active working knowledge of essential international and EU law principles, rules, institutions and decision-making processes. Students will be given the opportunity to practice their research, writing and presentation skills by considering some of the following broad themes: the evolution of the international and EU legal orders; the roles of various international and EU actors and the interplay between them; the mechanisms for and intricacies of decision-making in a multilevel context; market integration within the EU and economic cooperation on the international plane; the role of courts and compliance bodies in international and EU law, etc. Throughout the course students will be invited to consider also the socio-economic and political context in which international and EU law instruments and actors operate. Furthermore, they will consider how international and EU law may impact societal values related to the rule of law democracy, human rights and the protection of the environment. This also entails taking into consideration ethical concerns in the development and application of EU and international law.

During the course students will practice both substantive knowledge and legal skills in a ‘learn by doing’ fashion through various individual and group assignments. Class interactions and group discussions will play a key role in stimulating the learning process. Students will develop their research, writing and presentation skills by analyzing relevant legal developments and by placing these developments in the critical context offered by academic literature. By combining substantive knowledge with academic skills students will develop their own critical analysis of the role law plays at EU and international levels. In order to develop these skills, several sessions will be devoted to both research methodology and different legal methods (e.g. case analysis, comparative legal research). Students are also encouraged to examine the relevance of other disciplines, such as economics, political science, public administration, ethics and sociology, for a better understanding of the context and dynamics of the European and international legal orders.

The legal skills acquired and developed during this course will prepare students for the subsequent courses of the master programme, in which active academic learning is key. Moreover, students will be developing a solid basis for enhancing their knowledge and ability to work with EU and international law. In essence, this course provides students with transferable knowledge and skills, including the capacity to identify complex legal problems and develop solutions thereto, research a given legal topic, frame a research question, work with large volumes of legal information and select relevant legal sources, conduct rigorous legal analysis, synthesize their findings in a well-structured and written paper, and orally present their findings. These skills are essential for the successful completion of the IEUL master, including the finalization of the master thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course students explore the legal dimensions of cooperation at the level of the European Union and at the international level. This course gives a foretaste of topics, which will be revisited and dealt with in greater depth during subsequent courses of the IEUL master programme. This course serves a dual purpose: (1) it provides a general introduction to public international and EU law at master level studies and (2) it provides training for the acquisition and development of legal research, writing and presentation skills.
More specifically this course will enable you to:

column2: • Conduct research on a specific legal topic and write down concisely and clearly the results of your research
• Identify, understand and analyze, including by way of comparative analysis, relevant legal questions pertaining to International and EU law

• Becoming aware of the multifarious effects, dynamics, and interconnectedness of legal institutions of International and European Union law, including by considering insights from other disciplines, such as political science, ethics and economics
• Find, analyze and assess primary and secondary International and EU legal sources for the purpose of answering legal questions
• Develop critical legal thinking and reasoning in applying International and EU law
• Present your work in a clear and structured manner to a legal and non-legal audience
• Collaborating with others, especially through team work and engaging in a mutual peer review process

• Reflect on your own learning process by assessing your progress/needs and by identifying ways to improve your legal skills (including soft skills) and subject-matter knowledge in International and EU law

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The research fundamentals course is designed to support the individual master thesis project. The course focuses on the various thesis research methodologies that are available for thesis research, and on the more practical skills to carry out the thesis project. The most important methodologies for thesis research on innovation management are qualitative research (case studies and grounded theory) and quantitative research (surveys and archival data analyses, and experiments). The more practical skills address how to collect data and how to conduct analyses.

The course main components are the Research Fundamentals I & II courses. Research Fundamentals I comprises a set of introductory sessions. The goal of these sessions is to discuss the basic concepts of research and for students to get a better understanding of how to design a research project. Students will work on topics that go from developing a research question to making a preliminary selection of a research method for their study. Research Fundamentals II comprises group sessions and workshops, divided into two modules: qualitative and quantitative research. These two modules are taught by different instructors, who specialize in their specific research methodology. These sessions will provide students with in-depth knowledge and skills that can be immediately applied on their own thesis. Students need to register for the research method session that they aim to use for their own thesis. Students should decide on the methodology by consulting with her/his thesis coach and co-reader.

Importantly, this course requires students to be granted a “pass” on all the assignments. Failing to comply with this requirement will cause students to fail the course. Students can go for the re-sit of the course. Such a re-sit will be treated as an official re-sit and will carry the consequences of that of any other course in the program (e.g. may deter the student from getting a Cum Laude distinction). Furthermore, failing the course and the re-sit will impede the student in graduating during the current academic year.

This course works according to the flipped classroom principle, which means that the student needs to prepare before class based on the suggested material uploaded on Canvas. The sessions are used for interactive feedback, gamification, and in-class discussion, to deepen the student’s knowledge of the methodology and to provide specific feedback on her/his work. Meanwhile, through the assignments, the student will work on the thesis proposal, integrating what has been learnt throughout this course.
The place of this course in the Management of Innovation master

This course is meant to support the research activities leading to the Master thesis. It represents the opportunity for students to learn about important conceptual and methodological aspects of the research process with the focus on management of innovation topics. The contents and activities of the course focus on specific approaches that researchers can leverage to develop independent research initiatives that are valuable to theory and practice in the management of innovation field.

Similarly, to traditional content courses in the Masters, the Research Fundamentals course is based on a learning by doing approach. The planning and execution of the activities leading to the completion of the Master thesis will allow students to develop the knowledge, skills and attitudes required to become autonomous researchers. Assignments will be implemented with examples of some of the approaches that academics have used to develop different research products. The Research Fundamentals course is designed to support the intended learning outcomes (ILOs) of the Master program.

Attendance is mandatory for all students. Students may be excused for a maximum of one session (e.g., for an interview or due to sickness) without repercussions. Failing to attend any additional session requires notifying the teaching assistant of the course prior to the beginning of that session. Regardless of the underlying cause, students must deliver one additional assignment to compensate for each of the sessions that they did not attend. Students must submit the additional assignments following the course guidelines, failing to do so will cause the student to fail the course. Students experiencing long-term personal circumstances (e.g., chronic illness, serious first-degree family circumstances, top sport status, etc.) that affect their attendance and, more generally, their study progress must contact RSM MSc. student advisers to discuss their study planning and progress.

• To make the distinction between qualitative and quantitative methodologies in studies of Innovation Management
• To select a methodology for answering the research question of their thesis
• To plan the research activities necessary to develop a thesis in the area of Innovation Management

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course will give an overview of key research designs and approaches used in behavior change research, including quantitative, qualitative and mixed-methods approaches, and critical appraisal techniques. The focus is on how to address dilemmas in everyday research practice with a special attention on scientific integrity, validity, and reproducibility. Students are stimulated to develop 1) an understanding of the research process involved in the evaluation of behavior change interventions along all phases of design and implementation, and 2) a creative, yet pragmatic scientific thinking. The course will prepare students with the knowledge and skills to carry out research projects, such as their MSc thesis.

The overarching goal of this course is twofold: provide students with a set of research principles, guidelines, tools, and skills necessary to design an empirical research project and promote a critical understanding of methodological, ethical and pragmatic issues in the development and implementation of behavior change interventions. The course aims to introduce the fundamental ingredients of the research process for behavior change interventions, which are not exclusive to the “digital” context but are transversal to any type of complex behavioral intervention.

• Apply the basics of thematic analysis of qualitative data
• Design a detailed (mock) research proposal for the evaluation of a behavior change intervention by:

column3: • Conceptualizing relevant and testable research question(s) and related hypotheses, and explain the background rationale
• Selecting appropriate research designs and methods to address the targeted research question(s)
• Detailing all key aspects of the study methodology in relation to the study goals and scientific reproducibility and open science principles

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will first be introduced in the field of cultural tourism, as an increasingly important subfield or niche of tourism in general. Cultural tourism has a long history, with roots reaching back to the Grand Tour in the 18th Century. Since then cultural tourism has been booming. Due in part to globalisation and postmodernism the character of concepts such as 'culture' and 'local identity' has become more fluid, with changing meanings to different groups in society. The ways in which tourism, visual culture and local identity are intertwining is the central theme and starting point of this research seminar. Next to that, several important qualitative research methodologies will be touched upon, familiarizing students with doing qualitative research towards cultural tourism by means of content analysis, participant observation, in-depth interviewing and ‘netnography’, amongst others. After this, students will be sent out into the field, explore how issues related to cultural tourism are acquiring significance in practice and engage hands-on in applying their methodological as well as theoretical knowledge in this field to engage with a small-scale empirical research project in line with their own interests.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will be made familiar with a wide range of qualitative research methods, which will prepare them for conducting an independent research towards the way(s) in which place, culture and tourism intertwine and intersect in empirical reality. In order to do so, students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in the field of cultural tourism in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in publications. Following this, students will apply their knowledge in a small-scale qualitative research, developing a research design and acquiring hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data in addition to presenting findings amidst peers.

column1: Responsible Business Leadership (BT2101) is a course organized by the department of Business-Society Management, and examines business in an increasingly global world, where organizations operate in a complex natural, social and economic environment. Corporations are expected to act responsibly toward various stakeholders, such as governments, competitors, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs), shareholders, suppliers and employees, to do the morally right thing, and to foster sustainable development. These high expectations can be challenging, yet they also create business opportunities. In particular, business plays a pivotal role in realizing the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals by creating not only economic value, but also ecological and social value.

Responsible Business Leadership is meant to be a provocative course, living up to RSM’s mission to be a force for positive change in the world by addressing the role of business and business leaders in both locally and globally relevant problems, such as inequality, corruption and climate change. While business is often a part of these problems, we examine how it can also be part of the solution. You are therefore encouraged to think about how business can create value not just specifically for shareholders, but also for other stakeholders, including society in general.

After introducing the Sustainable Development Goals as an overarching framework in Lecture 1, we will give in Lecture 2 and 3 a broad introduction to the central concepts of Sustainability—which is key in Workshop 1—and Responsibility. Lectures 4 and 5, which are central to Workshop 2, subsequently examine how sustainability and responsibility allow companies to go beyond business-as-usual in more specific domains such as strategy and entrepreneurship, as well as how this helps to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. Lecture 6 introduces the third central concept of this course, Ethics, to which Workshop 3 will subsequently be devoted.

The three workshops that are intermixed with these six lectures focus, respectively, on sustainability leadership, formulating a proposal for a corporate responsibility strategy and discussing managerial moral dilemmas with other students. These workshops thus make the course material more directly relevant to you, by linking it to your personal development and awareness of sustainable challenges.
To help you further engage with the course material, supplementary video materials and animations will be made available. Finally, after six lectures, there will be an essay assignment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Explain the roles that companies play in the creation of and finding solutions for local and global sustainability issues, including corruption, climate change and inequality.

Apply concepts and theories relevant to how organizations can and should contribute to solving these issues through the way they organize themselves internally and the way they interact with external stakeholders.
Defend your own standpoint on how companies can contribute to solving these sustainability issues.
Create a plan on how to contribute to solving these issues.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116507,2023,Responsible Innovation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,[],,"Inhoud

The minor Responsible Innovation is a unique collaboration between Leiden University, Delft University of Technology and Erasmus University Rotterdam. The programme offers in-depth insight into how responsible innovation can be accomplished and promoted. During this minor you will be introduced to the technical, managerial and socio-economic principles that govern innovation, and discuss ethical and other conditions for innovating responsibly. You will learn how responsible innovation can be defined and analysed; how it can be done and managed at the level of a project team, of a company and of an entire economic system; and how responsible innovation can be promoted and irresponsible innovation avoided.

In this minor, we combine the unique knowledge and skills of TU Delft, Leiden and Erasmus Rotterdam. The students and teachers come from the different universities, and bring with them their own focus, expertise and perspectives. Education takes place at several locations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Retail continues to be an important part of national economies. Retail operations refers to “all activities involved in the selling of physical* goods to ultimate customers for personal or household consumption.” We start this elective course in the third year of the bachelor programme with an overview of the most important retail operations activities in the retail supply chain. Next, we detail the activities in the backend, including distribution and fulfilment (warehousing, transport). We move on to the consumer facing part of retail operations, including assortment planning, inventory control, and returns handling. We discuss how first online, and more recently omnichannel, business models have affected consumer behaviour and operational processes along the retail supply chain. We will zoom in on the changing role of stores in retail and the need for sustainability in retail. We end with an overview of the most promising new technologies (e.g., AI, Internet-of-Things) introduced in retailing, how they allow us to better measure consumer behaviour and track operational performance. Finally, we discuss how retail analytics can be used to derive actionable insights from existing and new data sources. Retail operations challenges are increasingly on the interface of operations, marketing, and information systems. We therefore take a multi-disciplinary perspective in this course.
* We do not consider services in this course, but we will touch upon the notion of servitization (offering services around a product).

Both instructors of the course, Robert Rooderkerk (coordinator and lecturer) and René de Koster (lecturer) are members of the Supply Chain Management (SCM) section of the Department of Technology and Operations Management. Robert Rooderkerk is Associate Professor of Operations Management. His research addresses retail operations challenges on the marketing-operations interface with a focus on omnichannel retail and retail analytics. He is particularly interested in research questions related to assortment, product lines, and fulfilment. He is interested in both empirical and conceptual research. His empirical work integrates insights from psychology and consumer behaviour with techniques from econometrics and operations research. His conceptual work focuses on how new technologies, data sources, advanced analytics, and business models are reshaping the global retail landscape. René de Koster is a professor of logistics and operations management and head of the Department of Technology and Operations Management. His research interests include warehousing, material handling, container terminal operations, behav-ioural operations and sustainable logistics.

5. Displaying an analytical mindset when it comes to dealing with operational challenges in retail supply chains; being able to factor in interdependencies between different actors in the supply chains and firm functions. (ILO 4, ILO 9)

column1: What is the use of history? Who determines the scientific character of historical knowledge? How can we be sure about historical evidence? Are the activities of truth committees in a society different from the work of professional historians? Providing answers to these questions is not simple, but it is very important to discuss and learn more about the intellectual and social relevance of history.

In this course, 'Rethinking History I', we reflect on the fundamentals of the scientific pursuit of history and the relevance of historical knowledge for society. You will be introduced to the basics of the historical discipline that are necessary to follow the courses in the History Bachelor. Based on primary source fragments and secondary scientific literature we will discuss the meanings of the term history related to historical consciousness, the infrastructure of the historical discipline, historical truth, fact and fiction, scientific integrity, history and identity, and the moral values of history.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114693,2023,Rethinking History 2,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. SK Manickam', 'N Sikkema', 'R van Velzen, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course further elaborates the theoretical issues related to historical scholarship discussed in Rethinking History 1. It does so by studying key issues and currents in the philosophy of the  humanities in general and in the philosophy of history (the philosophical reflection on the nature and study of history) in particular.

In our treatment of the philosophy of history, we will study both the 'speculative' philosophy of history and the 'critical' philosophy of history. While speculative philosophers such as Hegel and Spengler pondered over the grand schemes of history, 'critical' schools of thought, such as positivism, hermeneutics and post-modernism raised various questions about the extent to which we can know, study or represent the past. What is the meaning of history and what is the nature of historical truth? How can we justify historical explanations? To what extent can we understand the intentions of historical actors? Is historical objectivity desirable or even possible? How do historical narratives represent the past and what are the limits of historical representation?
This course will strongly challenge the purported truths of historical scholarship.</body>

column1: This course reflects on world history from the perspective of various revolutionary moments that have shaped, or are perceived in hindsight to have shaped, the historical trajectories of human civilisations and societies, and have influenced how we live our daily lives today. Reading materials will delve into the concept of ‘revolution’ and look into key moments throughout world history and across geographical regions through the lenses of various technological, scientific, political and/or social revolutions. Topics include, but are not limited to, the shift from oral- to literate cultures, the rise of agricultural societies, the emergence of cities and trade, the professionalisation of armies, technologies of planetary exploration and Empire building. Reading materials are selected from multiple disciplines, including global history, anthropology and philosophy.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course discusses the recent global transformations in urban life. The rise of global cities since the 1970s was accompanied by a major increase in the urban population. More than half of the world population is living in cities after 2000, but the majority of these people does no longer live in rich centres, but in the poor slums of the urban periphery. The classical Weberian picture of the city as a place of freedom and development has been turned upside-down by these developments. Cities across the world are still centres of economic growth, but they face problems such as growing inequality, poverty, violence, pollution and rising sea levels. Students learn how a combination of socio-scientific and historical methods can help to analyse these challenges.

This course uses Saskia Sassen’s concept of the global city as a starting point for a critical discussion of the current trends in urbanisation. Students discuss major texts in the field of global urbanisation during the weekly meetings and they will discuss the impact of historical changes on city life in different parts of the world. The other half of the meetings will be used to explain students how they can use developments in the digital humanities to study urban life in globalised cities. Several methodologies will be discussed including the use of online quantitative databases, data mining, social network analysis and GIS.

• Students can analyse the challenges of globalised cities from a historical perspective in different parts of the world

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/116676,2023,Risk Management and Fixed Income,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. J Koeter'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Financial risk management is of the utmost importance for institutional investors, both from the regulatory and fiduciary perspective. In this course, the Vestia case is discussed in-depth as it is a prime example that highlights the importance of an effective risk management strategy. Vestia is a The Hague and Rotterdam-based social housing corporation, and it turned out to be one of the largest public sector scandals in the history of the Netherlands. In 2011, Vestia suffered very large losses on its interest rate derivatives portfolio and experienced serious liquidity problems in the aftermath.

In this course, the theoretical concepts are discussed in order for the students the fully understand the flaws in the risk management strategy of Vestia.  The main sources of financial risk are discussed, such as: market risk, liquidity risk, credit risk and operational risk. Approaches to quantify each of these risks (e.g. duration, VaR, ES, etc.)  as well as the various approaches to manage these risks are explored. The course explores the market for fixed income securities which were at the center of the Vestia case, and these are instruments with direct exposure towards market risk (interest rate risk) and credit risk. The market for fixed income securities is one of the most important asset classes in financial markets. Several topics in relation to this market are discussed: Fixed-rate bonds, inflation-linked bonds, the term structure of interest rates, duration/convexity, asset backed securities, and regulatory capital. Furthermore, particular attention is paid to hedge risks associated to which fixed income assets have exposure, using instruments such as credit default swaps or interest rate swaps.
Mandatory attendance of the guest lecture. In case you cannot attend, the student is expected to an additional assignment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Recommend an effective risk management strategy for financial institutions (such as Vestia) with an exposure towards several sources of financial risk

• Analyze the exposure of an investment portfolio towards financial risks, and be able to quantify this risk exposure using various techniques, such as: Value-at-Risk (VaR), Expected Shortfall (ES), and Duration
• Understand the markets for interest rate swaps and credit default swaps and be able to explain how to utilize these instruments to manage interest rate risk and credit risk
• Evaluate the exposure of a cash flow towards interest rates using the concepts of duration and convexity, and understand its shortcomings

• Understand the main sources of financial risks, such as market risk, liquidity risk, credit risk, and operational risk, and be able to analyze the importance of these risks for fixed income securities

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/113406,2023,Risk and Rationality,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. PP Wakker'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: R&R presents the behavioral approach (2017 Nobel-awarded) to economics in depth-Micro IV did it broadly-by focusing on risk/ambiguity and prospect theory (2002 Nobel awarded). Empirical psychological realism is introduced for economic agents, used in nudging and requiring new formal models.

Risk and uncertainty are central in many fields: insurance, game theory, health economics, game theory, business, finance. Psychologists have discovered many irrationalities in human behavior. Kahneman & Tversky (1979) introduced prospect theory, integrating empirical psychological findings with economic models. It was the first rational model of irrational behavior, so to say, something considered impossible up to that point. This opened the door to nudging techniques.

For each participant, the risk and ambiguity (unknown probabilities) attitudes will be measured, and the best-fitting models will be determined. Financial advices will be given, based on theoretical foundations, such as, in general: do not insure low-cost risks such as bike-theft; (b) invest pension-savings in stocks and not in bonds. Characteristic of the behavioral approach: formal models are used to describe “soft” phenomena. Whereas Micro IV gave a broad presentation of behavioral economics, this course focuses on risk and uncertainty, thus showing how the behavioral approach works in depth. Summarizing, this course shows how to incorporate irrational psychological behavior into economic models. At the end of the course, participants will be able to apply empirically realistic models to economic problems and to nudge other people into more rational decisions.
Students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and communicate
Learning Goal 1: Get a deep understanding of behavioral economics, i.e., how to incorporate psychological realism (reckoning with irrationalities) in theoretically proper manners.
Learning Goal 2: Improving normative and empirical work by incorporating psychological realism
Learning Goal 3: Use the difference between normative and empirical models to improve human decisions

column1: Financiële ondernemingen opereren in een sterk juridische omgeving. De diensten die zij verlenen en de producten die zij aanbieden zijn in de regel onderworpen aan een streng en complex regulerings-, toezichts- en handhavingsregime. Financiële ondernemingen lopen het risico bestuurs(straf)rechtelijke sanctie opgelegd te krijgen door de toezichthouder. Ook kunnen financiële ondernemingen civielrechtelijk worden aangesproken. Daarnaast is het mogelijk dat een financiële onderneming en haar leidinggevenden worden vervolgd op strafrechtelijke gronden. Deze juridische risico’s kunnen zeer aanzienlijke reputatieschade ten gevolge hebben.

In dit vak komen verschillende soorten procedures aan de orde waarin financiële ondernemingen kunnen worden betrokken. Hierbij wordt tevens aandacht besteed aan de fase die aan een procedure voorafgaat, waarbij afwegingen kunnen spelen in de context van risico- en reputatiemanagement.

Als onderdeel van het vak werken de studenten aan een casus die met externe stakeholders uit de praktijk, namelijk advocaten en accountants van gerenommeerde kantoren, is ontwikkeld. De studenten maken in groepjes een advies voor een van de partijen bij deze casus, waarna de studenten namens deze partijen schriftelijke en mondelinge argumenten bepleiten in het kader van een procedure voor een oefenrechtbank.

Mede vanwege deze brede benadering is ervoor gekozen in de titelaanduiding van dit vak niet het Nederlandse woord ‘procederen’ te gebruiken, maar het Engelse woord ‘litigation’. In lijn met deze keuze heet het vak de titel Risk, Reputation & Litigation. De literatuur en alle colleges zijn overigens goeddeels Nederlandstalig.
Dit vak is niet alleen geschikt voor rechtenstudenten, maar uitdrukkelijk mede voor studenten met een economische of bedrijfskundige achtergrond.

Dit vak is ontwikkeld uit het keuzevak Risk, Reputation & Litigation, dat tot 2021 bestond en de hierboven vermelde met externe stakeholders ontwikkelde praktijk casus. Het vernieuwde vak is opgebouwd rondom de juridische risico’s en reputatierisico’s die (met name) financiële ondernemingen lopen in de context van litigation. Door deze interdisciplinaire aanpak kan het vak ook van toegevoegde waarde zijn voor studenten die geen loopbaan in de advocatuur of een andere typisch juridische functie ambiëren.
Veel van de docenten in het vak zijn dagelijks werkzaam in de juridische praktijk.
De aanwezigheid bij alle (al dan niet online) bijeenkomsten en de Moot court is verplicht. Van de studenten wordt bij elk bijeenkomst een actieve participatie verwacht.

Bij dit vak zullen externe stakeholders uit de praktijk, zoals advocaten- en accountantskantoren, betrokken zijn. Dit in het kader van impact onderwijs, waardoor studenten de theorie direct met en in de praktijk kunnen ondervinden en direct kennis maken met mensen uit de praktijk.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Inzicht in de rol en functie van bestuursrechtelijke, strafrechtelijke en privaatrechtelijke instrumenten in de context van het financiële toezichtrecht en de toepassing van bestuursrechtelijke, strafrechtelijke en privaatrechtelijke handhavingsmogelijkheden.
• Kennis en begrip van risicomanagement in de context van mogelijke en dreigende geschillen in financiële sector, waaronder normen met betrekking tot een beheerste en integere bedrijfsvoering.

• Inzicht in en begrip van privaatrechtelijke en publiekrechtelijke handhaving van normen uit hoofde van financieel (toezicht) recht en de mogelijkheden om financiële ondernemingen en/of hun bestuurders aansprakelijk te stellen.
• Toepassing van zorgplichtnormen uit hoofde van de Wft respectievelijk het privaatrecht.
• Kennis van en inzicht in de handhavingsmogelijkheden van toezichthouders DNB en AFM.

• Begrip van strategische overwegingen over de mogelijke reputatierisico’s in verband met (dreigende) juridische geschillen en het belang van gezonde verstandhoudingen met toezichthouders en regelgevers op nationaal en internationaal niveau.

• Aanleren van schriftelijke en mondelinge vaardigheden om financieel (toezicht)rechtelijke problemen weer te geven en te beoordelen en daarmee verband houdende voor- en tegenargumenten te formuleren, te analyseren en te bekritiseren.

column1: It is often rightly noted that people have more and easier access to information than ever before, and that there is more media created today (often by media users and audiences) than at any point in history. This vast and diverse media content offers an incredible opportunity, but also a challenge, to media analysts. Some of the most difficult questions facing media research concern not only how to properly identify critically important media texts, but also how to collect and make sense of patterns that can be observed within and across media. In this course, students will be provided scientific and industry-leading methodological tools in order to carry out these tasks, particularly in digital environments.

However, the course is not exhaustive; comprehensive coverage would require multiple courses. Instead, students will acquire a feel for tools of digital research. Thus, proficiency in any particular digital analysis approach is not a prerequisite. However, curiosity and willingness to experiment with digital technologies – that, due to their novelty, can be capricious – is necessary to succeed in and enjoy the course. It should also be noted that the approaches for digital analysis often blend qualitative and quantitative techniques.

Via lectures and interactive hands-on workshops, students will become acquainted with theoretical concepts and scholarly debates surrounding digital research combined with a hands-on approach for dealing with data. As most professional research happens in teams, this course also includes a small group research project in addition to individual work. After completion of this course, students will be able to gather and analyze digital data for future projects using appropriate methodologies and tools.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Digital analysis and their applicability in the field of media and communication.
• Research designs and measuring instruments for the analysis of digital media.
• Practical considerations necessary for digital analysis, for example the concepts and issues surrounding the collection of online data and their management.

column1: Students have developed the ability to:

column2: • Propose appropriate methods to meet particular research needs.
• Collect and analyze data from social media (Twitter, YouTube) and news (LexisNexis) on topics of their choice.
• Present digital research in clear, novel and engaging ways, orally and in writing.
• Perform basic text analysis, topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and network analysis.

column1: This course is part of cluster 4. The Politics of Wealth: Inequality, Capitalism, Exploitation

In Europe, from the late Middle Ages onward the concept of ‘race’ was used in order to distinguish different kinds of people. As a rule the distinctions drawn between human races were accompanied by clear cut moral hierarchies. Most early modern Europeans appear to have considered racial differences the result of a variety of external circumstances, but during the Enlightenment as a result of taxonomical attempts to classify man within the wider context of nature a modern, allegedly scientific racism arose, according to which these distinctions had a biological basis. In this course we will concentrate on the way in which European authors active prior to Darwin, who denied the reality of different human ‘species’, and to such 19th- and 20th-century racists as Gobineau, Chamberlain, and Rosenberg tried to meet the challenge implied by the discovery of peoples and cultures that looked fundamentally different from the ones early modern Europeans had been accustomed to, born as they were into a world which only recently had started to globalize. Some of the texts involved take the superiority of the inhabitants of Europe for granted. Other early modern authors, however, reveal an evident fascination sometimes coupled with genuine admiration for indigenous ‘natives’.
Attendance at lectures and seminars is mandatory. If students miss more sessions than allowed, they will not be allowed to hand in their papers.</body>

column1: The SCM Company Based Project (CBP) allows students to replace one free elective course in the program with a thesis / research internship for one of the elective blocks (minimum of 168 hours). During the remaining two elective blocks, the student is recommended to continue working part-time and follow the remaining electives.

The SCM CBP should seek to combine the writing of the thesis with an internship at a company during one of the elective blocks (Blocks, 3, 4, or 5). It is therefore important that the internship is related to the thesis and students will need to decide on an internship in consultation with their thesis coach and the master thesis coordinator. Students must be able to show that the internship will allow them to collect company-specific data (for that specific company), and that it is essential for their thesis project.
The CBP will be assessed separately from the thesis (on a pass/fail basis) by the thesis coach, company supervisor and master thesis coordinator.

If a student opts for the CBP, it will count as a free elective for 6 EC. This will give them the opportunity to work exclusively within the company for a period of 7 weeks. Thesis internships may be agreed for a longer period of time, but a minimum of 168 hours is expected and a maximum of 6 ECTS is credited. During the remaining two elective blocks, the student is recommended to work part-time and follow the remaining electives.
THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR SCM STUDENTS ONLY. In order to graduate you MUST complete at least two other SCM Programme Electives!

column1: Generally, in our program, there are two types of master thesis projects:

column2: • Theory-oriented projects: aim to contribute to theory development and/or theory testing. Usually, empirical data is used to build/test theory or to validate the research framework.

column1: The analysis of DNA variations, including Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs), is a standard research approach to understand causes of disease, in particular the so-called ""complex” diseases such as diabetes, osteoporosis, cancer, Alzheimer disease, etc. Since the Human Genome project. The field has been changing fast with large scale projects and databases (e.g., UK Biobank, TopMed, GWAS catalogue), and novel technology being continuously introduced, including Next Generation Sequencing, functional genomics, and Polygenic Risk Scores.

This is an advanced course on genetics on the latest advances in complex traits and monogenic conditions. Participants of the SNP course should have basic knowledge of molecular biology (such as DNA and gene structure, DNA translation to protein, etc.) and basic principles of techniques used for gene discovery. Participants lacking this knowledge should attend the course ’Basic Human Genetics’.

Basic background knowledge can also be found in any decent textbook of human molecular biology and genetics, such as ""Human Molecular Genetics"" (5th ed.; editors Strachan & Read; published by Taylor & Francis Inc.; €75,27).
In honor of the 20th edition of this course the course will be closed by a 2-day symposium with international guest speakers who are experts in their field.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

Giving a broad and hands-on introduction in genetic techniques and applications in complex genetics. The program also contains ""learning-by-doing” sessions (""practicals”) on the bio-informatic and statistical analysis in this field.

column1: THIS COURSE IS MANDATORY FOR ALL PHD CANDIDATES WHO ARE WORKING IN THE LABS!
Is a laboratory an extreme hazardous workplace?
Or is a laboratory a very safe workplace?
To answer this question, you need to have a proper understanding of hazards you can be confronted with when working in a laboratory and how to manage and avoid them.

Working in a laboratory you are certain to be confronted with different kinds of hazards and potential risks for your health and safety. This can vary from small dangers to major health risks, which you are sometimes not aware of. Mostly these risks can be reduced to acceptable levels when the right control measures are taken.

The objective of the training is to provide the participants with specific knowledge and skills about hazards and risks when working in laboratories. The participant will be trained in recognizing, interpreting, managing hazards and risks and which control measures to take. The training is based on the TOB model and will provide insights into specific hazards you can encounter and how to avoid or manage risk from three perspectives. During the training participants are asked to view and contribute their specific work situations. So, the risks relevant to the participants are dealt with in a focused manner.
In this way theory and practice are merged.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location and the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

column2: Provide the participants with specific knowledge and skills about hazards and risks when working in laboratories.
The participant will be trained in Recognizing, interpreting, and managing hazards and risks and which control measures to take.

column1: *the program may be subject to change.
The training is divided into two days:
In the first part, knowledge will be presented on which hazards and risks you may encounter when working in the laboratories and how these can be controlled in different ways. Topics are:

column2: What to do in case of an emergency
How to deal with specific hazards of machine/laser safety

column1: The set-up in part two is a workshop in which participants each introduce one or more unsafe situations.

column2: What are the concrete risks that I have to deal with?
How do we actually do things in our department?
What is my basic attitude when thinking and acting with these risks?
What role do I play in limiting the risks for myself, colleagues and the organization?

column1: These situations are classically discussed, analyzed and also specific control measures are suggested.
During this workshop insight will be provided on how safety behavior works
Participants get an answer on how they can deal with risks in their laboratory more professionally.

column1: In this course, you will be exploring the exciting world of sales. As you know, ‘sales’ is no longer stigmatized by greasy door-to-door salesmen utilizing slimy tactics and techniques to con their customers out of cash (remember the “always be closing” speech from Alec Baldwin? Google it). Sales is a global and thriving enterprise at the heart of everything we do. Think about it: the sales department is often the only profit-generating function in an organization! ‘Sales’ is also relevant to our personal and professional lives, as we all use persuasion to promote ourselves and our ideas. Whether you are interviewing for a job, sharing your ideas with friends/colleagues, or preparing assignments for this course—you are selling! This course therefore covers a broad range of topics and competences related to your career in business and marketing whether you will be working in a sales role or not.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Apply process elements of contemporary selling to a specific case.
• Describe decision stages involved in organizational buying.

column1: There is a big contrast between the proportion of business school alumni that work in sales -which is high- (and RSM is no exception) and the fraction of business schools offering a sales related course in the curriculum –which is low-. This is problematic because today’s world of sales more than ever requires professionals with an academic understanding of the field. Key trends like the knowledge intensity of sales work, and the shift towards a service economy have increased the complexity of the sales environment.

The goal of this course is to understand how sales leaders can most effectively manage salespeople. Note that this course does not focus on ‘how to sell’, but rather on ‘how to manage and lead salespeople.’
We will focus first on salespeople, starting with the question: “what makes a salesperson effective?” Next, we’ll move the analysis towards the sales team level and will zoom in on leadership.

We will analyse what is unique to the management and leadership of salespeople and discuss how to cope with this. Research-driven insights will form the foundation of the course, complemented with cases from modern-day business practice. We will combine lectures, practical case studies, exercises, and discussions.

• Understand the drivers of performance for salespeople and sales teams
• Understand how sales leaders can effectively manage salespeople
• Apply the theoretical knowledge to a business case in sales management
• Be able to critically evaluate performance cases of salespeople and -teams
