column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Family firms are the most prevalent ownership structure in the world. Research shows that these firms drive our global economy. In Europe, family firms represent over 80% of all companies, and about 75% of employment. Understanding the opportunities and challenges of family firms will provide you an unique addition to your toolkit of knowledge. This course aims to prepare you to work effectively and professionally in, and with, family firms.

Family firms represent an important heterogeneity in resourcing and venture growth as compared to high-growth VC-backed scaleup firms or 'regular' multinational enterprises. Family firms typically develop with own financing and for long periods of local bricolage. They grow at a different scale: deep towards locally anchored endurance. They consequently generate distinctive yet complementary benefits. Unlike scaling-up ventures whose local impact is explosive yet short-lived, scaling-deep ventures create jobs, products/services, and spillover effects that are meant to stay on the local and regional level. Building on these findings, we suggest that entrepreneurship-driven local development requires also ventures growing like family businesses.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyze critical issues such as governance, ownership, succession, communication and advising to family firms
• Apply business skills to address issues or problems facing existing family firms.
• Analyze the development of family firms in the context of social development and the economic, social and environmental benefits of growing firms deeply rooted in long-term goals.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112065,2023,Scaling Up & Strategies for High Growth,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['M Shahriari, MBA', 'S Varga, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Amazon, Netflix, LinkedIn, Dropbox, Airbnb... And the list goes on. All tremendously successful companies that managed to effectively scale up and have been recording impressive growth rates until present day. While many such famous companies with skyrocketing growth rates may come to mind, the reality is that such rapidly growing companies represent a handful of all firms. Namely, high growth firms (HGFs) represent only 3-5% of all firms yet create more than 50% of jobs across countries and regions (Haltiwanger et al., 2015). The challenges of scaling up and achieving high growth are numerous and often times referred to as “the entrepreneur’s impossible dream” (Nicholls-Nixon, 2005). Prior studies refer to rapidly increasing managerial complexity, frequent and quick changes in organizational structures, practices and processes (Nicholls-Nixon, 2005), as the firm doubles or even triples in size over short periods of time, internal friction and increasing workload and time pressure on employees, and extreme resource needs to continuously fuel the high growth of the firm (Hambrick & Crozier, 1985). Despite such challenging circumstances, there are firms that are able to successfully scale up and achieve such impressive high growth rates. This includes both SMEs and well-established large firms. But how are these firms able to do so? What strategic decisions do managers of these firms take to successfully scale up and fuel their growth despite the high expenses of rapid growth? how do these firms allocate their resources among different activities? What internal organizations and systems should they develop to effectively deal with the constant needs for change driven by their doubling or even tripling in size? How do these firms preserve the organizational culture and manage the tensions despite the ever-increasing inflow of new employees and customers to the firm? Which activities do these firms perform differently from their competitors? How do they secure and increase their market position over time? The purpose of this course is to encourage and facilitate seeking answers to these questions and provide a toolkit for today’s strategic management and entrepreneurship students to enhance their efforts to become tomorrow’s impactful and successful leaders and consultants.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the dynamics and challenges of scaling a firm up
• Prepare a strategic plan for developing and implementing high growth strategies
• Identify, analyze, and discuss the strengths of a firm, its resources, and capabilities that may contribute to effective scaling strategies
• Identify, analyze, and discuss areas for improvement in a firm’s scaling strategy
• Develop and present a competitive solution for addressing a real-life scaling challenge
• Identify, analyze, and assess own scale-up leadership potential (strengths and areas for improvement)
• Understand, analyze, and discuss the lifecycle of a scale-up
• Critically and constructively evaluate other’s and own work and provide developmental feedback for improvement

column1: <body>Het erfrecht en het huwelijksvermogensrecht worden op hoofdlijnen behandeld. De student maakt voorts kennis met de Wet op belastingen van rechtsverkeer 1970 en de Successiewet 1956. Van de Wet op belastingen van rechtsverkeer 1970 wordt alleen de overdrachtsbelasting behandeld. Bij bespreking van de overdrachtsbelasting wordt ook ingegaan op de samenloopproblematiek met de omzetbelasting en wordt tevens stil gestaan bij de cumulatie met de schenkbelasting. Bij de behandeling van de Successiewet 1956  wordt vooral ingegaan op de begrippen: 'al wat krachtens erfrecht of schenking wordt verkregen' en 'fictieve verkrijging’. Er wordt uitgebreid aandacht besteed aan de bedrijfsopvolgingsfaciliteiten. Estate Planning wordt vanuit diverse invalshoeken bezien, zowel nationaal als internationaal.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na dit blok bent u in staat om:

column2: • de hoofdlijnen van het Nederlandse erfrecht en het huwelijksvermogensrecht weer te geven en uit te leggen;
• in een casus de familierechtelijke elementen te identificeren en daarvan de gevolgen voor het Nederlandse erf- en huwelijksvermogensrecht te beoordelen;
• de hoofdlijnen van de schenk-, erf- en overdrachtsbelasting weer te geven en uit te leggen;
• in een casus de elementen van schenk-, erf- en/of overdrachtsbelasting te identificeren en daarvan de gevolgen voor de heffing van genoemde belastingen te beoordelen;
• in een casus de samenloop tussen overdrachtsbelasting en schenk-, erf- of omzetbelasting te identificeren en een conclusie te geven over de gevolgen van deze samenloop;
• in een casus te identificeren of sprake is van een fictieve verkrijging als bedoeld in de Successiewet 1956 en daarvan de gevolgen voor de heffing van schenk-, of erfbelasting te beoordelen; en
• in een casus te analyseren wat de schenk-, erf-, overdrachtsbelasting en familierechtelijke gevolgen zijn en daarover een gemotiveerd advies aan een belastingplichtige te geven.

column1: In this course, students will be introduced to science fiction as a major genre in cinema and  literature, but also in video games, music and other media. Science fiction has the ability to invent and prevent the future, but also to provide extremely precise analyses of societies. By studying its different past representations, we will try study how science fiction contributes to the understanding of our present, but also the shaping of our future.

Science fiction and media (A History of the Future) is the first course organized by CHIFT (Community for histories of the future), the platform based at Erasmus University aiming at studying and stimulating the production of science fiction in the Netherlands.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: De kinder- en jeugd GGZ maar ook het werkveld van de schoolpsycholoog heeft grote behoefte aan goed gekwalificeerde ‘scientist practioners’, dat wil zeggen psychologen die in hun dagelijks klinisch handelen oog hebben (en houden) voor recente wetenschappelijke inzichten en ontwikkelingen en van daaruit gebruik maken van ‘evidence-based’ diagnostiek en behandeling.

In dit derde blok in de Master Kinder- en Jeugdpsychologie zullen de studenten leren zich op te stellen als echte scientist practitioners. Ze zullen geconfronteerd worden met klinische en leerproblemen, waarvoor ze een wetenschappelijk gefundeerde oplossing moeten bedenken. Voorbeelden zijn: het selecteren van goed gevalideerde diagnostische instrumenten voor specifieke problematiek, het zoeken van de optimale (evidence-based) behandeling voor een kind met een bepaalde stoornis, het bekijken van evidence-based preventieprogramma’s, het onderbouwd kunnen adviseren van collega-psychologen. Tevens wordt er aandacht besteed aan de professionele attitude.

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<font color=""black"">Een     belangrijke     doelstelling     van     dit     blok     is     studenten     te     leren     een     brug     te     slaan     tussen     het     wetenschappelijk     onderzoek     en     de     academische     vaardigheden     enerzijds     en     de     dagelijkse     praktijk     van     de     kinder-     en     jeugdzorg     in     de     GGZ     en     het     onderwijs     anderzijds.     Inhoudelijk     zullen     problemen     behandeld     worden     uit     verschillende     relevante     K&J-psychopathologiedomeinen     die     in     eerdere     blokken     nog     niet     echt     aan     bod     gekomen     zijn.     Hierdoor     heeft     de     student     aan     het     eind     van     de     Klinische     Kinder-     en     Jeugdmaster     kennis     gemaakt     met     alle     belangrijke     stoornissen     uit     de     kinder-     en     jeugdpsychopathologie.</font>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What is this strange thing called the ‘modern sciences’? This course, the first of the academic skills curriculum, is the students’ introduction to scientific approaches. The course is set up to acquaint the students with several approaches that are commonly used in academia, and could be seen as the core approaches taught and used at EUC. And although students might be familiar with the approaches and methods introduced by the natural sciences (and adopted by several human sciences) - focusing on ‘causal explanation’ - the approaches involved with hermeneutic understanding and from the perspective of Critical Theory are probably less known. However, they are of great importance, as they can bring forth crucial insights the methods of the natural science are unable to provide. The three scientific approaches - causal explanation, hermeneutic understanding and ‘critique' - will be introduced by surveying how several scientific disciplines ‘do’ climate science. How to acquire knowledge about the determinants of, and reasons for climate migration? How to measure biodiversity and its decline? How to critically (re)conceptualize the way we understand climate change, historically and philosophically, and why is this important? And how to create economic models that describe and predict costs and benefits of our global economic systems and businesses in relation to the environment - as accurately as possible? With this course we aim to involve the students in broadening their views on ‘science’ as a pluriform activity directed at producing reliable knowledge, with different goals and through different methods. In this way we hope to prepare the students for all the good things a LAS-education has to offer.

column1: Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course

This course includes mandatory attendance when registered. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points and the cancellation policy applies.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, participants may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Participants should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Erasmus MC Graduate School PhD education is free of charge*. However, free of charge does not mean free of responsibility. Once you have signed up for a course or event, we expect you to attend. For every late cancellation or no-show, we have had to disappoint others who would have liked to join.
Please find the cancellation and no-show policy on STiP.
*A payment of €1.00 is required for administrative purposes.

Het schrijven van een scriptie van 12 000-16 000 woorden (10 ects) is een verplicht onderdeel van de masteropleiding Fiscaal recht. Voor de studenten van de variant Directe belastingen geldt dat het onderwerp van hun scriptie betrekking moet hebben op directe belastingen; voor de studenten van de variant Indirecte belastingen zijn dat de Indirecte belastingen.

Het schrijven van de masterscriptie Fiscaal recht is alleen mogelijk met deelname aan het door ons aangeboden scriptietraject. Indien u de wens heeft om in het collegejaar 2018 – 2019 af te studeren, dan dient in ieder geval uw scriptie vóór 26 juni 2018 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider. Indien de scriptie vervolgens wordt goedgekeurd door de tweede lezer, kan de scriptie worden verdedigd tijdens de afstudeerbijeenkomst van eind augustus 2019.

column2: • Goedkeuring scriptieonderwerp en aanmelding in het scriptievolgsysteem vóór 25 januari 2019;
• a. Studenten variant Directe belastingen: eerste afspraak met scriptiebegeleider vóór 8 maart 2019.

column1: b. Studenten variant Indirecte belastingen: deelname inleidende discussiebijeenkomst 6/7 februari 2019.

Let op: U kunt alleen aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak deelnemen als u aan de verplichte onderdelen 1 t/m 4 hebt voldaan. Dit zal voorafgaande aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak actief worden gecontroleerd.

Het is aan te raden op tijd met de scriptie te beginnen. Uit ervaring is bekend dat vooral de eerste fase van de ontwikkeling van een scriptie (bestaande uit de keuze van het onderwerp, de literatuurverzameling en het inlezen) veel tijd kost. Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat een eventueel in het bachelorwerkstuk behandeld onderwerp niet mag worden 'uitgewerkt' tot een masterscriptie. Het onderwerp van de scriptie dient tijdig aangemeld te worden door middel van het invullen van het 'Aanmeldingsformulier scriptie (Master) Fiscaal Recht'. Na goedkeuring van het onderwerp door de sectie Fiscaal Recht ontvangt u bericht met daarin de naam van de toegewezen scriptiebegeleider. Na goedkeuring ligt het onderwerp vast.

Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat niet eerder aan een scriptie kan worden begonnen dan nadat het aanmeldingsformulier is ingeleverd en u bericht heeft ontvangen over het toewijzen van een scriptiebegeleider.

Uw scriptie moet binnen twee collegejaren na aanvang van het masterscriptietraject door uw scriptiebegeleider zijn goedgekeurd. Daarna vervalt uw scriptieonderwerp. U dient dan opnieuw het gehele scriptietraject te doorlopen. Dat geldt niet voor het Fiscaal confrontatievak, indien u dat vak al met een voldoende heeft afgesloten. Indien u in het collegejaar 2018/2019 start met uw scriptie dient uw scriptie dus uiterlijk aan het eind van collegejaar 2019/2020 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider.

column1: The course starts by introducing the Semantic Web, and ontologies as the cornerstone of the next generation Web. After that, the most relevant Semantic Web data representation languages (XML, RDF, and OWL) and data query/transformation languages (XPath, XQuery, and XSLT) are presented. Some applications of the Semantic Web for building Web Information Systems for finance, marketing, logistics, or information retrieval are also given.

The students will work in teams on several assignments related to the application of the Semantic Web for developing Web Information Systems. The students will write a report describing the proposed solutions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Understand what a Semantic Web ontology is.
• Be aware of the usefulness of Semantic Web technologies for developing Web Information Systems.
• Be able to develop a Semantic Web ontology.
• Be able to query a Semantic Web ontology.
• Propose Semantic Web solutions for current problems that Web Information Systems face in finance, marketing, logistics, or information retrieval.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112359,2023,Seminar Advanced Corporate Finance: Corporate Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. CS Pfeil', 'dr. MG Gabarro Bonet', 'prof.dr. I Dittmann']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Corporate governance analyzes two conflicts of interest that arise in the financing of the firm.

The first is the conflict between shareholders and the firm's management. While shareholders usually want to see a high return on their investment, managers might have a different agenda. They could try to use the firm's funds for their own interests, or to build an empire that is big but unprofitable. We will discuss this problem and its two main solutions: monitoring by a big shareholder and incentive contracts that give the managers a share in the value they created for the firm.

The second conflict of interest emerges between controlling shareholder and minority shareholders. The controlling shareholder might try to ""tunnel"" money from the firm into her own pocket and thereby to expropriate minority shareholders. Depending on the legal environment, there might be many ways to do this. We will discuss the relevance of this problem and its implications for the ownership structure of the firm and for a firm's ability to obtain outside financing.

Against this background, we will discuss corporate governance laws and codes, the role and composition of the board of directors, executive compensation, the design of financial securities, mergers and acquisitions, and shareholder activism.

This seminar provides you with an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding about what good corporate governance is and why it matters. The course covers some theoretical and legal issues, but its main focus is on empirical research and insights. Therefore, we will analyze, discuss and criticize the methodology used in the empirical research. Hence, this course also aims at building a critical view on any empirical results presented to the student. In two group assignments, you will apply your knowledge and your skills to two different types of tasks.

Active participation in and a strong commitment to this course are a prerequisite. You are expected to present pieces of the literature and to prepare for in-class discussions. You will also present your own results, ask questions, mention doubts and express your ideas in the class discussion. Hence, learning group dynamics is a positive (and important) side effect of this course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into the theory of conflicts of interest within a firm.
• Students have knowledge of different corporate governance standards currently in use and why they matter.
• Students have knowledge of state-of-the-art techniques to resolve problems of endogeneity in empirical settings of corporate governance.
• Students are able to critically discuss in class other authors’ empirical results.
• Students are able to confront alternative empirical findings and evaluate their respective strengths and weaknesses.
• Students are able to design and execute in groups a small scale empirical study.

column1: The seminar is intended for students in their final master's year who want to obtain a thorough understanding of corporate finance, which examines the financial decisions of firms. Topics include capital raising, mergers and acquisitions, and CEO overconfidence. The lecturer will present recent empirical insights and techniques. During the course, students engage in presentations, discussions, and conduct research. More specifically, students are asked to work on weekly readings, present pieces of the literature, bring up subjects of discussion as preparation for the sessions, participate in group discussions, and perform empirical research in a group.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Learn techniques and methods used in empirical research.
• Learn the tools necessary to work independently on a master thesis in empirical corporate finance.
• Learn to master a challenging topic and perform research in a group.
• Improve verbal and written communication and presentation skills.
• Learn to critically analyze results and reflect on conclusions drawn from these results.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112355,2023,Seminar Advanced Corporate Finance: Private Equity,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. G Cocco', 'dr. JCM Kil']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course follows a problem-solving approach that synthesizes ideas from game theory, real options, and strategy for corporate decision-making. Corporate finance and corporate strategy have long been seen as different sides of the same coin. Though both focus on the same broad problem, investment decision-making, the gap between the two sides -- and between theory and practice -- remains large. This course synthesizes cutting-edge developments in corporate finance and related fields -- in particular, real options and game theory -- to help bridge this gap. The course covers a wide range of valuation examples, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, joint research ventures, product introductions, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment. The course will be given in close cooperation with people and organizations that are active in corporate finance, such as private equity investors, investment banks, and consultants. The course Corporate Finance and Strategy is structured in two modules. The first module introduces you to both traditional and new valuation principles for strategic investment. We review the basic concepts and foundations of the building blocks:
This part provides an overview and develops step-by-step the various principles useful for valuation and analysis. Questions addressed include amongst others:

column2: • How can one determine the value of a project or a firm?
• What is the value of a license that gives the firm an option to invest in commercial production of a new product?
• How is the optimal investment policy influenced by competition? How does competition affect the premium being paid in M&A?

column1: In the second module we discuss various applications and examples of private equity investment, acquisitions, and initial public offerings. Lectures by guest speakers will be an integral part of the course and provide an opportunity to become better acquainted with corporate finance in practice. This course provides the fundamentals for the seminar Advanced Corporate Finance and Private Equity.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into fundamental economic theories in corporate finance (real options, game theory and behavioral theory).
• Students have knowledge of different types of acquisitions and how they are structured and financed.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into strengths and weaknesses of using different types of valuation models, in the context where they can be applied.

• Students are able to apply valuation models in a variety of contexts, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment.
• Students are able to form an opinion based on different perspectives acquisitions and private equity investment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Money, credit, and banking (MCB) are the tools at our disposal to bring our dreams of the future immediately to the present. This is true for country politicians dreaming of full employment, corporate managers dreaming of innovative growth, and individuals dreaming of a home for their family.

This course discusses the role and impact of MCB by bridging the link between academia and practice. Well-known theories and frameworks on public money and credit (e.g., inflation, monetary policy and central banking,), private money and credit(e.g., financial markets, and the financing of firms) and banking (financial institutions) are presented and evaluated.

How does a modern financial institution or publicly held firm operate and how is it financed? What is the role of central banks, both in the past as well as today, and how does this relate to their mandate? How has financial intermediation changed with technology? And what impact does the role of regulation play in financial markets? All these developments are creating various opportunities -and risks- as we speak, and not understanding this properly can seriously damage your wealth.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• At the country level, you will understand the role of MCB in the most important financial crises (the US mortgage crises from 2008, the Euro crisis from 2011, and the current COVID-19 situation that is still evolving), and in the policy responses to these crisis. You will also learn how countries have coped with these crises through unprecedented monetary innovations, and what consequences this has had on the real and financial economy.

• At the firm level, you will learn about the role of MCB in the financing of corporations. You will understand the promise and pitfalls of financial market innovations, and bust the myth of the widely held public firm. This will allow you to better understand existing and future financial products and foresee vulnerabilities in financial markets.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this seminar, the emphasis will be on the policies governments and other stakeholders introduce to respond to the SDGs. Students will investigate how policies are implemented in their case, which stakeholders are impacted by the policies, how these policies affect the SDG’s and what possible change in policies are resulting in better reaching the SDGs. They use the knowledge build up in the first three blocks and present what they learned about the adopted case. This investigation will lead to weekly presentations of the literature and a group assignment in which the case groups report on the implementation of policy options related to their case.

column1: Behavioural economics models systematic deviations from the standard economic model. This seminar will show how to take into account these deviations to improve the design and implementation of business strategies and public policies.

The course will consist of guest lectures by practitioners and case studies in partnership with companies and government. In the past, established companies such as ENECO, IKEA, and Albert Heijn have provided cases to work on, but also start-ups like ByeWaste and MijnSofie.

This course is divided into multiple tasks. For each task, a case pitcher from industry or government will present students with a real world problem they face. In small teams, students will be tackling these problems by relying on existing knowledge, gathering new knowledge through a targeted literature review, design a relevant experiment and collect data, and combine all these insights to provide an advice towards the case pitcher. Each team presents their findings and writes a report.

This seminar is not only useful for students with academic aspirations, but also great preparation for anyone with an interest in practical or policy related research, or a career in consultancy. It teaches you to view a problem from multiple sides and not only come up, but also test possible solutions to the problem.
In addition, this seminar is useful preparation for writing an MSc thesis.

• Students learn how run an experiment and gather data.
• Students learn how to analyse data and connect the findings back to the existing literature.
• Students learn how to design a solution and give practical recommendations to representatives industry and government.
• Students learn how to critically assess their own work and to deal with peer and supervisor feedback.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In the seminar Behaviour, Health and Wellbeing students will learn to combine the knowledge and skills obtained in the major courses to analyse and possibly influence behaviour related to health and wellbeing. In particular they will work on two themes: (i) healthy behaviour, (ii) wellbeing; with four possible angles
(a) Measuring and analysing behaviour and well-being (e.g., Why do people procrastinate going to the gym?)
(b) Understanding the role of people’s own responsibility (e.g., Should overweight people pay more health insurance premiums?)
(c) Making policy recommendations (e.g., How can we incentivize or nudge healthier behaviour?)
(d) Evaluate the impact of policies (e.g., Can we test whether the incentives work using a field experiment?)

• The students learn to work in teams.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course aims at improving our understanding of financial markets and asset returns, by applying insights from psychology and other behavioural sciences. Traditionally, the finance paradigm seeks to understand financial decisions by building on optimal acting investors and market forces that correct mispricing; that is, it assumes people behave rational. However, abundant evidence, reveals that this paradigm is too restrictive and in many circumstances gives a poor description of people's behaviour. We (being people) do not always act in the best way possible. In fact, in many decision situations we make mistakes that result in non-optimal behaviour.

Using interactive sessions, the first part of this course will examine various influential behavioural biases and their implications for financial markets and decisions. The second part of the course will consider how behavioural principles can turn into a profit by studying how behavioural biases affect the behaviour of market participants and prices. Finally, the course will learn you how trading strategies can be developed based upon various behavioural pitfalls.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of various influential behavioural biases and their implications for financial markets and decisions.
• Students have knowledge of trading strategies can be developed based upon various behavioural pitfalls.
• Students learn how to build trading strategies on behavioral biases and to limit their impact on your investment behavior.
• Students develop a skillset to empirically evaluate various investment strategies.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students work in small groups on a specific theoretical or empirical econometric problem. Topics stem from international macro-, financial, and micro-econometrics, and may be provided by institutions, policy-makers and/or firms. Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. During the end of the term, each group writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the term, in which the research project is presented by members of the group and discussed by members of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.

column1: The students are divided in small groups. Each group works on a research question. Usually this research question is put forward by a company. First, the relevant literature is studied. Next, the research question is translated in one or more models. To estimate the parameters of the models, (company) data is used. Much attention will be paid to the selection of the best possible model, given the research question. This model can be any model dealt with in the various courses, but it can also be a model that needs to be developed by the students themselves. The model parameters are estimated, and the model results are interpreted within the light of the research question. The final results will be presented in a scientific report and a presentation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Learn how to formulate a research question and how to translate it in an econometric/statistical model.
• Learn how to obtain a well-specified model using techniques from econometrics/statistics/machine learning.
• Learn how to use the outcomes of an analysis to answer the research questions.
• Reporting of academic research in the form of an article.
• Reporting of academic research in the form of a presentation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In the seminar Case Studies in Data Science and Marketing Analytics, students get the unique opportunity to solve real-world management problems working on real data and collaborating closely with real companies. Solving the business case hinges upon six data-science talents that determine the success of a data science project. These talents are the foundational pillars of the course structure: subject expertise, data wrangling, data analysis, storytelling, design, and project management (Berinato 2019, Harvard Business Review).

The case starts with formulation and conceptualization of the research question and immersion into the relevant literature to gain subject expertise. Next, students wrangle the data acquired from the company behind the case. Then, students first conduct relatively simple data analysis and obtain preliminary insights. Afterwards, they use more advanced data-science methods to validate these preliminary insights and enrich them. Based on these insights, students develop their stories to engage the company to take action. Finally, students design effective visual communication and present it to company management. Throughout this period, students apply project management to organize effectively various activities and teamwork.

column2: • Challenge ourselves with a real-life case from a well-known company under demanding conditions.
• The seminar was for us the ultimate test of applying those methods we learned during the previous courses using a real-life dataset.
• The course showed that real life business problems are much more challenging than many of the toy examples we learn in other courses.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Precisely formulate a general management question as a specific research question
• Review the literature in terms of theory and methods related to the research question
• Determine the data requirements for answering the research question
• Find and implement a suitable analysis technique to answer the research question, given available data
• Answer the research question based on the outcomes of the selected technique
• Provide recommendations for management based on the results
• Communicate effectively within the team and with external relations
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, students apply the knowledge and skills acquired throughout their studies to real-world contexts in organizations. During the seminar, we will apply methods and use findings from academic research papers to solve problems that are important to organizations. These problems can be related to organizational structure, corporate strategy, and human resources management, with the dual objective of improving firm performance and creating a positive impact at work. Throughout the seminar, students will perform in-depth analyses of cases, find and apply relevant knowledge from the most advanced research in economics (both theoretical and empirical), analyze relevant data, and develop innovative solutions for organizations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this seminar, students should be able to:
1) understand how market structure and organizational policies impact performance,
2) design policies that can be tested to help organizations navigate today’s and tomorrow’s challenges,
3) perform a relevant empirical analysis, as well as expose and interpret the findings correctly and clearly,
4) collaborate with other students to formulate solutions that are relevant for organizations,
5) present research-based solutions for real-world problems in a way that can effectively be implemented by organizations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Obligatory attendance at all sessions. Students are required to participate actively in seminar discussions (both during formal presentations and general discussions).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the seminar you learn about different ways to conduct policy research, using recent cases in policy evaluation.

column2: • What can we learn about the impact of unemployment policies using quasi-experimental research designs?
• Can we measure the effect of additional funding for schools with a regression discontinuity design?
• How to set up a fiel experiment to analyze the effects of teacher performance pay?
• What does social-cost benefit analysis tell us about the costs and benefits of the Olympic Games?

column1: Students are expected tot discuss and present policy research during the seminar.
Finally, students are expected to do an empirical case study, do research assignments, and write a policy research paper.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• To learn the main techniques in the field of treatment/ policy evaluation: randomized controlled trials, instrumental variables models, regression discontinuity models, difference-in-differences models.
• To understand the underlying assumptions of the main models and the differences with the standard approaches as linear regression and matching models.
• To understand the main techniques of social cost benefit analysis.
• To be able to assess the credibility of policy evaluation by applying the knowledge of the main models and their assumptions.
• To be able to assess the quality of a social cost benefit analysis.
• To be able to present the scientific evidence for a specific policy cases and assess the credility of this evidence.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Within two weeks after a possible failure, a rewritten policy paper needs to be handed in.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112477,2023,Seminar Corporate Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. I Honarvar Gheysary', 'dr. MG Gabarro Bonet', 'dr. NRD Dwarkasing', 'dr. VV Volosovych']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this seminar we discuss the central topics in corporate finance paying particular attention to practical applications. We cover such topics as the corporate investment decisions, capital structure issues, company valuation, the dividend policy, and other topics. During the seminar, you will present and actively discuss academic papers and case studies and work on a group valuation assignment.
To enhance the development of practical knowledge and prospective we try to arrange the guest lectures of a valuation expert and/or a company CEO/CFO.
The required readings include articles from renowned academic and practitioners journals.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Know, understand, and explain key concepts and theories in the field of corporate finance, related to investment decision, financing decision, payout decision, and governance issues by the corporations.
• Understand the difference between price and value of the company.
• Learn to apply techniques behind investment decisions by companies and investors (Net Present Value, Payback method, Real Options analysis, etc.).
• Learn advanced techniques and appropriate quantitative research methods regarding the valuation of companies (Discounted Cash Flows method, method of multiples and their extensions).

• Cooperate professionally and effectively in teams, apply economic theories, data collection, and research methods to determine the fundamental value of a real-life company. Make strategic decision about the development of company's business in its industry and competitive environment.
• Based on economic theories and own analysis and research findings, draw conclusions about the value of the business and formulate the investment recommendation regarding this company.

• Based on existing research and complex contemporary conditions learn to individually select relevant discussion questions and to cooperate professionally and effectively in teams to address these problems from different points of view and using logical reasoning and formulate conclusions .
• Learn and practice to communicate effectively verbally and in writing by structuring the arguments correctly and consistently and using the argumentation skills and critical thinking.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112449,2023,Seminar Corporate Governance and Sustainability,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. MHR Erkens'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Corporate governance analyses two conflicts of interest in the firm's financing.
The first is the conflict between shareholders and the firm's

management. While shareholders usually want to see a high return on their investment, managers might have a different agenda. They could try to use the firm's funds for their own interests or to build a big but unprofitable empire. We will discuss this problem and its two main solutions: monitoring by a big shareholder and incentive contracts that give the managers a share in the value they created for the firm.

The second conflict of interest emerges between controlling shareholders and minority shareholders. The controlling shareholder might try to tunnel money from the firm into her own pocket and thereby expropriate minority shareholders. There might be many ways to do this, depending on the legal environment. We will discuss the relevance of this problem and its implications for the firm's ownership structure and for a firm's ability to obtain outside financing.

Against this background, we will discuss corporate governance laws and codes, the role and composition of the board of directors, executive compensation, and shareholder activism. We will also discuss recent literature on sustainability and will cover ESG rating, ESG investments, and sustainability reporting.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• This course provides you with an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding about corporate governance and sustainability and why both matter.
• Students will analyze, discuss and criticize empirical research.
• This course aims at building a critical view of empirical results presented to the student.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Marketing focus has been shifting from the product to the individual customer as the unit level of analysis. Managers are increasingly concerned with the long term profitability of customers; and with their ability to collect (and analyze) consumer data and manage both the value consumers provide to the firm and the value a firm can provide to the consumers. That is why Customer Intelligence and Customer Relationship Management (CRM) have become essential parts of the decision making process for successful firms.

This course will teach students how to gather data about consumers, and how to make sense of it in order to make decisions within the organization. The course will show students the benefits of using a systematic and analytical approach to marketing decision making, and will allow them to build their skills and confidence in undertaking such analyses and decision making in the context of CRM. A ""consumer-focused"" approach will enable students to acquire research techniques that provide more detailed insights into the behavior of customers.
The course is designed for students who have extensive background in or understanding of marketing research and marketing principles.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Identify the right context of the real life marketing problem where the data collection methods and models discussed in class can be applied.
• Create effective measurement instruments aimed at gathering data about their consumers.
• Explain the construction of key statistical models used to describe consumer behavior.
• Use statistical software to conduct the analyses discussed in class.
• Communicate the results to the general audience in an intuitive and practically relevant way.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this seminar several data science/machine learning methods are treated sequentially. First, students acquire the basics behind various machine learning techniques after which they deepen their knowledge and understanding of the methods by implementing and applying the methods to real data.

We discuss and apply several ""state-of-the-art"" machine learning methods. Students are asked to critically assess, present and discuss the material. Reviewing state-of-the art methods and their application in business settings will help students to assess whether (and how) data can be used to help answer real world business problems.
What students say about the course:
Exhaustive coverage of the main state-of-the-art machine learning techniques, from students to students learning approach""
“The best way to learn something, is by trying to explain it to others. You are forced to know every part and detail of the subject.”

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understanding various state-of-the art machine learnig (ML) methods.
• Explain several state-of-the art ML methods do to a general audience.
• Critically assess academic and public sources in which the ML methods are introduced.
• Carry out and write a short report on independent research in which ML methods are applied to a real data set.
• Interpret and explain results of such ML analyses through presentations and written reports.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/114483,2023,Seminar Data Science in Finance,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['A Soebhag, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This seminar provides an introductory overview of several well-known techniques in data science within a financial context. We will discuss techniques from regularization to natural language processing. Students apply the methods using the statistical language Python (or R) in several group assignments. Data science techniques will be, in particular, applied within an investment/asset management context.
After this course, you will be able to:
(1) Have a broad overview of the area of data science
(2) Understand popular data science methods and concepts
(3) Apply machine learning techniques in a programming language
(4) Judge which techniques to use given the data and context
(5) Train, validate and evaluate machine learning models
(6) Interprete statistical results from an economic perspective

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112363,2023,Seminar Developing and Marketing New Products,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. EK Keko', 'prof.dr. S Stremersch']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Innovation is the engine for growth in most modern firms. However, many organizations fail when bringing innovations to the market. The development and marketing of new market offerings is therefore arguably one of the most critical and most difficult challenges faced by any organization. In this seminar we will go through different stages of the new product development process, from opportunity identification until product launch. Throughout the lecture series, we will use business cases, articles from the academic literature, and many practical examples to illustrate recent developments in innovation and marketing and the possibilities to involve consumers in the process.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• To provide you with insights and understanding of the specific nature of innovation-related marketing by going through the entire cycle from having a great new business idea to taking that idea to commercial success.
• To equip you with conceptual frameworks that can help you make better marketing decisions regarding innovations.
• To let you apply this knowledge to real-world business problems via case studies.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This seminar investigates applications of econometrics to the some of the most important social problems of our time. The seminar focuses on frontier (quasi-experimental, structural, survey, etc.) approaches to these problems, in addition to economic and social considerations relating to efficiency and fairness. Students read and critically discuss current research relating to health, education, crime, inequality, pollution, innovation, institutions, etc., where topics can vary depending on the interests of students and faculty. Students then work in groups under the close supervision of a faculty member to develop and write an original research paper relating to one of these areas.
This course uses knowledge from FEB22009(X,Q) Introductory Seminar Case Studies and FEB22005(X) Econometrics 2.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Obtain in-depth knowledge about econometric and OR techniques related to machine learning, and new developments in this field.
• Learn how to formulate a research question.
• Learn how to critically read and discuss academic papers.
• Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques to answer the research question.
• Learn how to apply quantitative models to data.
• Learn how to interpret results to answers to research questions.
• Apply quantitative techniques in a real-world setting.
• Learn to report about the research project in the form of a scientific report and a presentation.
• Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112333,2023,Seminar Economic Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. KFJ Spiritus', 'prof.dr. DS Schindler', 'prof.dr. JA Bolhaar']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The definitive decision on the main topic(s) will be made before the start of the course. During the course, students will get an in-depth theoretical and empirical background into the economics of main topics of the course.

Guest lecturers with strong expertise in the main topics and policy makers will be invited. Students are expected to prepare lectures well. During the lectures students will present articles from a list of required reading to the whole class. Active student participation in the course will be rewarded.

During this course, each student will be writing a policy paper (in group work) on an important aspect of the main topic(s) of this course. Students will provide a theoretically sound and empirically founded policy advice to solve the policy problem under consideration. Since policy questions will generally be very broad, different students will analyze different sub-questions in their papers.
The lecturers provide assistance with writing the papers. Students need to defend their analysis in a class presentation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To require in-depth knowledge about one of the most pressing policy issues of our time, such as the eurocrisis, global warming, inequality, taxation of multinationals or the corona-crisis.
• To understand the economics of a policy question from theoretical literature.
• To judge the relevance of theoretical arguments using empirical evidence.
• To weigh different theoretical arguments based on their empirical validity.
• To formulate a policy advice based on sound economic reasoning, backed up by solid empirical evidence.
• To defend the analysis of a policy question in a presentation.
• To write an economic policy advice that contains i) theoretical analysis, ii) empirical evidence of theoretical arguments iii) weighing various arguments iv) formulating a policy recommendation.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Following earlier recommendations, we abolished the oral exam and moved the presentation of the policy paper to week 8, relaxing the deadlines during the seminar.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During this Seminar, students work on a topical, highly relevant research question. The question is introduced during the first session. Together, we develop a series of subquestions during the first two sessions. Students work in groups of two on a subquestion and report on their findings, both in writing (in a Google doc shared with all 15 students and the professor) and in class the week after. Findings are being discussed, comments are provided, and new subquestions are developed, which are again taken up by teams of students. During the weeks, teams vary in composition and exact tasks, so as to learn how to work together in a variety of ways. At the end of the 7 week block, a shared Google doc results that should shed new light on the research question posed at the start of the block. Each student keeps a logbook of his/her contributions to the project. The logbook is shared with the professor. Half way the block, students can request an indication of the grade they are heading to, given their performance so far.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Learn how to develop and formulate research questions
• Learn how to do small-scale empirical and theoretical studies
• Learn how to critically assess existing studies
• Learn how to provide feedback to others
• Learn how to respond to feedback from others
• Learn how to work in diverse teams
• Learn how to present a work in progress and a finished piece of work

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: International migration is at the center of the policy debate in many countries. Movements of people across countries can influence several aspects of the economy and society in both sending and receiving countries, from the labor markets to economic development to politics. Moreover, recent research has shed light on the effects of immigration on cultural variables, such as voting and attitudes of natives towards immigration.

Throughout this course, we will analyze the determinants of migration, the effects of migration on the labor markets and on the economy of source and destination countries, the political and social consequences of migration, the economic returns to migration for migrants, migrants assimilation in the host countries and its challenges. To address these questions, students will study, present and discuss academic papers, with a particular focus on the latest advances in the field of economics of migration. By studying these topics, students will gain a deeper understanding of the complexities of the field of economics of migration and of the role of migration in shaping global outcomes.
This seminar will have a strong empirical focus; therefore, prior knowledge of applied econometrics is strongly recommended.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Investigate the main economic consequences of migration in destination countries
• Illustrate the main determinants of migration and consequences of migration in the source countries
• Examine the political and social consequences of immigration
• Summarize and critically assess empirical academic research on migration.

Typical topics that *may* be covered during the course include:

The precise topics and organization of the seminar depends on the number of students who end up being assigned to the seminar. All relevant practical information will be provided through Canvas before the seminar begins, and discussed during the first meeting of the seminar.

column1: The seminar is about investing in real solutions for real problems: what can investors do to have impact and enable change to a sustainable world?

The first part of the seminar focuses on real solutions. We focus on risk from climate change as the real problem and we'll discover what real solutions work such that the energy transition leads to less carbon emissions.

In the second part of the seminar we focus on the impact investment process. How can we ensure that our investments generate impact? What is a theory of change and how does it help us to shape an investment portfolio? And lastly, how can verify that our investments lead to our impact goals?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To understand what impact investing is and how it contributes to funding real solutions for real environmental en social problems.
• To be able to assess how impact can quantified and how it then can be applied to portfolio management.
• To be able to assess what the real problem is.
• To understand what investments are needed to speed up the energy transition.
• To gain knowledge about renewable energy investments.

column1: In this course, we will focus on empirical financial accounting research topics, such as the capital market implications of accounting information, earnings properties and disclosures. The course is given in a seminar format: sessions take place in small groups of (up to) 24 students and will consist of active discussions about existing research. Besides reading academic research, you will learn to apply the knowledge to solve or provide advice on issues in practice. This will be achieved through in-class discussions and assignments, as well as a separate group assignments in which you will write a policy advice on a current topic of debate, drawing from existing academic research.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Identify and discuss mainstream research topics in financial accounting research.
• Describe and evaluate theoretical arguments in accounting research.
• Evaluate whether the empirical research design of a paper can provide an answer to the posed research question.
• Describe and draw their own conclusions from the empirical findings (tables/graphs) of a paper.
• Summarize academic knowledge to advise on issues in society or practice.
• Develop and present your own arguments founded in good reasoning.
• Engage in discussion about financial accounting topics with peers.

column1: The main contents of this seminar course are the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) and the (emerging) CSR/ESG reporting standards. The seminar is delivered with a limited number of students. The small class size requires and ensures active participation by all students. During the seminar course, full-time availability of the student is expected and attendance is mandatory. Students must take into account a commitment of ca. 42 hours per week for literature study and performing assigned tasks, such as submitting discussion points, looking for relevant news and company reports, preparing cases, presenting, and writing a student paper.
Examples of the topics covered in this seminar course include (but are not limited to):
• International Accounting Standards Board and its Conceptual Framework
• Recognition, measurement, and disclosure of specific accounts in financial statements under the IFRS, such as equity, inventory, intangible assets, leases, revenue, taxation, etc.
• CSR/ESG reporting standards and companies’ reports

The seminar course concludes with an analysis (as an external auditor) of a company’s annual report chosen by one of the Big Four accounting firms. Students will deliver a final presentation at one of the Big Four accounting firms, linking theory with practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The seminar course aims to provide knowledge about the external reporting of companies. External reporting covers all communications of companies with respect to their financial and certain non-financial performance (e.g., CSR and/or ESG reporting). Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to
• Understand the financial accounting and external reporting for various accounts;
• Apply academic and professional skills, such as reading, discussing, presenting, writing, and providing peer feedback;
• Evaluate the significance and limitations of financial and CSR/ESG reporting standards;
• (For students who write a BSc thesis) identify a relevant thesis topic from the seminar.

column1: Students work in teams of 4 on specific (theoretical or empirical) financial econometric research projects, which are supplied by firms in the financial industry (including asset managers, hedge funds, insurance companies, and pension funds). Examples include problems in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing.

Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. Each group writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the course term, in which the research project is presented by a member of the group and discussed by a member of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Learn to decide upon the correct data and appropriate econometric techniques to answer the research question.
• Learn how to use the outcomes of an econometric analysis to answer the research questions.
• Learn to report about the research project in the form of a (scientific) report and a presentation.
• Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Following the most recent trends in empirical research, this seminar will take a firm-level approach to the study of international trade. To have a firm grasp in understanding the empirics, we will start off with the “new” trade theory of international trade, its extension with heterogeneous firms, and the related gravity model of trade. We will then focus on the empirical research on heterogeneous firms and trade by studying and discussing frontier academic papers. The topics covered will include: self-selection into exporting, learning by exporting, intermediaries in trade, and the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The purpose of this seminar is to provide students with an understanding of the role of firms in international trade. By completing this course, students will be able to answer questions such as: Why only a few firms export? How are they different than other firms? What is the role of intermediaries in facilitating trade? What is the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms? Upon the completion of this course, the students will be able to critically evaluate empirical research, especially in identifying causal effects using micro-data to answer policy-relevant questions.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this seminar, we will explore Finance’s fascinating history to generate valuable insights for today’s world. The seminar is organized around four themes (1) securities markets, with special emphasis on how information is processed by financial markets, (2) limited liability, with special emphasis on entrepreneurship and banking, (3) banking and financial crises, with special emphasis on banking regulation and the real effects of crises, and (4) politics and finance, with special emphasis on the interaction between finance and people’s political attitudes. This seminar is relevant for all students who are interested in why today’s financial system looks the way it does, what lessons we can draw from past failures and successes, and the implications this has for how we should organize financial markets and institutions today. Tasks include the presentation and discussion of scientific papers. For the final (group) assignment, students will write a policy brief based on historical research. Alternatively, students will get the opportunity to develop a thesis proposal.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the important role financial markets play in processing information, and how that information shapes real economic decisions.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: limited liability, and the role this plays in risk-taking decisions.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: the central role of banks and other financial institutions, the way they operate, and the inherent risks they pose.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into: how politics and finance can interact to have positive or negative impact on society.
• Students are able to: read, interpret and evaluate academic work.
• Students are able to: translate academic findings into policy relevant insights.
• Students are able to: write a concise and effective policy brief.
• Students are able to: identify potential thesis topics from the topics discussed in class.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Most traditional market boundaries have disappeared. Successful firms in sectors as diverse as consumer packaged goods, consumer durables, industrial goods, and services have discovered that traditional rules of competition – such as focusing only on the competitive interplay in each country separately – have changed dramatically in today’s globalized markets.

New strategies are determining who are the winners and the losers. Brands that respond proactively to the challenges of a globalized world, fast technological progress, and environmental concerns, outperform brands that are unable to adequately respond to a changed world. Even if firms decide not to be involved in the global or pan-regional (ASEAN, EU, Mercosur, USMCA, etc.) marketplace, they still face increased competition in their home markets because of nimble foreign competitors reaping the benefits of global brand strategies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Knowledge of factors and criteria to determine foreign market attractiveness.
• Understanding the different ways in which brands can be rolled out globally.
• Understanding the impact of digitalization on global brands.
• Understanding the impact of sustainability on global brands.
• Implementing global marketing strategies that are a smart combination of global standardization, local adaptation, and worldwide learning.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112374,2023,Seminar Global Firm Strategy,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. B Karreman', 'dr. Z Wang']",,"Inhoud

Firm globalization arises along four dimensions according to Gupta et al. (2008). As a first dimension, global market presence refers to the extent to which the firm is present across international markets and serves a worldwide customer base. Interestingly, there are not many firms with a truly global presence although some oil, car and retail companies do sell products in many different locations across the globe. As a second dimension, supply base globalization, involves the degree to which firms have sliced up their value chains globally to optimally exploit the advantages of different locations. For instance, production may take place in locations with cheap labor and access to excellent transport infrastructure while a firm’s R&D activities are located in high-tech clusters with a large pool of skilled labor. The globalization of the capital base can be perceived as a third dimension and reflects how the company has globalized its financial structure, including its listing and tax payment locations as well as places where it attracts operating capital and distributes profits. Finally, the globalization of the corporate mind-set reflects the extent to which firms are culturally inclusive and able to integrate new ideas and management practices from around the globe.

Accordingly, in devising their optimal globalization strategy firms are very selective when choosing locations to invest or source goods and services. As a result, not all locations are suitable for all types of firm investments, simply because they lack the appropriate specialized advantages. Economic activities therefore tend to be very concentrated in space.

The aim of this seminar is to understand how firms internationalize, how they grow and where they locate. Most notably, attention will be paid to the empirics of multinational strategy and foreign direct investment. During the first half of the course, students are expected to present, discuss and evaluate recent articles related to the topic of the course. In the second half of the course, students have to conduct an empirical study in which they combine econometric techniques with theories on the importance of firm globalization strategies and location.

• Conduct an empirical study on the location choice of firms using econometric techniques.

The exam is composed of three individual assignments (each 15%),  one group case report (35%), two presentations related to the case (each 5%), and the defense of the group case (5% group and 5% individual).
Only the group grade (50% = 35% + 5%*2 + 5%), individual grade (50% = 15%*3 + 5%) and final grade will be published in Osiris. The minimum grade for the individual and group grade is 5/10.
The re-sit counts for 100% of the final grade. The re-sit will consists of an individual component only, and there will be no group component.
Only the final grade of the re-sit will be published in Osiris.
It is not possible to do a re-sit when you already passed for the course.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/112361,2023,Seminar Institutional Asset Management,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. OW Steenbeek'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The seminar is structured around three main topics.

First, the course starts with analyzing the largest category of institutional investors based on assets under management, defined benefit and defined contribution pension funds. We will also study endowment funds and sovereign wealth funds, and compare the assets and liabilities of these institutional investors.

Second, the seminar will focus on the asset allocation policy implemented by institutional investors. We will answer two key questions. How do institutions decide on the level of capital to allocate to individual asset classes? How to implement the asset allocation? The seminar will discuss the issues of diversification, portfolio optimization, trading costs, passive and active strategies. We will discuss not only traditional investments in equity and fixed income, but also investments in alternative assets, like private equity, hedge funds and real estate. The students will also work on a quantitative assignment that analyzes the added value of alternative assets for the current portfolio of a pension fund.

Third, the seminar will cover in-depth the governance and organizational complexities surrounding institutional investors. This part of the course will discuss the fiduciary responsibilities of institutional investors and study the role of socially responsible investing and institutional shareholder activism. An important question is whether investing in this type of funds has consequences for institutional investors because of the inherent restriction of the universe of stocks.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The goal of this seminar is to get a good understanding of the way institutional asset managers invest large pools of money. The focus is on pension funds, sovereign wealth funds and endowments.
• Insights in the role of alternative asset classes in a portfolio, such as hedge funds, private equity and commodities.
• Insights in the difference and between active and passive investment strategies and the implications for asset management organization.
• Insights in the practice of responsible investing by institutional investors.
• Students will learn how to work in groups, participate in a discussion, critically read academic articles, present to an audience.
